description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
An aerobic dance is a complete physical workout that demands increasing oxygen consumption over an extended period of time. The continuous dance routine, like jogging, swimming, hiking, and other aerobic activities, improves and maintains the physiological functioning of the heart, lungs, and muscles. Dancing to popular music, participants walk, run, jump, skip, and stretch all throughout the workout which has three phases: 5 to 10 minutes warm-up exercises, 15 to 30 minutes aerobic dance routine, and 5 to 10 minutes cool down or limbering exercises. Aerobic dancing is usually done 2 to 3 times a week.

Aerobic dance was conceived and developed as a form of physical fitness program in 1971 by Jackie Sorensen, an American dancer. Sorensen rated “excellent” in the 12-minute run test developed by Kenneth Cooper, and concluded that her years of dance training had kept her fit. She then choreographed dance routines, combining disco and jazz steps and calisthenics movements for a 12-week program designed to improve cardiovascular endurance. Its popularity in the United States rose in the late 1970s, prompting dance and physical education instructors to create their own aerobic dance routines and conduct classes in fitness centers, health clubs, and schools.

 

 

In the Philippines, aerobic dance was introduced in 1978 by physical education instructor Vivian Zapanta at the Mandarin Fitness Center. The same year, Hatch and Reed Fitness Center and Baden Haus Health and Fitness Center started offering aerobic dance classes. In 1982, Zapanta conducted a 15-minute aerobic dance class on TV as part of the variety program She. She has also taught aerobic dance and exercise on Sports Review.

In 1983, Amelia Zafra and Benita Maria P. Barros, both physical education professors of the University of the Philippines (UP), introduced aerobic dancing to the public at the Quezon City Sports Memorial Circle. The UP Department of Physical Education started offering aerobic dance classes the same year. The University of Santo Tomas and Far Eastern University began offering classes in the late 1980s. In the mid-1980s, aerobic dance invaded public and private offices and corporations in Metro Manila. Aerobic dance became a permanent physical fitness activity in health, fitness, and sports centers.

Aerobic dance workouts have been classified based on the intensity of the workout. The high-energy or high-impact aerobic dance involves vigorous jumping and hopping all throughout the routine and is recommended for those who have attained a high level of fitness. The low-impact aerobic dance workout is designed for beginners and requires less jumping and hopping; one foot is always in contact with the floor. Both types of workout, however, produce the same physical benefits. Other workouts include the use of light and free weights, usually held in the hands or attached to the lower legs, to improve specific muscle strength and muscle endurance as well as develop general stamina.  Written by Benita Maria P. Barros

 

Sources

De Leon, Eloisa. 1990. Interview by Benita Maria P. Barros. November, Manila.

Sorensen, Jackie. 1981. Aerobic Dancing. New York: Rawson, Wade Publications, Inc.

Zafra, Amelia. 1990. Interview by Benita Maria P. Barros. Department of Physical Education, University of the East. October, Manila.

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Atang-atang (offering) is an elaborate ceremony to heal the sick. The ceremony is performed by women healers or mang-atang with ritual chanting and dancing. This custom is practiced in Cagayan Valley, particularly by the Ibanag. A similar, and perhaps primordial, form of the atang-atang is the Ibanag’s mawwari, performed by a mangilu (healer) at times when a family member’s sickness is caused by a malevolent spirit. The mangilu traces the place where the argamasingan or agirigira (malevolent spirit) comes from. Cigars, candies, eggs, biscuits, and other red-colored offerings are placed on the selected spot. The ritual is accompanied by the beating of a maganllag or gong, which is tied around the waist of the healer.

Just like the mawwari, the atang-atang is done when the illness is caused by angered spirits. But instead of a gong, Catholic prayers are chanted during the atang-atang. The elaborate ritual starts with the construction of a bamboo raft. A white altar is built upon the raft and embellished with red and yellow paper cut-outs. The healers prepare offerings to appease the spirits: a white chicken, native eggs, coconut oil, rice, betel nut, rice cake, a white candle, and a three-day old chick whose leg is tied to the raft. The chick’s crying symbolizes the sick person’s voice.

 

 

The mang-atang rubs oil on the sick person’s face, neck, torso, and limbs. The blood from the neck of the sacrificial chicken is applied on the patient’s face and body. The women healers dedicate the offerings with chanted prayers and ritual dancing. As the mang-atang chants the Catholic prayers, ritualists freely move and sway arms in a fast and free manner that is contrapuntal to the slow rendition of the chanted prayer. Footwork is likewise unhampered by any counting, allowing the ritualist to turn or to move from place to place while dancing. The faces of the dancing mang-atang are expressionless and glassy-eyed.

The raft is carried to the river bank, where the sacrificial chicken is beheaded and thrown into the river. Its soul is expected to swim to the encanto or nature spirit that inflicted the illness. Thereafter, another sacrificial animal, such as a pig, is slaughtered. The mang-atang believes that its screams will get the attention of the supernatural beings and elicit their compassion. The pig’s blood is collected in a container with oil and placed under the balete or ficus tree, which is believed to be the spirits’ dwelling place. Then the raft is released on the river, in the hope that it will reach the abode of the angry spirits.  Written by Rosalie S. Matilac

 

See also

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
The balitaw is an extemporaneous exchange of love verses between a man and a woman. Danced and mimed, it is accompanied by a song, or the dancers themselves sing, improvising the steps and verses. It may last for hours, ending with the woman accepting or rejecting the man’s suit. The balitaw is found mainly in the Tagalog and Visayan regions. The dancers may be costumed in balintawak or patadyong (tubular skirt) or in contemporary everyday clothes. Its accompaniment could be provided by a subing (bamboo flute), castanets, coconut guitar, harp, five-stringed guitar, or a combination of the three. The Visayan balitaw is usually in the minor key, while the Tagalog is in the major. Both are related to the kumintang and kundiman in their styles of accenting.

As sung in quatrain or ballad stanza in the Visayas, it is extensive and sensual with accompaniment similar to the bolero, a Spanish dance also in triple time, accompanied by the dancers’ singing and castanet playing. In words which may be humorous and full of energy, the typical Visayan balitaw speaks of all domestic phases of life, from love and courtship, marriage and separation, gambling and employment, child rearing, envious neighbors, to the dignity of labor. The Cebuano couple Pedro Alfarara and Nicolasa Caniban were acclaimed as the “king and queen” of the balitaw at the turn of the century.

 

 

Francisca Reyes-Aquino recorded three balitaw dances, all courtship dances, with or without the singing. The dancing itself may or may not illustrate the words, which could be humorous. In one version, a flower is used to represent beauty, to attract attention, and to accept (or reject) a suitor. Straightforward dancing or mime with pleading and gesturing “no” with a finger may portray the courtship.

Hispanized, the dance includes waltz steps, paso español (a waltz combination and step-brush-swing hop) and the do-si-do (changing around in a square). Indigenous is the use of the kumintang gesture (wrist circling) that embellishes many figures of the dance.

The tirana may have been a later innovation on the old balitaw, made possible by the Spanish-style five-stringed guitar which could provide a more varied music than the native three-stringed coconut shell guitar. Unlike the “noisy” balitaw, the tirana is gentler, with more hand gestures and simple shuffling foot movements.

An example of the tirana verse runs:

Akong awitan si Tirana

Tirana bitaw’ng makalolo-oy

Sama sa isda nga balyena,

Sa dagat nga naglangoy-langoy.

Sama sa isda nga balyena,

Sa dagat intawon naglangoy-langoy.

Kon malo-oy ka, ako hagki,

Pangasaw-a ayaw biya-i.

Panga-agyud ug amomaha,

Pakataw-a, ayaw pahilaka.

 

(I will sing to Tirana,

Tirana who is pitiful.

Like the whale,

swimming in the sea.

Like the whale,

swimming in the sea,

If you pity me, kiss me,

Marry me, do not leave me.

Love me, do not leave me.

Make me happy, don’t make me cry.)

 Written by Basilio Esteban E. Villaruz

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
A dance performed by the Applais tribe in Western Mountain Province, the ballangbang or tallibeng is a reenactment of a tribal war. The dancers mimic the movement of spies, bending forward as if to snoop on or hide from their enemies, then straightening their bodies and moving backward as if to protect themselves. The snooping and hiding is clearly seen in the entrance steps; for example, where dancers hop forward with upper bodies bending in the same direction, then quickly step back, with upper bodies returning to an erect position. There are also movements that seem to signify “attack”—dancers lunging to the right then alternating with the left, followed by three sliding steps made by the same foot. The whole time, male dancers beat on their gongs while female dancers either have their arms akimbo or stretched sideways, with elbows bent, hands in a fist, and thumbs pointing up.

 

The ballangbang is a ritual dance performed during weddings and before planting and harvesting seasons. All dancers wear a bedbed (also apong) or woven cloth around their heads. The men wear a wanes or loincloth while the women don a gabey (also gaboy), a three-piece woven cloth held together by a bakget or woven belt. The ballangbang is also a festival dance quite similar to the pattong, as well as the other festival dances of the Cordillera region, in that it is performed mainly to entertain visitors. The only difference between the ballangbang and the pattong is that in the former, female dancers enter side-by-side with the men. Thus, effort is placed on varying the formations of the dancers and on the synchronicity of their movements.  Written by Sarah Lumba

 

See also

Indigenous Traditions and Transformations in Philippine Dance
Martial Dance
Ritual Dancing

 

Source

Taguba, Remedios, and Carmen T. Andin, eds. 1994. Cordillera Ethnic Dances: A Manual for Teachers. Manila: National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

text:
Sections

Modern Ballet
Opera Ballet
Folkloric Ballet

 

Ballet is a theatrical dance presentation with a choreographic or dramatic plot that integrates music, dancing, and stage designs (sets, costumes, and lighting). Ballet refers to a technique and style of dancing strictly based on a well-codified theatrical school of dance or danse d’ecole. The word ballet comes from Latin ballare (to dance) and Italian balletto, the diminutive of ballo (dance).

The ballet evolved from the European court spectacles that combined verse and story, music and designs, mime and dance, to create an operatic or dramatic form. One of these spectacles arranged by the Italian Catherine de Medici, then Queen Mother of France, was the Ballet Comique de la Reine, 1581, which was considered the first ballet.

 

 

The formation of the ballet’s enduring academic base was achieved by the Academie Royale de la Danse in 1661 under the reign of Louis XIV, himself a dancer. The Academie codified the ballet technique and style to compose the danse d’ecole. In the 1700s, the ballet was strengthened as a dramatic expression with the efforts of Franz Anton Christoph Hilverding and Gaspero Angiolini in Vienna, Jean Georges Noverre in Stuttgart and Vienna, Salvatore Vigano in Milan, Charles Didelot in St Petersburg, and Vincenzo Galeotti and Antoine Bournonville in Denmark. Their ballets stressed plot and character portrayal in the structures called ballet d’action, choreodrama, and other realistic productions.

In the first half of the 1800s, a greater degree of stylization developed, with the introduction of dancing on pointe or the tips of the toes. The influence of the Romantic Movement produced acclaimed prima ballerinas like Marie Taglioni, Fanny Elssler, Carlotta Grisi, and Fanny Cerrito, and created fantastic roles in operas like Robert le Diable, 1831, or in ballets like La Sylphide, 1832, and Giselle, 1841.

The ballet declined as an art form in Europe in the latter half of the 19th century. In Tsarist Russia, however, the Frenchman Marius Petipa and his collaborator Lev Ivanov staged numerous full-evening ballets that were to define ballet classicism as it is known today. Ballet masterpieces were choreographed to the music of Peter Ilyich Tchaikovsky, such as The Sleeping Beauty, 1890, The Nutcracker, 1892, and Swan Lake, 1895, and other three- to four-act ballets to the music of court composers like Ludwig Minkus, Ricardo Drigo, and later, Alexander Glazounov.

In the early 20th century, Michel Fokine, Vaslav Nijinsky, Leonide Massine, Bronislava Nijinska, and George Balanchine modified the ballet into the predominant one-act form produced by Serge Diaghilev for his Ballets Russes. They revivified the ballet in Europe with their choreographies and their dancing, together with ballerinas like Mathilde Kchessinska, Anna Pavlova, and Tamara Karsavina. This influence was also felt with the contributions of Alexander Benois, Leon Bakst, Pablo Picasso, Henri Matisse, and Giorgio di Chirico, in design; and Igor Stravinsky, Serge Prokofiev, Maurice Ravel, Manuel de Falla, and the French Les Six, in music.

Ballet in England and America gained greater following after the tours of Anna Pavlova, the Ballets Russes of Diaghilev, and later, of Colonel de Basil, and Rene Blum. After the 1917 revolution in Russia and the dispersal of the Ballets Russes companies, many dancers and teachers spread throughout Europe, America, and Asia. Other than the first known English teacher Kay Williams, early ballet teachers in the Philippines in the 1920s and 1930s included Russians like Katrina Makarova who taught Anita Kane in Manila, Mara Selheim who taught Fe Sala-Villarica in Cebu, and briefly, Olga Dontsov, and Vladimir Bolsky.

The most influential was the Polish-Russian emigre Lubov “Luva” Adameit. In her Cosmopolitan Ballet and Dancing School established in 1927, Adameit taught, among others, Remedios de Oteyza, Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, and Rosalia Merino-Santos, who became the Philippines’ first homegrown dancers, teachers, and choreographers of note.

Among the earliest known visiting performers were the Australian Lilliputians with their little “ballet girls,” 1901, the Infantile company from Japan, and the dancers of the Baroufski Imperial Russian Circus, 1902. In 1915 and 1916, the mysterious Paul Nijinsky, who claimed descent from the imperial school in St Petersburg, performed in Manila. In 1922, Anna Pavlova and her company danced at the Manila Grand Opera House during one of two Asian tours.

Most of the prominent dancers, teachers, and choreographers descended from Kane, de Oteyza, Orosa-Goquingco, and Merino-Santos. Hungarian Paul Szilard and American Ricardo Cassell were also very influential. Their small companies, such as the De Oteyza Ballet (later the Manila Ballet Company), the Studio Dance Group, the Anita Kane Ballet Company (later the Pamana Ballet), Ballet Theatre Philippines, and the folkloric Filipinescas Dance Company produced dancers who would set up the first professional companies—Hariraya Dance (later Ballet) Company and Dance Theater Philippines, both founded in 1968.

Further reconstitution of these groups gradually led to the organization of the two major companies today, Ballet Philippines (not to be confused with the similarly named Ballet Philippines in the early 1960s) in 1970, and Philippine Ballet Theatre in 1986, and Ballet Manila in 1995. These three professional companies stage the most significant productions from the ballet classics to the contemporary works of foreign and Filipino choreographers in the Philippines and abroad.

Other notable companies are the Dance Concert Company founded in 1970, the Manila Metropolis Ballet in 1978, and the Quezon City Ballet in 1988. Most groups and companies have studio-type schools, some internationally accredited. Two universities offer dance degree programs. Annual seasons and festivals sustain the professional life and the public following of this theatrical art. Some outstanding Filipino dancers, such as Benjamin Reyes, Josefa Reyes, Tina Santos, and Maniya Barredo, have made their mark in companies, musical comedies, competitions, and festivals worldwide.

Modern Ballet

Modern ballet is a dance production of contemporary content but utilizing classical ballet technique and style. The movements may accommodate some modern dance devices and techniques, like contraction and release, fall and recovery, bound and rebound; they may also include natural rather than classical mime and reflect a contemporary tempo. It may, for instance, use pointe technique in an earthy and sharp manner rather than in the ethereal and fluent ideal of romantic ballet.

Modern ballet dates from the Ballets Russes de Serge Diaghilev period (1909-29) and its influence in Europe. Isadora Duncan influenced Michel Fokine, and Kasyan Goleizovsky in Russia influenced George Balanchine and other choreographers. Vaslav Nijinsky (Afternoon of a Faune, 1912, Rite of Spring and Jeux, both 1913, and Til Eulenspiegel, 1916) and his sister Bronislava Nijinska (Les Noces, 1923, Les Biches, and Le Train Bleu, both 1924) also broke new ground.

There were also works that depicted the machine age, its automation and dehumanization. An example is Adolph Bolm’s Iron Foundry, 1932, also known as Ballet Mechanique, set to Alexander Mossolov’s percussive music. In 1939, Trudl Dubsky-Zipper also choreographed Iron Foundry in the Philippines. Her company, 1939-41, was called Manila Ballet Moderne.

Modern ballet also deals with subjects relating to social conflicts, urban issues, and psychological anxieties. Examples of these are the various versions of Bela Bartok’s The Miraculous Mandarin since 1926; the several versions of Soviet realism in The Red Poppy, 1927, and Golden Age, 1930; Kurt Jooss’s The Green Table, 1932; Lew Christensen’s Filling Station, 1938; Eugene Loring’s Billy the Kid, 1938; Antony Tudor’s Pillar of Fire, 1942; Agnes de Mille’s Rodeo, 1942; Jerome Robbins’s Fancy Free, 1944; Beijing’s Red Detachment of Women, 1964; and Rudy van Dantzig’s Monument for a Dead Boy, 1965. These ballets convey contemporary meanings, but should be distinguished from Martha Graham’s style, with its Greek and American themes, or Twyla Tharp’s way of tracing a story or commenting on styles in her elliptical, crisp, and quick method. Although the works of Graham and Tharp are also called ballets, they are properly modern dances.

Other Philippine examples of modern ballet include Eric Cruz, Eddie Elejar, and Alice Reyes’s respective treatments of the Carmen story in 1976, 1980, and 1984; and the various interpretations of Nick Joaquin’s short story, in Felicitas Layag-Radaic’s May Day Eve, 1971, Lydia Madarang-Gaston’s Anak-Bulan (Moon Child), 1976, and Basilio’s Agueda, 1991. Other ballets are Elejar’s Gates of Hell, 1968, on vengeance; and Masks, 1981, on identities, based on Virginia Moreno’s poem, “Order for Masks;” Luis Layag’s Positive-Negative, 1970, on contrasts; Layag-Radaic’s The Prey, 1973, on humanoids; Basilio’s La Lampara (The Lamp), 1980, on Jose Rizal’s life and writings, Testament, 1980, on alienation, and Sweet Warfare, 1982, on the battle of the sexes; Tony Fabella’s Limang Dipa (Five Armstretches), 1981, on a street scene in Manila, and Beautiful Girls, 1990, on beauty contests. They not only deal with themes relevant to contemporary life but also employ modern theatrical staging devices. These ballets use Filipino or foreign contemporary music.

Opera Ballet

Opera ballet is a dance within the context of an opera which may elucidate an idea or symbol, advance a plot, set a place in a vision or a festivity, or present a straightforward divertissement.

Ballet in operas became obligatory in France in the 1800s, so that even Richard Wagner had to add a bacchanal ballet in Tannhauser and Giuseppe Verdi in Il Trovatore and Othello when these were presented in France. When there is dancing in George Bizet’s Carmen, the music is interpolated from his other works. Opera ballet may also mean the dancing ensemble permanently attached to most European opera houses, performing most of the dances in opera productions.

New York Metropolitan Opera choreographer Boris Romanoff says that contemporary productions stress dancing as part of the whole opera ensemble and in harmony with the overall style of the presentation. He explains the value of this fusion: “The dance in opera must be expressive to the highest degree and in many instances it must be able to contain within itself the meaning and development of the action of the entire scene or act.” Even when stylized, it must “reflect the iconographic and architectural art of a given period” (Romanoff 1949, 337-9).

Philippine opera productions have utilized the choreographies of Trudl Dubsky-Zipper, Remedios de Oteyza, Veda Bañez, and Edna Vida. As a special genre, the opera ballet spanned the late 1600s to the early 1700s, particularly in France. This genre ties singing and dancing together in a “lyric theatre, more spectacular than dramatic” (Harris 1977, 260-2). It is largely “a combination of the Italian opera and the French court ballet” (Wilson 1974, 368). A modern descendant of the opera ballet is the rock opera ballet which brought singing and dancing in equal balance to create a new musical theater in the 1970s. In the Philippines, a ballet company example was Tommy with music by The Who, choreographed in Canada by Fernand Nault in 1970, and in the Philippines by Alice Reyes in 1972. Another was Jesus Christ Superstar, with music by Andrew Lloyd Webber and lyrics by Tim Rice, which enjoyed several Philippine productions in 1972, choreographed by Amelia Apolinario, Alice Reyes, and many others after. Still another was The Survival of St Joan, with music by Smokerise, lyrics by James Lineberger, choreographed by Luis Layag in 1973.

Original Filipino rock opera ballets came with Mahal (Beloved), with music by Abel Labrador and Mon Faustmann, libretto by Rahissa Lahat-Wala, choreographed by Julie and Rose Borromeo in 1975; Tales of the Manuvu, with music by Nonong Pedero and the Afterbirth and libretto by Bienvenido Lumbera, choreographed by Alice Reyes in 1977 and by Rene Hofileña in 1988; and Rama, Hari (Rama, King), with music by Ryan Cayabyab and libretto by Lumbera, choreographed by Alice Reyes in 1980.

Folkloric Ballet

Folkloric ballet is a manner of theatrical presentation that utilizes the stories, themes, motifs, and styles found in the arts and culture of the ordinary people or folk. These are adapted to contemporary theater by editing, ordering, and stylizing the primary materials of folk music, dances, dramas, literature, and visual arts.

Folkloric ballet pioneer Leonor Orosa-Goquingco imbued “the Philippine dance not only with stylization and theatricalization, but also with a theme, a plot, a storyline—with characterization, symbolism, narrative, and drama. She produced original dance compositions inspired by a line from history, or from a novel, or a legend or other literary sources” (Orosa 1980). In Filipinescas: Philippine Life, Legend and Lore in Dance, she presented the following: “Eons Ago: The Legends of Creation” which showed how the bird, the sky, and sea, and the first man and woman came to be; “Long, Long Ago: Tribal Story” which interpreted dances from the Cordillera; “Long Ago: Morolandia” composed of “Obay-a-Ragat” or “By the Sea” and “Malas Kalilag” or “Royal Wedding”; “Yesterday: Cuadros Filipinos,” which showed flagellants, cockfights, and Jose Rizal’s fictional character, Maria Clara; and “Today: The Bird and the Planters,” which ends with the bird-costumed tinikling.

The contemporary repertoire of folkloric ballets include Basilio’s Tropical Tapestry, Agnes Locsin’s Igorot, Gener Caringal’s Vinta and Ang Sultan (The Sultan), Eddie Elejar’s Katakata Sin Rajah Indarapatra (Stories of Rajah Indarapatra), Alice Reyes’s Tapestry/Bayanihan Remembered, and Corazon Generoso-Iñigo’s Baile de Ayer (Dance of Yesteryears).  Written by Basilio Esteban E. Villaruz

article.value: Written by Basilio Esteban E. Villaruz

Ballet is a theatrical dance presentation with a choreographic or dramatic plot that integrates music, dancing, and stage designs (sets, costumes, and lighting). Ballet refers to a technique and style of dancing strictly based on a well-codified theatrical school of dance or danse d’ecole. The word ballet comes from Latin ballare (to dance) and Italian balletto, the diminutive of ballo (dance).

The ballet evolved from the European court spectacles that combined verse and story, music and designs, mime and dance, to create an operatic or dramatic form. One of these spectacles arranged by the Italian Catherine de Medici, then Queen Mother of France, was the Ballet Comique de la Reine, 1581, which was considered the first ballet.

article.value: The formation of the ballet’s enduring academic base was achieved by the Academie Royale de la Danse in 1661 under the reign of Louis XIV, himself a dancer. The Academie codified the ballet technique and style to compose the danse d’ecole. In the 1700s, the ballet was strengthened as a dramatic expression with the efforts of Franz Anton Christoph Hilverding and Gaspero Angiolini in Vienna, Jean Georges Noverre in Stuttgart and Vienna, Salvatore Vigano in Milan, Charles Didelot in St Petersburg, and Vincenzo Galeotti and Antoine Bournonville in Denmark. Their ballets stressed plot and character portrayal in the structures called ballet d’action, choreodrama, and other realistic productions.

In the first half of the 1800s, a greater degree of stylization developed, with the introduction of dancing on pointe or the tips of the toes. The influence of the Romantic Movement produced acclaimed prima ballerinas like Marie Taglioni, Fanny Elssler, Carlotta Grisi, and Fanny Cerrito, and created fantastic roles in operas like Robert le Diable, 1831, or in ballets like La Sylphide, 1832, and Giselle, 1841.

The ballet declined as an art form in Europe in the latter half of the 19th century. In Tsarist Russia, however, the Frenchman Marius Petipa and his collaborator Lev Ivanov staged numerous full-evening ballets that were to define ballet classicism as it is known today. Ballet masterpieces were choreographed to the music of Peter Ilyich Tchaikovsky, such as The Sleeping Beauty, 1890, The Nutcracker, 1892, and Swan Lake, 1895, and other three- to four-act ballets to the music of court composers like Ludwig Minkus, Ricardo Drigo, and later, Alexander Glazounov.

In the early 20th century, Michel Fokine, Vaslav Nijinsky, Leonide Massine, Bronislava Nijinska, and George Balanchine modified the ballet into the predominant one-act form produced by Serge Diaghilev for his Ballets Russes. They revivified the ballet in Europe with their choreographies and their dancing, together with ballerinas like Mathilde Kchessinska, Anna Pavlova, and Tamara Karsavina. This influence was also felt with the contributions of Alexander Benois, Leon Bakst, Pablo Picasso, Henri Matisse, and Giorgio di Chirico, in design; and Igor Stravinsky, Serge Prokofiev, Maurice Ravel, Manuel de Falla, and the French Les Six, in music.

Ballet in England and America gained greater following after the tours of Anna Pavlova, the Ballets Russes of Diaghilev, and later, of Colonel de Basil, and Rene Blum. After the 1917 revolution in Russia and the dispersal of the Ballets Russes companies, many dancers and teachers spread throughout Europe, America, and Asia. Other than the first known English teacher Kay Williams, early ballet teachers in the Philippines in the 1920s and 1930s included Russians like Katrina Makarova who taught Anita Kane in Manila, Mara Selheim who taught Fe Sala-Villarica in Cebu, and briefly, Olga Dontsov, and Vladimir Bolsky.

The most influential was the Polish-Russian emigre Lubov “Luva” Adameit. In her Cosmopolitan Ballet and Dancing School established in 1927, Adameit taught, among others, Remedios de Oteyza, Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, and Rosalia Merino-Santos, who became the Philippines’ first homegrown dancers, teachers, and choreographers of note.

Among the earliest known visiting performers were the Australian Lilliputians with their little “ballet girls,” 1901, the Infantile company from Japan, and the dancers of the Baroufski Imperial Russian Circus, 1902. In 1915 and 1916, the mysterious Paul Nijinsky, who claimed descent from the imperial school in St Petersburg, performed in Manila. In 1922, Anna Pavlova and her company danced at the Manila Grand Opera House during one of two Asian tours.

Most of the prominent dancers, teachers, and choreographers descended from Kane, de Oteyza, Orosa-Goquingco, and Merino-Santos. Hungarian Paul Szilard and American Ricardo Cassell were also very influential. Their small companies, such as the De Oteyza Ballet (later the Manila Ballet Company), the Studio Dance Group, the Anita Kane Ballet Company (later the Pamana Ballet), Ballet Theatre Philippines, and the folkloric Filipinescas Dance Company produced dancers who would set up the first professional companies—Hariraya Dance (later Ballet) Company and Dance Theater Philippines, both founded in 1968.

Further reconstitution of these groups gradually led to the organization of the two major companies today, Ballet Philippines (not to be confused with the similarly named Ballet Philippines in the early 1960s) in 1970, and Philippine Ballet Theatre in 1986, and Ballet Manila in 1995. These three professional companies stage the most significant productions from the ballet classics to the contemporary works of foreign and Filipino choreographers in the Philippines and abroad.

Other notable companies are the Dance Concert Company founded in 1970, the Manila Metropolis Ballet in 1978, and the Quezon City Ballet in 1988. Most groups and companies have studio-type schools, some internationally accredited. Two universities offer dance degree programs. Annual seasons and festivals sustain the professional life and the public following of this theatrical art. Some outstanding Filipino dancers, such as Benjamin Reyes, Josefa Reyes, Tina Santos, and Maniya Barredo, have made their mark in companies, musical comedies, competitions, and festivals worldwide.
Modern Ballet

Modern ballet is a dance production of contemporary content but utilizing classical ballet technique and style. The movements may accommodate some modern dance devices and techniques, like contraction and release, fall and recovery, bound and rebound; they may also include natural rather than classical mime and reflect a contemporary tempo. It may, for instance, use pointe technique in an earthy and sharp manner rather than in the ethereal and fluent ideal of romantic ballet.

Modern ballet dates from the Ballets Russes de Serge Diaghilev period (1909-29) and its influence in Europe. Isadora Duncan influenced Michel Fokine, and Kasyan Goleizovsky in Russia influenced George Balanchine and other choreographers. Vaslav Nijinsky (Afternoon of a Faune, 1912, Rite of Spring and Jeux, both 1913, and Til Eulenspiegel, 1916) and his sister Bronislava Nijinska (Les Noces, 1923, Les Biches, and Le Train Bleu, both 1924) also broke new ground.

There were also works that depicted the machine age, its automation and dehumanization. An example is Adolph Bolm’s Iron Foundry, 1932, also known as Ballet Mechanique, set to Alexander Mossolov’s percussive music. In 1939, Trudl Dubsky-Zipper also choreographed Iron Foundry in the Philippines. Her company, 1939-41, was called Manila Ballet Moderne.

Modern ballet also deals with subjects relating to social conflicts, urban issues, and psychological anxieties. Examples of these are the various versions of Bela Bartok’s The Miraculous Mandarin since 1926; the several versions of Soviet realism in The Red Poppy, 1927, and Golden Age, 1930; Kurt Jooss’s The Green Table, 1932; Lew Christensen’s Filling Station, 1938; Eugene Loring’s Billy the Kid, 1938; Antony Tudor’s Pillar of Fire, 1942; Agnes de Mille’s Rodeo, 1942; Jerome Robbins’s Fancy Free, 1944; Beijing’s Red Detachment of Women, 1964; and Rudy van Dantzig’s Monument for a Dead Boy, 1965. These ballets convey contemporary meanings, but should be distinguished from Martha Graham’s style, with its Greek and American themes, or Twyla Tharp’s way of tracing a story or commenting on styles in her elliptical, crisp, and quick method. Although the works of Graham and Tharp are also called ballets, they are properly modern dances.

Other Philippine examples of modern ballet include Eric Cruz, Eddie Elejar, and Alice Reyes’s respective treatments of the Carmen story in 1976, 1980, and 1984; and the various interpretations of Nick Joaquin’s short story, in Felicitas Layag-Radaic’s May Day Eve, 1971, Lydia Madarang-Gaston’s Anak-Bulan (Moon Child), 1976, and Basilio’s Agueda, 1991. Other ballets are Elejar’s Gates of Hell, 1968, on vengeance; and Masks, 1981, on identities, based on Virginia Moreno’s poem, “Order for Masks;” Luis Layag’s Positive-Negative, 1970, on contrasts; Layag-Radaic’s The Prey, 1973, on humanoids; Basilio’s La Lampara (The Lamp), 1980, on Jose Rizal’s life and writings, Testament, 1980, on alienation, and Sweet Warfare, 1982, on the battle of the sexes; Tony Fabella’s Limang Dipa (Five Armstretches), 1981, on a street scene in Manila, and Beautiful Girls, 1990, on beauty contests. They not only deal with themes relevant to contemporary life but also employ modern theatrical staging devices. These ballets use Filipino or foreign contemporary music.
Opera Ballet
Opera ballet is a dance within the context of an opera which may elucidate an idea or symbol, advance a plot, set a place in a vision or a festivity, or present a straightforward divertissement.

Ballet in operas became obligatory in France in the 1800s, so that even Richard Wagner had to add a bacchanal ballet in Tannhauser and Giuseppe Verdi in Il Trovatore and Othello when these were presented in France. When there is dancing in George Bizet’s Carmen, the music is interpolated from his other works. Opera ballet may also mean the dancing ensemble permanently attached to most European opera houses, performing most of the dances in opera productions.

New York Metropolitan Opera choreographer Boris Romanoff says that contemporary productions stress dancing as part of the whole opera ensemble and in harmony with the overall style of the presentation. He explains the value of this fusion: “The dance in opera must be expressive to the highest degree and in many instances it must be able to contain within itself the meaning and development of the action of the entire scene or act.” Even when stylized, it must “reflect the iconographic and architectural art of a given period” (Romanoff 1949, 337-9).

Philippine opera productions have utilized the choreographies of Trudl Dubsky-Zipper, Remedios de Oteyza, Veda Bañez, and Edna Vida. As a special genre, the opera ballet spanned the late 1600s to the early 1700s, particularly in France. This genre ties singing and dancing together in a “lyric theatre, more spectacular than dramatic” (Harris 1977, 260-2). It is largely “a combination of the Italian opera and the French court ballet” (Wilson 1974, 368). These are adapted to contemporary theater by editing, ordering, and stylizing the primary materials of folk music, dances, dramas, literature, and visual arts.

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
The balse, from the Spanish valse and the Viennese waltz (meaning “to turn”), is characterized by a series of continuous turning steps in closed ballroom-dance position to a musical accompaniment in fast 3/4 time. It was introduced and assimilated in the Philippines during the Spanish period. In Philippine folk dances, the balse is called the waltz step or turn performed as a step, close, step, in distinction to the folk waltz of the West which is a step, step, close. The waltz balance is a step, close, and a rise on the ball of the second foot, and a step in place of the first foot. The cross-waltz is a step across in front, a close, and step. Two folk dance steps—the sway-balance and the engaño—may end with a waltz as part of the combination.

There is no precise information on the exact origin of the waltz. Castel-Blaze contends that the waltz is a direct descendant of the galliard. In Orchesographie, 1588, Thoinot Arbeau described the volta, a turning dance of Provence, which some believe is the mother of the waltz. Most dance authorities agree that the German deutcher (also called tedesco) and the Austrian landler are the more direct forerunners of the waltz.

 

 

After its ascent from its folk base, and despite strong prohibitions from moralists, the waltz conquered the dance floor. Prudes objected mainly to the close ballroom hold which was called an indecent embrace, the joyous exuberance which was considered wild, and the holding of the tail of the skirt close to the breast. All these were interpreted as scandalous behavior. The appeal of the waltz was such that the different countries evolved their own variations, with the Viennese waltz remaining supreme in style and execution.

When danced in ballroom style, the Philippine balse comes closest to a combination of the fast Viennese and the slower Boston waltzes. It has no set steps, sequences, or definite style, but is danced according to individual preference and skill. The waltz is included in at least 224 documented Philippine European-style dances.

A few balse have been documented. The balse tagalog from Marikina is performed after a religious procession, the lutrina, which involves continuous praying with candles while walking with the image of a patron saint or crucifix. It is meant to alleviate pestilence or drought, and ends at the home of the hermana mayor or sponsor where the balse is performed amidst feasting.

The balse vieja or waltz of antiquity is from Pangasinan and is usually performed on important social occasions. The garambal is coined from “gran” (grand) and “bal” (balse), and is performed by two girls and one boy. Strangely enough, the dance does not include a waltz in its figures. The jotabal is a festival dance from Gumaca, Quezon, combining the rhythm of the jota which is in 2/4 time and the balse in 3/4 time.

The mazurka valse, also from Gumaca, features unique figures where the girl steps on the feet of the boy. They then proceed to do mincing step turns, walking steps, and lift the feet sideways right and left. article.value: Written by Corazon Generoso-Iñigo

There is no precise information on the exact origin of the waltz. Castel-Blaze contends that the waltz is a direct descendant of the galliard. In Orchesographie, 1588, Thoinot Arbeau described the volta, a turning dance of Provence, which some believe is the mother of the waltz. Most dance authorities agree that the German deutcher (also called tedesco) and the Austrian landler are the more direct forerunners of the waltz.

After its ascent from its folk base, and despite strong prohibitions from moralists, the waltz conquered the dance floor. Prudes objected mainly to the close ballroom hold which was called an indecent embrace, the joyous exuberance which was considered wild, and the holding of the tail of the skirt close to the breast. All these were interpreted as scandalous behavior. The appeal of the waltz was such that the different countries evolved their own variations, with the Viennese waltz remaining supreme in style and execution.

When danced in ballroom style, the Philippine balse comes closest to a combination of the fast Viennese and the slower Boston waltzes. It has no set steps, sequences, or definite style, but is danced according to individual preference and skill. The waltz is included in at least 224 documented Philippine European-style dances.

A few balse have been documented. The balse tagalog from Marikina is performed after a religious procession, the lutrina, which involves continuous praying with candles while walking with the image of a patron saint or crucifix. It is meant to alleviate pestilence or drought, and ends at the home of the hermana mayor or sponsor where the balse is performed amidst feasting.

The balse vieja or waltz of antiquity is from Pangasinan and is usually performed on important social occasions. The garambal is coined from “gran” (grand) and “bal” (balse), and is performed by two girls and one boy. Strangely enough, the dance does not include a waltz in its figures. The jotabal is a festival dance from Gumaca, Quezon, combining the rhythm of the jota which is in 2/4 time and the balse in 3/4 time.

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
This dance became popular in the early 1970s and was part of Kayaw (Headhunt), 1974, a folk dance choreography by Ramon Obusan premiered at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Before the 1960s, a dance balancing pots on a woman’s head was unknown in Kalinga because it was not a tradition to dance while carrying a pot, or pots, filled with water collected from a river or stream. The formation of dance troupes in the early 1970s, concentrated in Lubuagan area and supported by religious institutions, encouraged the creative inclination of the Kalinga to improvise and create new choreography that eventually became part of what is considered to be traditional, such as the skill dance called banga.

Of all the Cordillera dances, the banga, also known as kinkinaton or pot dance of the Kalinga, probably brings out the most excitement in any audience. For the highlight of the dance, the female dancers carry and balance banga or clay pots of different sizes on their heads while keeping to the syncopated beat produced by six or more gangsa, or gong, players. The number of pots to be used depends on the skill of the dancers and the sizes of the pots. There could be as many as seven pots on a dancer’s head, arranged according to size, with the smallest pot on top. To provide a stable base, female dancers put on a dikon or crown made of ligis or palm leaves before placing the first—and largest—banga on their heads.

 

As in other highland dances, the banga’s music starts slow but builds up toward a more rapid syncopation, thus requiring dancers to perform exhilarating movements that correspond to the changing rhythm. Aside from worrying about clay pots, dancers also need to ensure that their movements are synchronized with the whole group.

With or without the pots, all the dancers’ feet are kept busy doing either the spring-and-swing step, which is a small hop on the right foot on the first count and a swing forward, backward or sideward of the left on the second count; the pivot; or the lunge. The male dancers’ upper bodies are usually slightly bent forward while the female dancers need to constantly sway their hips to the beat. The females have their arms either akimbo or in a dopa, i.e., stretched sideways, with palms facing out and fingers pointing up. Initially, the males hold the pots. Once the men place the pots on the women’s heads, female dancers must keep their upper torsos erect, while maintaining the hip and the arm movements.

The dancers traditionally wear costumes that are predominantly bright red, with touches of yellow, green, white and black, from the baal or loincloth and bidang or woven piece of cloth draped across the shoulders for the men, to the tapis or woven wrap-around skirt worn by the women. Both men and women accessorize heavily with headbands, bracelets, and necklaces made of multi-colored beads.  Written by Sarah Lumba, with notes from Rosalie S. Matilac

 

See also

Kayaw

 

Sources

Alejandro, Reynaldo Gamboa and Santos-Gana, Amanda. 2002.Sayaw: Philippine Dances. Edited byRamon Obusan. Manila: National Bookstore and Anvil Publishing, Inc.

Pangsiw, Frederick U. Kalinga elder and culture bearer. 2016. Interview by Rosalie S. Matilac. Video and transcript, October, Tabuk City.

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
The Ifugao dance called bangibang only requires two pieces of stick, each one around a foot long and an inch wide. A participant needs only to strike these sticks against each other for every beat of a 2/4 measure. This action already serves as both accompaniment and the arm-and-hand movement for the dance. The footwork, which is skipping with the occasional half or full turns, is easy even for a child to follow.

The bangibang is sometimes danced to drive away agricultural pests. But it is more often identified as a funeral dance. Originally, participants of this ritual procession were all male, with the male relatives of the deceased leading them. All wear a crown of kungkung, “a headdress made of dry betel nut bark decorated with the dungla [or dongle plant], a red hibiscus flower” (Taguba and Andin 1994, 47), a symbol of war for the Ifugao. Only a wanoh or loincloth covers their bodies.

 

As they dance in one- or two-line formation, some of them, according to Alejandro and Santos-Gana (2002, 77) “brandish spears and shields while others beat rhythmically on wooden sticks.” Some are tasked to transport the corpse on a sangadil or wooden bamboo chair up to the house of the murdered person while intermittent shouts of “Ha-ha-gui-yoo!” are heard, urging the corpse to take revenge. The Hudhud—a narrative about the origin of the Ifugao, their customs, traditions, and their heroes’ adventures—is sometimes sung during the funeral before the deceased is buried in a sitting position inside burial tombs.

In the 21st century, the bangibang is performed even when there is no death in the tribe. Like other rituals of the Ifugao, it has been showcased in cultural shows both local and international. Women have also been able to join the dance.  Written by Sarah Lumba

 

See also

Indigenous Traditions and Transformations in Philippine Dance

Ritual Dancing

Bati, a sacred flag dance during the Easter Sunday salubong, Angono, Rizal, 2016

(LotusBlaze Projects and Lara Villaruz)

text:
Bati/sayaw na bati (dance of greeting) is a flag dance performed in Angono, Rizal as part of the religious rituals before and during the salubong which is the dramatized meeting of the Virgin Mary and the resurrected Christ on Easter Sunday. This annual dance has two main performers: the tenyenta (female lieutenant) and the kapitana (female captain). The dancing is deceptively simple but quite backbreaking if done without proper physical preparation. Bati dancers have a year to prepare for the religious event since the succeeding tenyenta and kapitana are chosen by lottery on the incumbent Easter Sunday.

The kapitana and the tenyenta are not just trained to dance the bati and to recite the poem that goes with the ritual. They participate in the town’s religious practices and initiate activities to uplift the morale of the community. They adhere to a code of conduct and are not allowed to marry or get pregnant during their official duty. Violations could mean being relieved of their valued positions. Moreover, the kapitana and the tenyenta must understand the sacredness of the flag. They must securely hold it throughout the procession and the performance. There is a folk belief that if the flag of the kapitana or the tenyenta falls on the ground, it may bring bad luck to the community in the form of fire, drought, floods, and other calamities.

 

The kapitana and the tenyenta are usually non-dancers who gain mastery of the dance during the intensive daily practice starting in Jan until before Holy Week. The choreography is said to have been created by Tandang Apang Gil, the teacher of the first known kapitana named Dominga “Ingga” Reyes in 1870. Other teachers who transmitted the dance were Candida Ner, aka “Ti Canding,” and the siblings, Primitivo and Marta Vitor. The choreography consists of seven figures with distinct footwork, body movement, and gestures. Because the dance is regarded as sacred, the choreography is forbidden to be taught to anyone but the chosen kapitana and tenyenta.

The tenyenta and kapitana dance the bati during the panaog, a ritual performed on the evenings of Palm Sunday, Holy Wednesday, and Good Friday. But the most elaborate activities happen in early Easter Sunday during the salubong. Two processions come from separate locations. The first one originates from the church and carries the image of the Risen Christ, accompanied by the parish priest, kapitana, tenyenta, and council women. The second procession starts in a place called Poblacion Itaas and parades the images of Mary Mother of Jesus, Mary Magdalene, Mary Salome, Saint Veronica, and Saint John. The two processions meet and converge at the galilea, a huge four-post structure made of bamboo with a wooden stage under it. The galilea is decorated with ornaments like flags, flowers, and coconut palm leaves. Above the stage hangs a curious construction shaped like a banana heart that represents heaven.

The flag amplifies the graceful movements of the kapitana and the tenyenta. This prop is about 1 x 1.5 ft, inscribed with the word “Alleluia.” Band music is used as accompaniment, such as those composed by Juan Petiza and Lucio San Pedro. As the band plays for the tenyenta, usually San Pedro’s “Gavotte,” the dancer starts the slow bending of the torso sideways from the waist. The bent torso leads the turning of the dancer either to the left or to the right, as if the whole body itself is a waving flag. When the tenyenta’s dance ends, the kapitana recites a 20-minute dicho or poem of 31 stanzas. The dicho’s rendition is accompanied with hand and arm gestures along with standing and kneeling stances, narrating the travails and triumphs of Mary in connection with her son’s death and resurrection.

...Hesus, mapalad na Birhen

Masintahing Ina, Amang mahabagin

Ituro ang landas naming tatahakin,

Dito sa sangmundong batbat ng hilahil...

 

(...Jesus, fortunate Virgin

Loving Mother, merciful Father

Lead us to the proper path

In this world full of sorrows...)

 

Itong aming bayang busog sa dalita,

Isilong sa yabong ng saganang awa,

Upang kung sapitin guhit ng tadhana,

Makasamang lahat sa bayang payapa.

 

(This country filled with destitution,

Shelter it under your bountiful mercy,

So that when we reach the destined life,

We will join everyone in the peaceful land.)

 

Sa akay ng lugod, tunay na pag-asa,

Itong aking taglay, hawak na bandera,

Iwawagayway ko’t bilang pagsasaya,

Wika’y Resurrecit [sic] Alleluia, Alleluia.

Viva!

 

(Guided by joy and true hope,

this flag in my possession,

I wave to rejoice and

to exclaim He has risen, Alleluia, Alleluia.

Long live!)

When the kapitana recites the words about the resurrection, five birds fashioned from paper and bamboo swoop down to the banana heart structure to unfasten and open its petals. The heart opens and reveals an angel, who now slowly descends with the joyful singing of “Regina Coeli.” The angel, played by a child, takes off the black veil that covers the image of the Virgin Mary to signify the end to her sorrow because Christ has risen. The kapitana then concludes her dicho with a joyful and energetic “Alleluia, Viva!” or “Viva Resurreccion!” The people applaud and caged doves are released with a burst of confetti. The kapitana then performs her flag dance with lively band music chosen by the kapitana’s clan, such as the “Balse” composed by San Pedro. The kapitana’s accompaniment is lively in contrast to the melancholy rhythm of the tenyenta’s music. While the kapitana sways, the birds above also move in rhythm. Meanwhile, men who carry the religious images move the statues to the beat of the kapitana’s dancing. People show appreciation for the kapitana’s performance by throwing coins on the stage.

The tenyenta’s and the kapitana’s dances are similar in movements and postures. The marked difference is in arm and hand gestures, mood, and pacing since the tenyenta’s performance mourns Jesus’s death while the kapitana’s dance celebrates Christ’s resurrection. The two bati versions are characterized by the bali or kiling—the steep and sinuous bending of the torso from the waist on either side towards the back, rotating the whole body in an engaging swirl.

Both dances have seven figures according to seven combinations of footwork, each part ending with a turn. In the tenyenta’s variant, the dancer holds the flag’s base with the right hand at waist level and positions the flag’s staff obliquely to the right across the chest and right arm, which allows the banner’s fly to drape over the arm. The left hand rests either at the side or back of the waist, palms outward. These hand positions are maintained all throughout the dancing, except during the final bow. In the first figure, the dancer bends the torso sideward perpendicular from the upright position, continuing the movement by slowly turning clockwise in half or full pivot. The same is repeated in counter-clockwise direction. In the second figure, the dancer bends sideward left and maintains this body posture as she steps sideward left. Then she bends almost 180 degrees to the right and rotates clockwise. The whole sequence is then done in reverse, after which the dancer repeats the first figure in accordance with the melody of the band music. Since the hand and arm positions are set, the dancer may decide whether she wants to do a half, a full, or a double full turn. As the music ends with a flourish, the tenyenta waves the flag across to the left side of the body and in front with outstretched arms. Then she executes a full double turn clockwise, circling the flag in a spiral movement from chest level to overhead position and back to chest level. In another clockwise turn, the dancer sways the flag at the back and transfers it to the left hand, signaling her turn to the left in counter-clockwise motion. While doing this rotation, she transfers the flag to the opposite hand and turns to face the audience with a low curtsy in kneeling position, arms stretched out at shoulder level, and flag extending from the right hand.

The kapitana’s version of the flag dance uses hand and arm motions coordinated with the flag’s swaying as she turns to either right or left direction. The signature posture is maintained in which the dancer is perpetually doing the bali or kiling. When the band music begins, the dancer bends sideward right to the lowest level, turns clockwise with outstretched arms, and presents the flag with the right hand. After this elaborate full turn, which may well be a double turn depending on the skill of the dancer, she may wave the flag behind and in front, while the left hand either sways or rests on the waist. Another combination consists of waving both arms in a figure of eight, in which limbs intersect in a cross-arm position in front of the body. The flag may be transferred from left to right while arms are crossed. Then this movement may be followed by a spiraling action of the banner over the dancer’s head while turning in a bowed posture. Next, she holds the flag’s staff parallel to the floor at chest level, turning in this position with left hand on the waist. Or, she may also hold the flag’s staff on both ends parallel to floor at chest level while swaying the torso sinuously from side to side. She proceeds to circle the banner once or twice overhead, its fly barely touching her hair. The kapitana ends with a curtsy similar to the tenyenta’s dance. The beauty of the kapitana’s dancing is when the flag becomes an extension of the dancer’s hand, which allows effortless swaying and transference of the flag from one hand to the other. It is important to look at the flag as it moves so that the head and neck are coordinated in the swirl. This technique adds fluidity and helps the dancer to gracefully sway and bend.

The test of a good bati dancer is in her ability to bend lower and slower, seamlessly turning and never staying in a straight vertical posture. The exaggerated bending of the torso in a wavelike motion makes this dance unique. This is made possible with simple footwork that deftly transfers weight on to either the right or left foot, whichever is needed to allow the smooth pivot. At some point, the dancer may also use waltzing steps, depending on the music.

In the past, the dancers wore the traditional baro’t saya. In the 2000s, the bati has become a spectacle with elaborate costume and stage design. The kapitana and tenyenta don ornate ball gowns with butterfly sleeves to approximate the look of the terno. The terno’s articulated skirt layered with petticoats underneath is meant to exaggerate the swirling movements. The color of the flag is the same as the color of the gown. However, the ball gown’s enormous skirt may encumber the dancer.

The bati is a thriving dance tradition in the first class-municipality of Angono, known as the Art Capital of the Philippines. To maintain this distinction, the preservation and sustainable innovation of traditional rituals such as the bati is important. A factor in sustainability is the awareness of local citizens about the importance and relevance of their cultural heritage. The tenyenta, kapitana, and their entourage are all young women who strive to learn the traditions and rituals for self-development and for community service. Objectionable revisions in the tradition are avoided with the drafting of the document titled “Panuntunan ng Samahan ng Kapitana at Tenyenta” (Guidelines of the Organization of the Kapitana and Tenyenta) in 2015. Moreover, the fact that Angono’s band music is alive helps to ensure that the dance will be preserved for posterity.  Written by Rosalie S. Matilac

Dito sa sangmundong batbat ng hilahil...

 

(...Jesus, fortunate Virgin

Loving Mother, merciful Father

Lead us to the proper path

In this world full of sorrows...)

 

Itong aming bayang busog sa dalita,

Isilong sa yabong ng saganang awa,

Upang kung sapitin guhit ng tadhana,

Makasamang lahat sa bayang payapa.

 

(This country filled with destitution,

Shelter it under your bountiful mercy,

So that when we reach the destined life,

We will join everyone in the peaceful land.)

 

Sa akay ng lugod, tunay na pag-asa,

Itong aking taglay, hawak na bandera,

Iwawagayway ko’t bilang pagsasaya,

Wika’y Resurrecit [sic] Alleluia, Alleluia.

Viva!

 

(Guided by joy and true hope,

this flag in my possession,

I wave to rejoice and

to exclaim He has risen, Alleluia, Alleluia.

Long live!)

When the kapitana recites the words about the resurrection, five birds fashioned from paper and bamboo swoop down to the banana heart structure to unfasten and open its petals. The heart opens and reveals an angel, who now slowly descends with the joyful singing of “Regina Coeli.” The angel, played by a child, takes off the black veil that covers the image of the Virgin Mary to signify the end to her sorrow because Christ has risen. The kapitana then concludes her dicho with a joyful and energetic “Alleluia, Viva!” or “Viva Resurreccion!” The people applaud and caged doves are released with a burst of confetti. The kapitana then performs her flag dance with lively band music chosen by the kapitana’s clan, such as the “Balse” composed by San Pedro. The kapitana’s accompaniment is lively in contrast to the melancholy rhythm of the tenyenta’s music. While the kapitana sways, the birds above also move in rhythm. Meanwhile, men who carry the religious images move the statues to the beat of the kapitana’s dancing. People show appreciation for the kapitana’s performance by throwing coins on the stage.

The tenyenta’s and the kapitana’s dances are similar in movements and postures. The marked difference is in arm and hand gestures, mood, and pacing since the tenyenta’s performance mourns Jesus’s death while the kapitana’s dance celebrates Christ’s resurrection. The two bati versions are characterized by the bali or kiling—the steep and sinuous bending of the torso from the waist on either side towards the back, rotating the whole body in an engaging swirl.

Both dances have seven figures according to seven combinations of footwork, each part ending with a turn. In the tenyenta’s variant, the dancer holds the flag’s base with the right hand at waist level and positions the flag’s staff obliquely to the right across the chest and right arm, which allows the banner’s fly to drape over the arm. The left hand rests either at the side or back of the waist, palms outward. These hand positions are maintained all throughout the dancing, except during the final bow. In the first figure, the dancer bends the torso sideward perpendicular from the upright position, continuing the movement by slowly turning clockwise in half or full pivot. The same is repeated in counter-clockwise direction. In the second figure, the dancer bends sideward left and maintains this body posture as she steps sideward left. Then she bends almost 180 degrees to the right and rotates clockwise. The whole sequence is then done in reverse, after which the dancer repeats the first figure in accordance with the melody of the band music. Since the hand and arm positions are set, the dancer may decide whether she wants to do a half, a full, or a double full turn. As the music ends with a flourish, the tenyenta waves the flag across to the left side of the body and in front with outstretched arms. Then she executes a full double turn clockwise, circling the flag in a spiral movement from chest level to overhead position and back to chest level. In another clockwise turn, the dancer sways the flag at the back and transfers it to the left hand, signaling her turn to the left in counter-clockwise motion. While doing this rotation, she transfers the flag to the opposite hand and turns to face the audience with a low curtsy in kneeling position, arms stretched out at shoulder level, and flag extending from the right hand.

The kapitana’s version of the flag dance uses hand and arm motions coordinated with the flag’s swaying as she turns to either right or left direction. The signature posture is maintained in which the dancer is perpetually doing the bali or kiling. When the band music begins, the dancer bends sideward right to the lowest level, turns clockwise with outstretched arms, and presents the flag with the right hand. After this elaborate full turn, which may well be a double turn depending on the skill of the dancer, she may wave the flag behind and in front, while the left hand either sways or rests on the waist. Another combination consists of waving both arms in a figure of eight, in which limbs intersect in a cross-arm position in front of the body. The flag may be transferred from left to right while arms are crossed. Then this movement may be followed by a spiraling action of the banner over the dancer’s head while turning in a bowed posture. Next, she holds the flag’s staff parallel to the floor at chest level, turning in this position with left hand on the waist. Or, she may also hold the flag’s staff on both ends parallel to floor at chest level while swaying the torso sinuously from side to side. She proceeds to circle the banner once or twice overhead, its fly barely touching her hair. The kapitana ends with a curtsy similar to the tenyenta’s dance. The beauty of the kapitana’s dancing is when the flag becomes an extension of the dancer’s hand, which allows effortless swaying and transference of the flag from one hand to the other. It is important to look at the flag as it moves so that the head and neck are coordinated in the swirl. This technique adds fluidity and helps the dancer to gracefully sway and bend.

The test of a good bati dancer is in her ability to bend lower and slower, seamlessly turning and never staying in a straight vertical posture. The exaggerated bending of the torso in a wavelike motion makes this dance unique. This is made possible with simple footwork that deftly transfers weight on to either the right or left foot, whichever is needed to allow the smooth pivot. At some point, the dancer may also use waltzing steps, depending on the music.

In the past, the dancers wore the traditional baro’t saya. In the 2000s, the bati has become a spectacle with elaborate costume and stage design. The kapitana and tenyenta don ornate ball gowns with butterfly sleeves to approximate the look of the terno. The terno’s articulated skirt layered with petticoats underneath is meant to exaggerate the swirling movements. The color of the flag is the same as the color of the gown. However, the ball gown’s enormous skirt may encumber the dancer.

The bati is a thriving dance tradition in the first class-municipality of Angono, known as the Art Capital of the Philippines. To maintain this distinction, the preservation and sustainable innovation of traditional rituals such as the bati is important. A factor in sustainability is the awareness of local citizens about the importance and relevance of their cultural heritage. The tenyenta, kapitana, and their entourage are all young women who strive to learn the traditions and rituals for self-development and for community service. Objectionable revisions in the tradition are avoided with the drafting of the document titled “Panuntunan ng Samahan ng Kapitana at Tenyenta” (Guidelines of the Organization of the Kapitana and Tenyenta) in 2015. Moreover, the fact that Angono’s band music is alive helps to ensure that the dance will be preserved for posterity.

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Bendiyan (also bindian, bendean, and benedjan) in the Ibaloy dialect means, “Let us see who gets tired.” The term used is quite apt, for bendiyan is a “fatigue dance.” Its nonstop footwork alone—the stamping of the left foot followed by a quick partial backward swing of the right—is a test of a dancer’s endurance.

The Ibaloy is the indigenous group that inhabits the southernmost part of Cordillera Central. Traditionally, the bendiyan, which originated in Kabayan, Benguet, was a victory dance celebrating a successful headhunt or the tribe’s triumph over their enemies. Nowadays, this dance is performed to celebrate a bountiful harvest or to honor Kabunian, the supreme being of the Ibaloy. It is also showcased during cultural shows.

 

 

The arm movements of the dance remind one of war-like stances. The salawasao, for instance, has “both arms raised above the head like curved carabao horns, palms facing each other…arms [swaying], fingers [flipping]…every count” (Taguba and Andin 1994, 25) and becomes a kind of posturing that declares how brave the warriors of the tribe are. The kinkiyan is a movement that is supposed to challenge the enemy as the “right hand [is] tucked to chest level, left hand [is] extended forward, fingers [are] stretched, palms [are] facing [up].” The inushongan, on the other hand, has “both arms raised above the head level, a little forward, fingers pointing downward…fingers [flipping]…in every count” to signify protection from the enemy, while the pinadjosan has “both arms at the back closed to sides like wings, fingers stretched, palms facing upward” to mimic how warriors transport the spoils of war back to their own community (Taguba and Andin 1994, 25).

Bendiyan is a mass dance—everyone present could participate. But it is the mambunong or native priestess who leads it. At the start of the dance, the mambunong invokes all the spirits of the earth, sky, and underworld to provide her with the names of courageous headhunters, after which the oro-ols (young men with crowns of woven bamboo embellished with rooster feathers) dance the tchunga, another name for bendiyan, around the pig being sacrificed.

A line of dancers, both male and female, enters and forms an inner and an outer circle moving counter to each other. At any moment during the dance, amidst the beating of drums and gongs, these dancers triumphantly cry out “Oowa-ay…Oowa-ay,” which means “Long Live” or “Mabuhay.” A leadman calls out each step to be performed, much like a line dance leader would.

The dancers wear traditional Benguet costumes when dancing the bendiyan. The men have a cloth wrapped around their heads called the pangjet (also shinget and binatjek). To cover their bodies, wealthy men wear a kulibao (also kulebaw) or white blanket with dark blue border lines over each shoulder, and wrap an akuval or cloth around two-and-a-half meters long around their waist to cover their loins. Meanwhile, the women wear a kambal or blouse, together with the aten (also debit, divet, divit, and tapis) or wrap-around skirt.  Written by Sarah Lumba

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Binabayani is a war dance performed only by male dancers among the Aeta of Zambales. In the past, the dance was performed by an Aeta group when there were imminent threats from enemies. Binabayani was an ingenious way to select the best fighters among them in case the group needed to go into battle. Those who won over opponents in this war dance were considered to be competent combatants.

The male dancers are clad in a lubay, or red loin cloth, tied around the waist or hip. The ends of the cloth hang loosely from one side. An instrumentalist deftly plays the local guitar called givaran bakil, carved from local wood, with rhythmic beat of one and two to a measure.

The footwork has four variations. The first movement consists of small step hops: step right or step left and hop on the same foot while raising the other foot behind. This footwork is done in any direction with two-step hops to one measure. The second movement requires the dancer to hop with the right foot as the left foot taps forward. He may use only the heel or ball of the foot to hop, walk, or run. The third movement simply requires the dancer to execute small steps toward any direction. The fourth movement consists of two chasing steps to one measure: step left foot forward, sideward, or backward; then step the right foot behind close to left foot. The movement is then done in reverse order.

In one version, this martial dance pits two contending male groups armed with a bolo and a circular shield. The dance ends when the two groups, at the height of intense fighting, exchange their bolos for the spear.

 

The binabayani may also be performed by two opponents armed with bows and arrows. The dueling warriors enter the space as soon as the guitarist starts strumming. Opponents sometimes beat their bow with an arrow like a percussive instrument as they appraise each other while moving to their fighting positions. Inside the combat arena, they rhythmically move in circular or oval formations through the step-and-hop footwork. They may advance and retreat but the circular formation is maintained as they continue to circle in clockwise or counter-clockwise direction. At one instance, a fighter may try to shoot and then change his mind, perhaps because he lost the precise position to execute a shot. The martial dance requires stamina and skill in order to sustain nonstop and frenetic footwork for the duration of the dance, which may be from 5 to 15 minutes. The best dancers step and hop continuously with lightness and agility, but at the point of perfect timing and position, they release the arrow to vanquish the opponent.

Binabayani is one of the Aeta dances showcased in the tourism packages of the Subic Bay Freeport Zone. The show is a dance demonstration of less than three minutes, featuring two Aeta mimetic dances and the binabayani as the climax. Performers are young male dancers, a guitarist, and a tour guide who annotates the dances. The binabayani versions presented in these shows are terse and bland compared to the traditional style.  Written by Rosalie S. Matilac

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
The binanog is an imitative and courtship dance from the Bukidnon of Central Panay, straddling the provinces of Iloilo and Capiz. It mimics the banog or hawk, also thought of as eagle, and called “bird of birds.” It is one of several and similar hawk dances in the country, which include the Blaan banog-banog, the Higaonon binaylan, and the Mandaya kinabua. The performance of Panay’s binanog closely involves dancers and musicians as they jive together in sunu (or fitting in) or hampang (playing together). The audience uses hiyaw or tata to express approval, saying “Herli, herli, herlikita” (i.e., us). Both dancers and musicians must achieve sibod (matching sound and steps together).

 

The basic instruments that provide musical accompaniment are the agung (brass gong), tambur (drum), and kahuy (sticks). They compose a barasalun ensemble. Other occasions may have the subing (mouth harp), litgit (chordophone), suganggang (bamboo buzzer) and tikumbu (zither). A complete performance includes the playing of a bamboo flute and the kubing (native lute), said to be the favorite of epic heroes Labaw Donggon and Humadapnon. The boses (music and movement) are cued by mnemonics or patterns of sound, or by a chant. Sangkap or costuming requires embroidered (panubok) shirt, pants, and head-kerchief for men, and a blouse, patadyong (skirt), and tapis (overskirt) for women. Women also wear a takurong (veil) topped by a pudong or forehead band with coins, which is matched by her binigkit or necklace with coins and a round bell or silver bao-bao (turtle-like) pendant.

Roles are defined in dahunga where a man and a woman dance together, and tinagbak where only a woman dances. The dance figures progress from walking the bayhunan or lisyun-lisyun, to repasu that improvises with kaykay and isduyung steps, sadsad in a variety of accented steps, simbalud with dramatic arm movements, and the pinanyo. The last is like a game, with the woman trying to hook a man within her shawl or panyo. Prominent movements are the arm movements in simbalud and the use of a shawl to catch a man in pinanyo, both suggesting the flying hawk.

The binanog is danced on a tambi or balcony of a house with bamboo floor. Today it is also done in an open shed, sometimes with an amakan (spliced bamboos woven together) floor which allows more flexibility in performance because it has more room for hampang. Choreographers Angela Betina Carlos and Japeth Mari Cabling used and transformed the idiom of the binanog in a full-length ballet version called Nasalapu-an (Birthing) for UP Dance Company in 2013. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz
