description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
There are many Philippine dances portraying different kinds of native birds, from eagle to sparrow, in different narratives representing courtship, battle, or love, among others. They are usually performed during various tribal gatherings, such as celebrating a wedding, a new tribal pact, or thanksgiving for a good harvest.

In the highlands of the Cordillera Range, the dances of different ethnic groups typify the iconography of birds. Even as they dance with their feet close to the ground, the Cordillera dancers spread out their arms, move their feathered heads, and flourish blankets to imitate swirling or soaring birds. Most of the bird dances of the Cordillera depict courtship. Among the Ifugao, the talip portrays both the swooping of a high-flying bird and a man pursuing an evasive woman. The same is seen in the uya-oy, with a couple’s hands flapping up and down like wings. In Benguet, the tarektek imitates the movement of woodpeckers. A man shows off his agility by flaunting a prized blanket or by gong-playing (the gangsa) to attract a woman. Again with wing-like blankets, the Bontok’s ballatan has a rooster swooping toward a hen that eludes him with her kalahig or scratching steps—until she gives in. A blanket is also a ready prop in Apayao’s pingpingan, depicting a swallow in pursuit of his pair. For the Kalinga, the salip is the most noted courtship dance and has a rooster displaying his blanket-wings as he encircles a hen. Even in their head-hunting dance kayaw, the Kalinga run, hop, and leap like birds, using their spears and shields as wings.

 

In Cagayan, the Ibanag imitate the small klingkingan birds living in caves, after which the dance klingkingan is named. To evoke the sounds that the birds make when flying, the dancers click Spanish or bamboo castanets. In Ilocos, to portray courtship, the Ilocano kalapati has two doves billing and cooing as a pair. With hands on waist, the dancers flap their elbows and peck at each other’s faces over each other’s shoulders. Similarly, the galyo in Pangasinan is another courtship dance, with a rooster in a barong chasing a hen in a baro and serpentina saya (skirt with train). At some point they subtly touch each other’s elbows. Tayabas has pabo that mimics the strut of a turkey. Interestingly, it is portrayed by an odd person in a circle. The dancer tries to get a partner, and when successful, another person becomes the pabo. In Sorsogon, a pantomina mayor imitates the flirtation of rooster and hen as danced by a newly wedded couple. In the Visayan kuracha, a couple dressed in a barong and a balintawak teasingly steps out like chickens or doves. The dance links them to nearby Samar’s own kuracha and salampati. In the latter, a pair also portrays doves in courtship, looking back at each other while turning. Meanwhile, in Negros Occidental, the sinalampati portrays a mother dove tending to her chicks. Elbows, hands, and fingers are fluttered like wings.

In Masbate, on the shore of Bantigue, people portray the lapay or seagulls by steeply leaning back as they slide-glide forward. In imitation of the hawk, the Bukidnon of Panay dance the binanog with the same leaning profile. Here the woman brandishes a shawl, with which she tries to hook the man. In Capiz, the tinolabong depicts the heron with its statuesque neck and legs. Like most realistic delineations in the lowlands, the dancer’s articulated elbows depict wings, while hands represent beaks.

Deemed a Visayan dance, the itik-itik, or duck’s dance, was supposedly first seen by Francisca Reyes-Aquino in Surigao. Agile singer-dancers improvised movements with “short, choppy steps” and pretended to “splash water over their backs while calling to their mates” (Reyes-Aquino 1953, 28). New research discovered another version in Sibunga, Cebu. Called itik-itik sibunga, it has the waddle and wiggle of the first itik-itik, but with different ways of moving arms and executing hops and foot-brushes. Leyte is famous for tinikling. An early version, tinikling ha bayo, employs a pair of pestles to mark the rhythm. However, the modern tinikling has two bamboo poles struck in a jota rhythm. A couple imitates the rice-eating tikling birds, hopping in and out of the bamboo trap. Today, tinikling has become a signature Filipino dance. The tempo has accelerated while various complex formations have been devised to show off the dancers’ virtuosity and build up the dance to a rousing climax.

Some dances in Mindanao do not always literally imitate birds, but the surrounding aviary life that must have inspired their costuming, adornments, and movements. In the Subanon soten in Zamboanga, warriors frenetically move around while shaking ornate shields and palm leaves to make a boisterous sound. Similarly, in the Maranao and Maguindanao ritual dance called sagayan, warriors clash and leap about with wing-like scimitars and shields, wearing helmets topped by peacock-like plumes. Done before a combat, the dance is meant to bring the warriors to a trance or spiritual flight. Meanwhile, young Bagobo exuberantly run and leap about with their wing-like shields in the gin-um, as part of the water-cleansing pamalugo ritual as they portray eagles flying against the wind. On the other hand, hawks are imitated in the kinabua of the Mandaya, the man-manaok of the Manobo, and the banog-banog of the Blaan and Higaonon. In the last, a baylan (shaman) portrays a hen protecting her chicks against a hawk that is finally killed by hunters.

Again, costuming amplifies the look of birds among the Tboli and Blaan dances. Kadal tahaw imitates a variety of birds in the Tboli landscape. Dancers hang the malong (multicolored tubular skirt) from their shoulders, thrust their hands into the malong, and move these continuously in a number-eight pattern to create the illusion of flapping wings, as they execute step-and-hop movements, turns, and runs. They also create pleasing sounds with brass bells dangling from their girdles and brass singkil anklets. They depict the story of how a food-hunting bird injures its leg but still attempts to fly—indicated by the swooping movements of the malong, the flipping of wrists, and the dragging of one foot. Similarly requiring elaborate adornments, the Blaan kadal kafi in Lanao, Cotabato, and Saranggani imitates the crawl, strut, turn, and leap of the kafi bird, all executed with up-and-down movements of elbows and wrists.

In Sulu and Tawi-Tawi, there are pangalay variants that imitate bird movements. The linggisan inscribes a woman’s flowing postures and movements similar to a bird in flight. On the other hand, a man enacts a rooster in the pangasik with its mincing steps, shrugging shoulders, swaying arms, and cupped hands.

These examples of regional dances represent different modes and degrees of choreographic abstraction of bird movements, performed in response to various social functions, and even the demands of combat. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Bodabil dance is the type of dancing in the variety show called bodabil, consisting mainly of popular and theatrical dances from the United States, but later including Philippine folk dances and choreographies among its production numbers. Bodabil comes from the French voix de ville (street songs), or chansons de vaux de vire (topical or satirical drinking songs from Normandy), the latter supposedly created by a 15th-century literary society led by Oliver Bosselin. In the late 17th century, Nicolas Boileau (aka Despreaux) applied the term to some ballads. In the 18th century, it became a theatrical term for performers of mime, song, and dance. It has also been called “variety entertainment” in the United States. In the Philippines, the show called vod-a-vil later became bodabil. During the Japanese occupation, bodabil with a melodrama was called stage show.

The vaudeville act is part of “low comedy” that requires “precision, polish, timing, and many techniques, such as juggling, mime, ballad singing, dancing and acrobatics,” and offers “a satirical view of the life of the times in popular language, gesture and movement” (Palmer 1978, 12). During the American colonial period from 1901 to 1946, vaudeville invaded the Philippines, and ultimately ousted the local musical or sarsuwela. In the United States, it became current mainly through the Pastor family, especially through Tony Pastor, the “father of American vaudeville.” In the Philippines, John C. Cowper, who came with Harry Brown, was considered the “dean of Philippine vaudeville.” The new form was first seen in sarsuwela theaters such as the Teatro Zorrilla and Teatro Paz, and novelty houses such as the Savoy Nifties (later Clover), the Rivoli (later Tivoli), and Sirena (later Lux). Then, cinema theaters housed the bodabil with its full extravaganza alongside the regular feature films. During the Japanese occupation, bodabil became the venue for the expression of Filipino sentiments, even as the Japanese banned American songs and dances. Incorporating the melodrama as its main attraction, bodabil became known as the stage show. Among the first dancers to perform in Manila bodabil at the turn of the century were Spanish dancers like Anita, Emilia, Teresa, Planella, Malfrosa Juan Panadei, Francisca Nabao (famous for her “flea dance”), the Agita Sisters (“a clever Spanish trio”), and the Frezagonda Sisters. They performed alongside American minstrels and clog, buck-and-wing, and skirt dancers. Billed as “the world’s greatest dancer” was Ada Delroy who played She in The Fire of Life, and was one of hundreds who were influenced by the pyrotechnical lights-and-skirt dancing of the legendary Louie Fuller, a contemporary of Isadora Duncan. Emily Lucifer, a popular child dancer, staged several benefits before she finally left the country.

 

A number of groups in the international vaudeville circuit performed in the Philippines: the Lilliputians in 1901 with their “ballet girls;” the Japanese Infantile company with its “Japanese ballet;” the Baroufski Imperial Russian Circus in 1902; the Denishawn Company of Ruth St Denis and Ted Shawn in 1926; Alicia Markova and Anton Dolin and Far Eastern Entertainment with its “Fil-American Variety Show” in 1948; Katherine Dunham’s company in 1957; and the Spanish maestro Luisillo in 1962.

In the 1930s and 1940s, the most notable of visiting artists were Richard and Raymond Reynolds who were billed as Brothers and who taught their Filipino counterparts the tap dance and charleston; Helen and Lucy Martin; Anita Fiori from Budapest; and Jose Zarah, who stayed on after his troupe left. A Portuguese, Zarah spent World War II as a member of Lou Salvador Sr’s Merrymakers at the Dalisay, Strand, and Palace. After the war, he performed at the Clover which, with the Opera House, was the foremost bodabil theater. His local partner for Spanish dance was the famous Bebe Marcaida. Charito “Chuchi” Hernandez became a noted choreographer at the Clover, especially between 1953 and 1963. She had risen from chorus girl to performer of character and national dances, jazz, and tap. Filipino bodabil artists soon came into their own, especially after jazz pianist Lou Borromeo returned from the United States. In the early years of this century, Sunday Reantaso founded the first Philippine Vaudeville Company. In the shows, Katy de la Cruz became the “queen of jazz” and the “Carmen Miranda of the Philippines,” and Atang de la Rama the “queen of the kundiman.” Early bodabil stars include the Garcia sisters, Flo and Modesta, who were trained by tap and jazz dancer Buster Dunson. As a trio, they were “the three-cornered combination [that was] the best dancing act Manila ever had.” There were also Pacita and Esthering, and Vitang Escobar. Carmen “Miami” Salvador was famous for her “hula wiggle” and for being a member of the Salvador family, his brother Lou Sr being the “master showman” of the day. An early observer wrote: “There is a dainty nymph-like grace and beauty about those tiny Malay figures possessed by no other race in the world. They are quick to learn their routine, and are natural dancers” (Maynard 1929, 306-7). Noted choreographers who started in bodabil were Bobby Salvador, Jake Jacinto, Nieves Manuel, Bayani Casimiro, Jamin Alcoriza, and Al Quinn. Dancers Lucio Sandoval and Shirley Santos staged their own dances in the 1950s when Conching Rosal sang with Bert Alpuerto at the Opera House. Other noted dancers were Paquito Bolero and Angelita “Rhumba” Rey; the Rusca Brothers called “tap dancing wizards;” Dandy, the “tap dancing expert” who became the comedian Casmot; Millie Sparks, later called Lopita; Rosa Aguirre and Metring David. Chichay and Patsy both started as chorus girls. Chiquito and Dolphy were remarkable dancers, too. Casimiro and Nieves Manuel had a famous partnership and were billed the “Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers of the Philippines.” Casimiro’s comedy team with Jose Cris Soto made them the “Laurel and Hardy of the Philippines.” Later dance stars were Ramon Zamora and Jun Aristorenas who later became action stars, Shirley Santos, Marie Cui, Arturo Zamora, and Dinky de la Cruz, who were mostly members of Alcoriza and Quinn’s Modernaires. Bodabil was at its height at the time of the cakewalk, one-step, fox-trot, tango, charleston, and big apple, as well as the Latin rhumba, samba, and curracha of the 1940s, the conga, pachanga, apalachicola, calypso, and charranga, and the post-World War II mambo, bossa nova, and cha-cha. Philippine folk dances were also performed by Lucio Sandoval and Patria Panajon or Aida Gonzales, or arranged by Paz Cielo Angeles-Belmonte. The era also witnessed the popularity of tap, soft-shoe, can-can, apache, and adagio dancing. Bodabil or stage show began to decline in the 1950s, when theaters like the Inday and Art featured burlesque dancing in haba-haba shows, an unsavory term for bodabil. Among the burlesque dancers were Virgie Night, Betty Co, Nina White, Jenny Moh, and Carlotta. In the 1970s, burlesque dancing drew male audiences to the Dragon and Playboy theaters. From the 1960s on, television threatened the stage show and even the movie theaters. Attempts in the 1960s to revive legitimate bodabil on stage came to naught despite the efforts of choreographer Corazon Generoso-Iñigo. Her father, Jose Generoso, was a noted producer-director for the bodabil. The stage show continued to be popular as entertainment in provincial fiestas and was resurrected in the variety shows on television or radio, which absorbed many of the old bodabil artists. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

A number of groups in the international vaudeville circuit performed in the Philippines: the Lilliputians in 1901 with their “ballet girls;” the Japanese Infantile company with its “Japanese ballet;” the Baroufski Imperial Russian Circus in 1902; the Denishawn Company of Ruth St Denis and Ted Shawn in 1926; Alicia Markova and Anton Dolin and Far Eastern Entertainment with its “Fil-American Variety Show” in 1948; Katherine Dunham’s company in 1957; and the Spanish maestro Luisillo in 1962.

In the 1930s and 1940s, the most notable of visiting artists were Richard and Raymond Reynolds who were billed as Brothers and who taught their Filipino counterparts the tap dance and charleston; Helen and Lucy Martin; Anita Fiori from Budapest; and Jose Zarah, who stayed on after his troupe left. A Portuguese, Zarah spent World War II as a member of Lou Salvador Sr’s Merrymakers at the Dalisay, Strand, and Palace. After the war, he performed at the Clover which, with the Opera House, was the foremost bodabil theater. His local partner for Spanish dance was the famous Bebe Marcaida. Charito “Chuchi” Hernandez became a noted choreographer at the Clover, especially between 1953 and 1963. She had risen from chorus girl to performer of character and national dances, jazz, and tap. Filipino bodabil artists soon came into their own, especially after jazz pianist Lou Borromeo returned from the United States. In the early years of this century, Sunday Reantaso founded the first Philippine Vaudeville Company. In the shows, Katy de la Cruz became the “queen of jazz” and the “Carmen Miranda of the Philippines,” and Atang de la Rama the “queen of the kundiman.” Early bodabil stars include the Garcia sisters, Flo and Modesta, who were trained by tap and jazz dancer Buster Dunson. As a trio, they were “the three-cornered combination [that was] the best dancing act Manila ever had.” There were also Pacita and Esthering, and Vitang Escobar. Carmen “Miami” Salvador was famous for her “hula wiggle” and for being a member of the Salvador family, his brother Lou Sr being the “master showman” of the day. An early observer wrote: “There is a dainty nymph-like grace and beauty about those tiny Malay figures possessed by no other race in the world. They are quick to learn their routine, and are natural dancers” (Maynard 1929, 306-7). Noted choreographers who started in bodabil were Bobby Salvador, Jake Jacinto, Nieves Manuel, Bayani Casimiro, Jamin Alcoriza, and Al Quinn. Dancers Lucio Sandoval and Shirley Santos staged their own dances in the 1950s when Conching Rosal sang with Bert Alpuerto at the Opera House. Other noted dancers were Paquito Bolero and Angelita “Rhumba” Rey; the Rusca Brothers called “tap dancing wizards;” Dandy, the “tap dancing expert” who became the comedian Casmot; Millie Sparks, later called Lopita; Rosa Aguirre and Metring David. Chichay and Patsy both started as chorus girls. Chiquito and Dolphy were remarkable dancers, too. Casimiro and Nieves Manuel had a famous partnership and were billed the “Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers of the Philippines.” Casimiro’s comedy team with Jose Cris Soto made them the “Laurel and Hardy of the Philippines.” Later dance stars were Ramon Zamora and Jun Aristorenas who later became action stars, Shirley Santos, Marie Cui, Arturo Zamora, and Dinky de la Cruz, who were mostly members of Alcoriza and Quinn’s Modernaires. Bodabil was at its height at the time of the cakewalk, one-step, fox-trot, tango, charleston, and big apple, as well as the Latin rhumba, samba, and curracha of the 1940s, the conga, pachanga, apalachicola, calypso, and charranga, and the post-World War II mambo, bossa nova, and cha-cha. Philippine folk dances were also performed by Lucio Sandoval and Patria Panajon or Aida Gonzales, or arranged by Paz Cielo Angeles-Belmonte. The era also witnessed the popularity of tap, soft-shoe, can-can, apache, and adagio dancing. Bodabil or stage show began to decline in the 1950s, when theaters like the Inday and Art featured burlesque dancing in haba-haba shows, an unsavory term for bodabil. Among the burlesque dancers were Virgie Night, Betty Co, Nina White, Jenny Moh, and Carlotta. In the 1970s, burlesque dancing drew male audiences to the Dragon and Playboy theaters. From the 1960s on, television threatened the stage show and even the movie theaters. Attempts in the 1960s to revive legitimate bodabil on stage came to naught despite the efforts of choreographer Corazon Generoso-Iñigo. Her father, Jose Generoso, was a noted producer-director for the bodabil. The stage show continued to be popular as entertainment in provincial fiestas and was resurrected in the variety shows on television or radio, which absorbed many of the old bodabil artists.

text:
The buklog is considered the most important ritual dance of the Subanon of Zamboanga. The dance addresses the kanagkilawan (pantheon), which include the ginoo (gods), mitibug (spirits), and getautelunan (demons). According to the timuay or spiritual leader (now called datu) Agdina Bacong Andus, the Subanon hold the buklog for communal and personal reasons: to heal the sick through panaad (vow), to be rid of gangan or dimalas (ill fortune), to ask for blessings, and to release the dead so that they may float up to langit (sky) to join magbabaya or ginoo. The latter is in imitation of the Subanon hero Sandayo who, in the epic Keg Sumba neg Sandayo (The Tale of Sandayo), rose to heaven with his people.

 

 

Before the buklog, the following rituals are performed: the dulang to ask for permission to cut the trees, the gampang to provide offerings, and the gatud to drive away evil spirits. The buklog stage is built just for this special occasion. Rising high in the middle of the field, the stage has posts of timber on which a bamboo floor is attached above the ground. Under the center of this bamboo floor is a log pestle (pathaw) which moves vertically up and down as the Subanon dance on the bamboo floor, making booming sounds as it pounds on a horizontal log below called duluyan, under which are buried large empty earthen jars. In former times, this stage was built only for a day, but today this could remain standing for days, to be used for the buklog and other events.

The Subanon dance on the elevated floor, join hands in a circle, and weave criss-crossing steps as they move counter-clockwise across the stage. No musical instruments are played, so the only sounds heard are those of the bouncing floor, the pounding of the pestle over the mortar below, and the sounds of the celebrants’ merrymaking and communal prayers to the gods. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

text:
Cheerdance is an energetic and highly athletic form of dance characterized by sharp and snappy movements combined with tumbling and aerial stunts. It is a relatively new dance form popularized in the Philippines by the University Athletic Association of the Philippines (UAAP) cheerdance competition in the mid-1990s. With more than 22,000 spectators watching the event in 2014, the UAAP cheerdance competition is considered one of the most anticipated sports events in the country.

Cheerdance in the country can trace its roots to the American sport of cheerleading, an aesthetic sport which includes elements of dance, gymnastics, cheer, group stunts, and pyramids. It started as an all-male sideline event with the purpose of boosting school spirit among spectators and their respective teams. It was introduced to the Philippines through the American educational institutions in the early 1940s. Similar to a cheerleading routine, each cheerdance piece is short and lasts for about 2:15 to 2:30 minutes only. Compulsory elements include double pirouettes, high kicks, front or side splits, jumps, and leaps, performed by all team members either in unison or in succession. In both jumps and leaps, all team members must show the same routine during execution. Pompoms must also be used continuously by all participants for at least one third of the routine time. In the cheerdance category, cheers, chants, stunts, tumbling, pyramids, and acrobatics are prohibited.

 

Cheerdance, as popularized by the UAAP, however, has evolved into a form of its own. While the Filipino form of cheerdance still includes all the elements of American cheerleading, it is also thematic and longer in routine. Performance can be as short as five minutes to as long as 20 minutes. Props, which are usually prohibited by international standards, may be incorporated into the routine. For example, umbrellas, toy swords, and jump ropes have been used in the UAAP competition. Folk dance steps have also been incorporated in some routines.

In the mid-1990s, teams started to explore the use of space, creative movements, props, and themes. Costumes also moved away from the traditional skirt and jersey in order to complement the theme of the routines. School teams which had gymnastics programs or resources to hire international cheerleading coaches were able to execute standard cheer stunts and pyramids while other teams resorted to creativity in showing the required elements. Two UAAP teams with strong dance backgrounds, the University of the Philippines Varsity Pep Squad (UP Pep Squad) and the University of Santo Tomas Salinggawi Dance Troupe (UST Salinggawi), dominated the competition until the mid-2000s.

Although the Cheerleading Philippines Federation or Cheerleading Philippines, the government-recognized national organization of cheerleading in the country, was established in the early 1990s, the training of local coaches in safe and proper stunts and pyramid techniques was scarce until the National Cheerleading Championships Incorporated (NCC) was formed in 2004. The success of NCC’s summer camps facilitated by American cheerleaders resulted in a renewed drive in the programs of Cheerleading Philippines. The organization became more aggressive in promoting cheerleading and its various categories, including cheerdance, in the country. As a result, a number of Filipino coaches received international training and now hold international coaching and judging certifications.

In the 2014 UAAP competition, each five minute long routine required cheer, stunts, tosses, pyramids, tumbling, and dance. Judging is divided into two parts: cheerleading and dance (overall effect including energy and dynamism, costume, and music), choreography (creativity and musicality, difficulty, format, and transitions), technique (execution of style and clarity of movement, placement, control, extension, and strength of movement), and group execution (synchronization and spacing). Traditional cheer moves characterized by sharp and powerful arm movements are essential components. Street dance techniques like locks and pops are also used. Other dance forms include folk dance such as malong dance by the University of the East (UE) in 2014 and the sakuting by UP in 2001; martial arts like capoeira by UP in 2006 and tai chi by the Far Eastern University (FEU) in 2014; sports exemplified by synchronized swimming by UP in 2001, boxing by De La Salle University (DLSU) in 2013, and aerobics by UP and FEU in early 2000. Cheerdance groups utilized various props like hoops and jump ropes by UP in 2002; flags and ribbons by UST and fans and umbrellas by UE, both in 2014.

Cheerleading competitions have also become popular outside of Metro Manila. However, as many cheerleading coaches are untrained, stunts, tosses, and pyramids are usually restricted or totally eliminated from the criteria. At present, there are four major cheerleading competitions in the Philippines. These are the UAAP Cheer Dance Competition, the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) Cheer Dance Competition, the NCC, and the Philippine National Games (PNG). The UAAP and NCAA competitions are partially accredited by NCC, while PNG is certified by Cheerleading Philippines. The NCC judges the technical aspects of the routine, which include difficulty and execution of tumbling, jumps, stunts, pyramids, and tosses. The UAAP competition committee also invites dance experts to judge the dance and artistic quality of each routine.

While the NCC and PNG follow international rules and regulations for cheerleading, the UAAP and NCAA competitions have two criteria or components: dance and cheerleading. These two serve as blueprint for understanding cheerdance in the Philippines, which has evolved into something more dramatic with the adoption of themes and social advocacy. For instance, in 2014 the UP Pep Squad broke tradition by delivering the message of equality. In a typical cheerleading performance, male cheerleaders act as bases and provide solid foundation for stunts and pyramids, and they lift or toss their female teammates up in the air. This somehow reinforces public perception that men are heavier and stronger while women are lighter and more flexible. The UP Pep Squad challenged this notion and advanced its advocacy by performing stunts and pyramids with female cheerleaders acting as bases and male cheerleaders as flyers. The cheer lyrics further emphasized the message of the routine. UP’s performance stimulated discussion on social media for weeks even if the group failed to win the championship title. Written by Jonathan Y. Cagas

text:
A courtship dance is a ceremonial dance in which the male pursues a female who may accept or reject the male’s attention. Courtship dances are usually performed during special occasions. Wedding dances are performed by newlyweds to formalize before the community members the new relationships that have been forged by the couple, their families, and relatives.

There are hundreds of courtship dances in the Philippines. The very young can begin with game dances, such as the Tausug-Sama igal ha panyuh. European-inspired social dances, such as the indigenized minute alcamfor from Leyte and the habasinan in Pangasinan, can also be vehicles for courtship. The exhibitionistic kuratsa in Ilocos, Bicol, and the Visayas can start with playful male-female contests and end in mutual understanding. Even a combat dance among the Tiruray which is done at weddings, the dance rivalry over a widow among the Talaingod, and the rivalry over a man among the Matigsalug, are dances of courtship.

 

The apas-apas (going after) at a belasyon (novena at a wake) in Antique is a courtship dance, as are the Tagalog and Visayan varieties of the balitaw that feature a song and dance debate between males and females. The Samar ismayling (from English, smiling) and the sampaguita from Cebu are similar to the balitaw. The cariñosa features the devious yet obvious devices of a fan and a handkerchief for a play of hide-and-seek in many of its figures. These devices are also used in the pag-aring in Samar. A pair of earrings is used in the putrillo of Leyte, a Chinese saucer in the pinggan-pinggan of Bohol, and the sampaguita in the an marol of Samar. The like (coquetry) in Negros and Antique may go beyond the man’s pleading to the woman’s lifting of her skirt. The man may play-act, looking dejected with an elbow on a knee and propping up his drooped head on a spurned hand as in the maramyon in Leyte, and the voluntario in Iloilo and Antique which is about guerrillas during the Spanish colonial era, or the lingawen in Samar, which is similarly about a subversive who goes off to the mountains. The man may pretend to be dying in the Abra biniganbigat. Instead of the usual pair, two girls and a boy perform the Cebuano la berde, a courtship and wedding dance. A woman may “resist” by putting up her palms, shading her face, or by mimicking a clam in the gumanhap of Cebu. She may play hele-hele (coy), as in a dance so named or in the saguin-saguin of Albay. Another Visayan courtship dance is the miligoy performed by a couple, usually at weddings, baptisms, and fiestas. The man may brag about his strength with “seven spears and eight bolos” in the inday na kunday in Leyte, to which the woman replies that only God is really powerful. On the other hand, a woman may be so distraught over a man’s relentless pursuit as to stab herself in the punyal ni Rosa (Rosa’s dagger) in Laguna. Love can be sad, as in the Ilocano sileleddaang with its figure called patay (with one dancer despairing, the other comforting), which is also found in the ti liday and purpuri of Tarlac. In the Capiz sa-ad, the hapless Indo serves Aning and her family for a long time, only to find out that she has eloped with someone else. The objects of courtship in the lulay of Laguna, the manang biday of Ilocos (both with singing), the rogelia of La Union, and the pastora of Pangasinan are quite obvious. Less precise are the costurera (seamstress) of Iloilo, the virgoire (virgin air) of Antique, the kumakaret (wine or vinegar maker) of Pangasinan, the ilocana a nasudi (the lovely Ilocana) of Ilocos Norte, the timawa (free person) of Capiz, the libon boli (beautiful lady) of Cotabato, and the magkatipan (sweethearts) and the sayaw sa pag-ibig (dance of love) among the Tagalog. The metaphors are obvious in the ohoy, alibangbang (hey, butterfly) of Capiz, and the mariposa of Pangasinan, where boys pretend to be butterflies to the girls’ flowers, or flirtatious doves in the palomita coquitana of Capiz and the salampati of Samar.

In the Sulu Archipelago, there are many courtship dances, like the dalling-dalling, the sua-sua, and the gandingan. In one variant, relatives, friends, and guests place coins in a container as an offering to the new couple. In another regional variant, the bride and groom themselves dance on a mat spread out on the floor while guests throw money onto the mat. After the dance, the mat is rolled up and the money gathered and given to the couple. At the bride’s house, there is more dancing; in Panasahan, Malolos, this dance is called sayaw panasahan. The sabalan lulay in Oriental Mindoro features a long wedding ritual in four parts: the sabalan, the pamalaye, the sabog, and dapit. The verse for the Ibanag dance wawway (Cagayan) is both assiduous and whimsical: “I brought a handkerchief / as soft as a new leaf / to wipe only the perspiration / especially the face of my inspiration / Aye, aye, you’re perspiring / come hither, I do the wiping / lest ‘twill be dried by the wind / you’ll get sick and lose your whim.”

The Ifugao imitate hawks in the wedding feast called uyauy, as do the Manobo in the binanog, where two women try to attract one man. The Tboli imitate the birds by manipulating a malong (tubular skirt) or a shawl, while a man dances with a haglong (a boatlike guitar). description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Cultural dance is a term that loosely describes the type of dancing performed in restaurants, bars, cruise ships, tourist sites, and tourist events in the Philippines and abroad. The dancing includes Philippine folk dances, jazz folk, current popular dances, and novelty dances.

The earliest example of cultural dancing was performed by members of the Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company in the early 1960s. Acquiring recognition from their debut at the Brussels Universal Exposition in Belgium in 1958, the Bayanihan performances were viewed by international tourism organizers as emblematic of Oriental culture and the group was tapped as exotic cultural performers for the Century 21 Exposition aka Seattle World’s Fair, an enormous six-month event in 1962 that sold more than 10 million tickets to tourists from all over the world.

Las Vegas City in Nevada, USA, which became popular as a gambling and entertainment capital, popularized the type of cultural dancing that capitalized on exoticism and sex. Steve Parker, better known as the former husband of Shirley MacLaine, produced the long-running Philippine Festival at the Dunes in Las Vegas in 1961. The show was promoted as an exotic treat featuring “75 Ravishing Island Queens!” Among those who were recruited by Parker to perform in Las Vegas were dancers from the Bayanihan, namely, Rose Borromeo and Alice Reyes, the latter proclaimed National Artist in dance in 2014. What became popular in the mid-1960s was the type of cultural dancing that consisted of folkloric exhibitions of traditional Philippine dances combined with modern, glitzy cultural shows patterned after the Las Vegas productions. In 1964, the Bayanihan was in the forefront of such performances in Australia.

 

 

In the late 1970s, cultural performances proliferated in restaurants and tourist sites in Manila. An example of a dance group involved in this type of cultural dancing is the Folklorico Filipino Dance Company with members coming from the Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company and the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group (ROFG). The group performed in reputable restaurants, international cruise ships, and tourism events with a repertoire consisting of dances and choreography similar to those of the Bayanihan and the ROFG.

For over two decades, from the 1980s to the early 2000s, hundreds of thousands of Filipino entertainers, majority of them women, worked abroad as entertainers, either as singers or cultural dancers in Japan or in other Asian nations, as well as Middle Eastern and European countries. As most performers had little training and experience in dance, the term “cultural dancer” was often placed in quotation marks.

Japan was the most common destination of Filipino cultural dancers. The overseas departures for Japan started in the late 1970s. This was also a time when Japan experienced continuous economic growth, resulting in the demand for cultural dancers, vocalists, and hostesses in Japan night clubs and hotels. By the mid-1990s, the number of entertainers in Japan was estimated at 80,000. The relatively large incomes of cultural dancers must often be shared with promoters, who have invested in studios, dormitories, or job placement agencies. Many dancers were exploited by recruiters, who sometimes exported them illegally. Once abroad, many performers discovered that they must render “extra-cultural” or hostessing services while assigned to hotels and clubs, which ranged from the grand to the dingy. Most male dancers ended up as waiters. The export of cultural dancers declined in 1995-96 due to the imposition of new regulations by the Philippine Overseas Employment Administration (POEA) of the Department of Labor and Employment. Previously, POEA regulations only had an audition system of the most elementary kind in order to qualify as a dancer, singer, musician, and specialty performer (magician or other variety entertainers), who were then certified with a numbered card.

The Technical Education and Skills Development Authority or TESDA elicited the help of professional dancers and dance educators to elevate the dance qualification of aspirants. This included basic ballet dancing skills and increase in the age limit of applicants to 23 years old, later reduced to 21 years old. In 2004, the US State Department’s report on human trafficking categorized Japan and the Philippines under countries that failed to stop or prevent human trafficking. The report put pressure on the Japanese government to impose stricter measures against the entry of foreign entertainers, thus ending the exodus of Filipino overseas cultural dancers to Japan.

In 2001, a Korean business group ventured into producing the Amazing Show in Manila and Cebu. The show employed beautiful transgender and gay performers who were considered among the most in-demand cultural dancers for their talent, versatility, and flamboyance. By 2011, the Amazing Show had been seen by over 350,000 people, making it perhaps the Philippines’ most watched performance event. The show continues to draw foreign and local audiences due to its spectacular production numbers that include ethnic dances from the Cordillera and Southern Philippines, traditional Chinese and Korean dances, Korean pop song and dance numbers, and excerpts from Hollywood movies like Dreamgirls and Broadway musicals like Cabaret and Fame.

In the 2010s, the move to make tourism a leading industry has stimulated the development of cultural dancing not only in Manila but in other tourist destinations like Boracay, Cebu, Bohol, and Davao. These cultural-variety shows are organized in hotels, restaurants, events places, and tourist sites and provide jobs for performers, technical staff, and promoters. Dancers may or may not have substantial dance training and experience. Examples of restaurants and sites that promote touristic cultural dancing are the Jungle Restaurant in Mactan, Cebu; the Bohol Cultural Park in Dauis, Bohol; Fridays Resort in Boracay; and the Tribu K’Mindanawan cultural village in Davao City. The dance selection may include Philippine folk and ethnic dance suites, pop dances, sexy but wholesome dances, and novelty numbers like fire dancing. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, updated by Rosalie S. Matilac

For over two decades, from the 1980s to the early 2000s, hundreds of thousands of Filipino entertainers, majority of them women, worked abroad as entertainers, either as singers or cultural dancers in Japan or in other Asian nations, as well as Middle Eastern and European countries. As most performers had little training and experience in dance, the term “cultural dancer” was often placed in quotation marks.

Japan was the most common destination of Filipino cultural dancers. The overseas departures for Japan started in the late 1970s. This was also a time when Japan experienced continuous economic growth, resulting in the demand for cultural dancers, vocalists, and hostesses in Japan night clubs and hotels. By the mid-1990s, the number of entertainers in Japan was estimated at 80,000. The relatively large incomes of cultural dancers must often be shared with promoters, who have invested in studios, dormitories, or job placement agencies. Many dancers were exploited by recruiters, who sometimes exported them illegally. Once abroad, many performers discovered that they must render “extra-cultural” or hostessing services while assigned to hotels and clubs, which ranged from the grand to the dingy. Most male dancers ended up as waiters. The export of cultural dancers declined in 1995-96 due to the imposition of new regulations by the Philippine Overseas Employment Administration (POEA) of the Department of Labor and Employment. Previously, POEA regulations only had an audition system of the most elementary kind in order to qualify as a dancer, singer, musician, and specialty performer (magician or other variety entertainers), who were then certified with a numbered card.

The Technical Education and Skills Development Authority or TESDA elicited the help of professional dancers and dance educators to elevate the dance qualification of aspirants. This included basic ballet dancing skills and increase in the age limit of applicants to 23 years old, later reduced to 21 years old. In 2004, the US State Department’s report on human trafficking categorized Japan and the Philippines under countries that failed to stop or prevent human trafficking. The report put pressure on the Japanese government to impose stricter measures against the entry of foreign entertainers, thus ending the exodus of Filipino overseas cultural dancers to Japan.

In 2001, a Korean business group ventured into producing the Amazing Show in Manila and Cebu. The show employed beautiful transgender and gay performers who were considered among the most in-demand cultural dancers for their talent, versatility, and flamboyance. By 2011, the Amazing Show had been seen by over 350,000 people, making it perhaps the Philippines’ most watched performance event. The show continues to draw foreign and local audiences due to its spectacular production numbers that include ethnic dances from the Cordillera and Southern Philippines, traditional Chinese and Korean dances, Korean pop song and dance numbers, and excerpts from Hollywood movies like Dreamgirls and Broadway musicals like Cabaret and Fame.

In the 2010s, the move to make tourism a leading industry has stimulated the development of cultural dancing not only in Manila but in other tourist destinations like Boracay, Cebu, Bohol, and Davao. These cultural-variety shows are organized in hotels, restaurants, events places, and tourist sites and provide jobs for performers, technical staff, and promoters. Dancers may or may not have substantial dance training and experience. Examples of restaurants and sites that promote touristic cultural dancing are the Jungle Restaurant in Mactan, Cebu; the Bohol Cultural Park in Dauis, Bohol; Fridays Resort in Boracay; and the Tribu K’Mindanawan cultural village in Davao City. The dance selection may include Philippine folk and ethnic dance suites, pop dances, sexy but wholesome dances, and novelty numbers like fire dancing.

text:
Dancesport combines dance as an artistic expression, as a social activity and as an athletic feat. It is performed by partners, a woman and a man, who compete against other couples on the same dance floor all at the same time. In the past, it was called “competitive ballroom dancing” but the name was changed to dancesport with the increased emphasis on athleticism. Dancesport demands strength, endurance, agility, coordination, teamwork, grace, musicality, artistic interpretation, and choreographic skill. The International Olympic Committee recognizes it as a sport, which may be included in the Olympics.

As a competition, dancesport organizations have their own parameters in costume or dress code, age restriction, and judging requisites. Generally, couples perform five Latin and five standard/international dances. Each dance is executed according to a strict tempo and music, which become the basis for judging the technique and quality of movement. The five Latin dances are samba, cha-cha, rhumba, paso doble, and jive. The five standard dances are waltz, tango, Viennese waltz, slow foxtrot, and quickstep.

 

The international category requires specific costumes: an aristocratic formal suit for the male, along with a short and clean haircut. The female wears a flowing gown that accentuates the feminine form, with colorful accents like floats, feathers, drapes, and boas to get the judges’ attention. Hair is done in a dramatic but sophisticated style. For the Latin category, the male dancer usually wears a loose top opened to the navel, along with tight-fitting trousers that cling to the body. The female dancer usually wears a short, sensual, and tight-fitting dress, or a glamorized version of what women wear in Havana or Rio. In hairstyle, the Latin category allows the male to sport facial hair as well as long tresses which nevertheless must have masculine appeal. Meanwhile, women can wear short hair or ponytails. In both categories, the costumes must enhance the masculine and feminine characteristics of the partners.

Dancesport in the Philippines began in 1996 when the Blackpool modern standard champion, Paul Bishop, linked the Philippine Sports Commission to the World Dance and Dancesport Council—one of the world’s leading organizations in dancesport. Interested in participating in the World Ballroom Championship and in the Olympics, the commission sought the assistance of socialite and lambada dancer Becky Garcia. She subsequently became the first president of the Dancesport Council of the Philippines, Inc (DSCPI), a position she still holds as of this writing. DSCPI held the first dance congress at the Ninoy Aquino Stadium in 1997 to introduce the competitive style of ballroom dancing. In the same year, two couples represented the Philippines in the international competition in Bangkok. In succeeding years, the country won international awards: Michael Mendoza won Dancesport in the South East Asian Games. Alberto Dimarucut and Deborah Civardi were the first Filipino professionals to represent the country in Blackpool, England in 2000. Edna Ledesma, who was partnered by John Co in the Latin senior division, became the first Filipina to win a gold medal in the prestigious Blackpool Competition in 2005.

Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo signed Proclamation 203, declaring Nov 4 to 10 as National Dancesport Week in 2002. Today, dancesport competitions have become widespread in schools and universities all around the Philippines. An indication of the popularity of dancesport is its inclusion as a sport event in the competitions held by sports associations like the State Colleges and Universities Athletic Association, the Private Schools Athletic Association, and the Association of Local Colleges and Universities. Wheelchair dancing is an evolution of dancesport, introduced in 2013 at the DSCPI National Championship. This was initiated by Genice “Bong” Marquez in collaboration with the Tahanang Walang Hagdanan in order to give persons with disabilities an opportunity to discover and showcase their talents.

Practitioners in the field are aggressive in training teachers and coaches. The establishment of professional dancesport organizations like the Philippine Dance Teacher Association, the Philippine Dance Sport Association of the Philippines, and the DSCPI-Professional Division allowed professional dancers to help in the growth of the industry through conferences, seminars, and workshops. Since the entry of dancesport in the Philippines, Filipinos have excelled in the field, winning gold and silver medals in the 2005 Southeast Asian Games, bronze medals in the 2010 Asian Games, gold and bronze medals in the 2013 Asian Indoor and Martial Arts Game, and silver medal in the Asian Paralympic Games 2014 Wheelchair Dancesport. Written by Alberto L. Dimarucut and Rosalie S. Matilac

 

Source

Picart, Caroline Joan S. 2006. From Ballroom to DanceSport: Aesthetics, Athleticsand Body Culture. New York: SUNY Press.

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Dinuy-a is both a ceremonial and a festival dance. It is an integral part of Ifugao rituals such as weddings, births, funerals, and burials. It is also performed during planting and harvesting seasons, either as supplication or thanksgiving for a bountiful harvest. Beyond these ceremonies, dinuy-a is performed during cultural shows and other festivities that are open to the general public.

This dance originated from Lagawe, but it now has different versions even in the nearby areas such as in Kiangan, Hingyon, Banawe, and Hungduan. Dinuy-a depends on one lead gong and five gong beaters to produce the syncopated rhythm characteristic of Cordillera music. The gangsa or gongs used are a combination of the tobob or ten-inch brass gong beaten with open palms and various hibat or gongs whose sounds are produced by beating their inner surface with a stick.

 

 

Footwork is quite simple: usually a step-close or step-hop with a slight bounce on the knees. There are occasional pivots. Once in a while, too, the dancers do the dalikdik or mincing steps. The arm and hand movements are stiff. The payadon, for example, has the left arm extended in front while the right is bent, and the right hand is at waist level with palm facing up, being flicked from the wrist at every count. The wekwek has the palms facing up, with both arms bent close to one’s sides and flapped like a bird’s wings according to the beat. The stiffness is intentional as it signifies confidence and firmness in one’s convictions. Meanwhile, the open palms signify the renunciation of evil spirits, and when done with arms overhead, become an expression of thanksgiving to Kabunian, the Ifugao’s supreme deity.

Female dancers, who are usually in a balko or blouse and an ampuyo/tapis or wrap-around skirt, have slower, smaller movements than their male counterparts—a symbol of their submissiveness. Male dancers, usually in wanoh or loincloths, make more pronounced, almost jerky gestures and footwork to signify their sense of superiority over women. The occasional tilting of the upper body of both male and female dancers evokes a closeness to the earth. Written by Sarah Lumba

 

See also

Indigenous Traditions and Transformations in Philippine Dance

Ritual Dancing

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
The diyandi is a traditional dance performed in Iligan City, Lanao del Norte during the feast of the city’s patron saint, San Miguel or Saint Michael, every 29 Sep. It is a religious ritual, performed only by women, as a halad/panaad (prayer-offering) to Archangel Michael, who is revered by the Maranao who regard him as a heavenly being in the Koran, and by the Iliganon who look up to him both as an angel and a warrior capable of defending them and their city. The dance is symbolic of the historical relations of the three dominant groups in the region—the indigenous Higaonon, the Muslim Maranao, and the Christian settlers—as it assimilates Higaonon and Maranao dances, songs, and verses in a Christian ritual.

During the Spanish colonization, Mindanao was one of the most difficult frontiers to penetrate due to strong native and Moro resistance. It was only during the mid-19th century that Spanish presence came to be felt. Eventually, it led to the Christianization of some native inhabitants and the influx of non-indigenous and non-Moro settlers to the area. This displaced the indigenous and Islamic groups, many of whom moved to the hinterlands. One of the ways by which the colonizers then tried to win over the locals was by throwing colorful fiestas that attracted the curiosity of the natives. Part of these fiestas was the diyandi, meaning “to celebrate.”

 

 

Traditionally, the diyandi was known as the dance of the youth, performed only by children ages 6-12. It was performed by 12 dancers divided into two groups: six wearing traditional female Higaonon garb, and six wearing traditional male Maranao garb. Then as now, the dancers are also called diyandi. The eldest in the group leads the performance and is called the kapitana. The youngest in the group, called anac-anac (child), bears food offerings of piyak (chick), orak (egg), cagcawa (ginger), and lasona (garlic). The Higaonon costume consists of a knee-length skirt called saya ha pinanguntingan, a blouse that comes down to the midriff called pinagsoy ha sinulawan, a comb called panika worn in the hair, necklaces, bracelets, and other ornaments worn around the feet and ankles. The Maranao costume is made up of a pair of loose pants, a loose waist-length blouse with long sleeves, and a tubao (kerchief) wrapped around the head. They bear ritual offerings in a pouch attached to a sash slung around their torso. All dancers carry a tubao with varying designs in their hands. Two lead dancers, one for the Higaonon and one for the Maranao, called pangabaga (right hand), help the kapitana lead everyone through the dance. The entire performance is danced barefoot.

The beginning of the Feast of Señor San Miguel is marked by the pagkanaug, or the bringing down of San Miguel’s image from its pedestal at the center of the cathedral altar. It is cleaned and dressed, complete with its kalo (helmet), taming or kalasag (shield), and bangkaw (spear) with a banner attached to it. As the image is prepared, the diyandi dance and sing the gosos (canticles) of Señor San Miguel, along with other devotees.

On the fifth day of the feast, a dance competition called kasadya (merrymaking) is held at the town plaza, featuring Iliganon dances including the sinulog, a dance based on the Filipino martial art eskrima with the performers dressed in Maranao costumes; yawa-yawa, meaning “devil-devil,” a comedia about the life of Señor San Miguel; and the diyandi, the dance of the women and of the youth.

The diyandi is performed in front of the church on the ninth day of novena, typically in the morning. Afterwards, the diyandi dancers move from house to house to partake of food offered by neighbors and local officials. They may also do this to show their gratitude. Again, the diyandi is also danced during the Feast of Nuestra Señora del Rosario on the first week of October.

The sound of the agong marks the beginning of the performance. A specific beat is played as the Higaonon enter in a swaying motion, hands poised on their hips. The Maranao enter in the same style and the hands holding the kerchief move toward the opposite shoulders. Throughout the dance, the hand that is flipped and waved dictates the movement of the feet. Every hand gesture is followed by an intense gaze. Once all the dancers are in position, they raise their hands in unison, kiss the kerchiefs, and bring their hands down.

There are nine identifiable parts in the traditional diyandi. First is the uruyan. The formation breaks into two as the Higaonon circle to the right and the Maranao circle to the left while the kapitana and anac-anac remain in the middle. The two lines eventually draw up alongside the kapitana and anac-anac. Once the two pangabaga reach the middle, the kapitana moves between them and begins to dance with them again. The anac-anac remains at the end of the formation, between the last two Maranao and Higaonon dancers. The second part is the singing of Tominongbong Day Dinhe (Come Down Here), the first song of the diyandi, sung without any musical accompaniment. The third part is the berso, wherein the kapitana leads the diyandi in the recitation of verses. Fourth is the sayaw sa anac-anac (dance of the child). The dancers form a circle with the kapitana sitting in the middle. The anac-anac then dances around her, to the clapping and the rhythm of the agong. From the circular formation, the diyandi break up and flutter around like butterflies for the fifth part of the dance called alibangbang (butterfly). Then they form a line of alternating Higanonon and Maranao dancers for the luhod-luhod (kneeling), the sixth part. The diyandi dance on their knees as they move and flap their hands by their waists. In the next two parts of the dance, gabas-gabas and kinadena, the dancers interpret in movement the formation of a chain that binds them all together as one people. In the final part of the dance, called panyo-panyo, the Higaonon and Maranao dancers meet in the middle and exchange kerchiefs as a symbol of their friendship and acceptance of each other. Other songs sung in the diyandi are Dalagang Day Bukid (The Country Lass) and Ang Iliganon nga Buotan (The Kind Iliganon). After the performance, all the dancers lift their hands and shout, “Viva Señor San Miguel!”

No one knows who first taught the diyandi dance as it has been performed in this format. The earliest documented teacher is Sancha Leonar-Cabillon, who danced as a kapitana alongside Hilaria Zalsos Cambalong, who performed as anac-anac, circa 1915. Both were under the tutelage of Carlos Leonar, known as Tiyo Alo or Mang Alo, who was a cantor in the church.

In 1977, Felicidad Actub, head of Katilingbanong Kapunungang Iliganon, an Iliganon organization, was assigned by then Mayor Camilo Cabili to establish a diyandi dance group. To fulfill the task, Actub traced the verses used in the diyandi to the care of Lydia Madrazo-Seraspe, the daughter of Tomasa Fuego Madrazo, who had learned it from Sancha Leonar-Cabillon. However, the verses Tomasa Fuego Madrazo had collected were incomplete, and so Actub and her group decided to simply divide the recovered verses and appropriate them for later renditions of the dance.

Today, the diyandi is danced not only by the youth. It has been ascribed a more religious rather than festive significance, as halad or panaad to the patron saint. Performances have also become more dominantly Cebuano. Costumes remain patterned after traditional clothes but have been infused with ornaments like sequins and beads. In 2004, the Iligan City Council established the Diyandi Festival through a resolution, turning the fiesta into a month-long tourist attraction. Written by Louise Jashil Sonido

 

Source

Navidad, Estrella. 1995. "Diyandi: Alaala ng Kahapon, Panaad sa Kasalukuyan, at Larawan ng Tunggalian." MA thesis. Quezon CIty: University of the Philippines Diliman.

The formation breaks into two as the Higaonon circle to the right and the Maranao circle to the left while the kapitana and anac-anac remain in the middle. The two lines eventually draw up alongside the kapitana and anac-anac. Once the two pangabaga reach the middle, the kapitana moves between them and begins to dance with them again. The anac-anac remains at the end of the formation, between the last two Maranao and Higaonon dancers. The second part is the singing of Tominongbong Day Dinhe (Come Down Here), the first song of the diyandi, sung without any musical accompaniment. The third part is the berso, wherein the kapitana leads the diyandi in the recitation of verses. Fourth is the sayaw sa anac-anac (dance of the child). The dancers form a circle with the kapitana sitting in the middle. The anac-anac then dances around her, to the clapping and the rhythm of the agong. From the circular formation, the diyandi break up and flutter around like butterflies for the fifth part of the dance called alibangbang (butterfly). Then they form a line of alternating Higanonon and Maranao dancers for the luhod-luhod (kneeling), the sixth part. The diyandi dance on their knees as they move and flap their hands by their waists. In the next two parts of the dance, gabas-gabas and kinadena, the dancers interpret in movement the formation of a chain that binds them all together as one people. In the final part of the dance, called panyo-panyo, the Higaonon and Maranao dancers meet in the middle and exchange kerchiefs as a symbol of their friendship and acceptance of each other. Other songs sung in the diyandi are Dalagang Day Bukid (The Country Lass) and Ang Iliganon nga Buotan (The Kind Iliganon). After the performance, all the dancers lift their hands and shout, “Viva Señor San Miguel!”

No one knows who first taught the diyandi dance as it has been performed in this format. The earliest documented teacher is Sancha Leonar-Cabillon, who danced as a kapitana alongside Hilaria Zalsos Cambalong, who performed as anac-anac, circa 1915. Both were under the tutelage of Carlos Leonar, known as Tiyo Alo or Mang Alo, who was a cantor in the church.

In 1977, Felicidad Actub, head of Katilingbanong Kapunungang Iliganon, an Iliganon organization, was assigned by then Mayor Camilo Cabili to establish a diyandi dance group. To fulfill the task, Actub traced the verses used in the diyandi to the care of Lydia Madrazo-Seraspe, the daughter of Tomasa Fuego Madrazo, who had learned it from Sancha Leonar-Cabillon. However, the verses Tomasa Fuego Madrazo had collected were incomplete, and so Actub and her group decided to simply divide the recovered verses and appropriate them for later renditions of the dance.

Today, the diyandi is danced not only by the youth. It has been ascribed a more religious rather than festive significance, as halad or panaad to the patron saint. Performances have also become more dominantly Cebuano. Costumes remain patterned after traditional clothes but have been infused with ornaments like sequins and beads. In 2004, the Iligan City Council established the Diyandi Festival through a resolution, turning the fiesta into a month-long tourist attraction.

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines

photos.desc:
Bukidnon women performing the dugso, San Fernando, Bukidnon, 2008

(Ceasar Amirhassan Nimor)

text:
Dugso, dugsu or dinugsu is a complex ritual dance performed by women during the kaliga ceremonies of the Bukidnon. The term “Bukidnon” means “mountain dweller” in the Cebuano language. It also refers to the four ethnic sub-groups in Mindanao: the Bukidnon in northeastern Mindanao, the Talaandig in the northwestern part of Bukidnon province, the Higaonon in Misamis Oriental and Agusan del Norte, and the Banwaon in Agusan del Sur.

The kaliga ritual or kaliga-on is composed of elaborate ceremonies that employ prayers, dugso, songs, chants, and music from a dagingen (hanging xylophone) and the agung (gong). The kaliga is performed to communicate with recognized spirits or gods assigned by the supreme being, Magbabaya. These deities are responsible for specific functions like ensuring success in planting, reaping a bountiful harvest, and healing of diseases. The kaliga has a portion where the women perform responsorial songs called tabuk, after which they hold hands in half-circle formation around the bangkasu or altar to dance the dugso. The dancers may also dance around a dapulan or ceremonial fire placed inside a wooden container. Its smoke is believed to carry the mortal entreaties to the gods. Men sometimes join the women in dancing the dugso.

 

 

The solemn dance has no musical accompaniment. Led by a female babaylan or shaman, the dugso has seven figures performed with various foot movements on the ground or on the bamboo floor. The feet stamp, kick, and glide, providing an earthy bass to the curious jangle of the women’s sandak (brass bracelets) and singgil (anklets). The rhythmic sounds are enhanced by the tinkling of saliyaw and lingkit (small bells) which adorn their salay (necklaces) and palakut (belts). Sound from footwork and ornaments has six rhythmic patterns. There are two variants of the dugso known as hinaklaran and lagudas which may be performed with instrumental accompaniment.

The first figure of the dance is called dinatag (introduction) that produces the first rhythmic pattern. With arms in T-position, dancers join hands and move in clockwise and counterclockwise directions: Brush left foot backward, tap left foot close to right, step left sideward, and then repeat. Step right foot behind left foot, tap left foot close to right, step left sideward and repeat. Brush right foot backward, tap right foot close to left, then step right foot sideward. Step left over right, tap right close to left, then step sideward right. Step left behind right, step sideward right, and then repeat. Performers repeat dinatag once more.

The second figure called sinangka creates the second rhythmic pattern as dancers move in counterclockwise direction. Joining hands and with arms in T-position, dancers lean sideward to the right as they raise left foot in front. Then they step left sideward, tap right close to left, step right sideward, and tap left foot close to right. Then they swing hands downward as left foot steps sideward; the right foot closes to left; then dancers step left sideward and raise their right foot as their torsos lean sideward left, swinging arms upward to T-position. The steps are repeated from the start, still moving counterclockwise.

The third figure called sinayaw (dance-like) has yet another rhythmic pattern. Brush left foot backward, tap left foot close to right, and step sideward left; step right behind left, tap left close to right, step sideward left, and repeat the first two footwork patterns; brush right foot backward, tap right foot close to left, then step sideward right; step left foot over right, tap right close to left, step sideward right, and repeat first two footwork patterns; stamp left foot and clap hands while bending torso forward; turn towards left and step left foot forward, tap and step right; then tap and step left, and stamp right foot sideward two times with arms raised in reverse T-position on the second count. Repeat the last pattern to the right starting with right foot. Repeat sinayaw once more.

The fourth figure producing another rhythmic pattern is called inulang (shrimp-like). The women join hands in reverse T-position and do footwork in counterclockwise direction. They start with left foot forward, stamp right close to left foot, then stamp right foot backward, and repeat footwork pattern twice. They stamp left twice and stamp right foot twice. The sequence is repeated three times.

The fifth figure is called linibog (confusion). Dancers start by repeating the first three footwork patterns of dinatag. They proceed to the following footwork which has similar rhythmic pattern as inulang: stamp left over right foot, step right foot behind, stamp left foot obliquely forward, step right foot behind, stamp left once in front and twice sideward. This is repeated from the beginning starting with right foot.

The sixth figure moving counterclockwise is called sangkulolo, which imitates the courtship of a rooster and a hen. This figure has another distinct rhythm produced by the sound of footwork: step left foot forward and step right backward; step left forward, stamp right close to left, and step right sideward; stamp and step left foot, then stamp and step sideward right.

The footwork of the seventh figure called pinispis, or parrot-like behavior, creates the last rhythmic pattern. Women move clockwise, hands connected in reverse T-position, with knees slightly flexed moving in clockwise direction. They brush right foot behind and step left foot in place; brush left foot behind and step left foot in place. They repeat the first pattern. Then they step right behind left foot and step left foot sideward, and repeat counts one and two. They repeat the three footwork patterns thrice.

There are at least 12 identified types of the dugso and the more popular variants are the dugso Songco, dugso Kalasungay, dugso Cabanglasan, dugso Lagoras, inaksyon, and the hinaklaran.

The elaborate costume is one of the main attractions of the dance. Among the Higaonon, the complete attire is called sinuyaman. This is composed of the panaksoy, a colorful blouse with bell-shaped sleeves; the saya, a wrap-around skirt secured by a tapis or overskirt designed like two conjoined bibs placed at the sides; and the sulam-sulang, pananggahan, saloloy or pelupandung, all referring to the headdress, which is symbolic of the mythical papagayok bird. The dugso has been performed in the Kaamulan (gathering for a purpose) festival since its inception in 1974. At the time, traditional Bukidnon dancers were the principal performers in the Kaamulan. Since the 2000s, the festival has become the local government’s most important event for tourism and publicity. Choreographers are hired to stage the dances including dugso, which, by the standards of street dancing for big crowds, is considered repetitious and boring. The traditional dancers among the indigenous peoples are no longer the main actors in the Kaamulan. Young dancers are trained by choreographers. The new version of dugso for street dancing is no longer used for religious purposes. The movements are accompanied by loud cheering and percussion. Footwork and arm movements are accelerated to suit the festive mood. Costumes and props are likewise modified to suit this version. Written by Rosalie S. Matilac

Ritual Dancing

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines

photos.desc:
A version of the escotis, Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company, Manila, ca 1970

(Bayanihan Philippine Dance Company Collection)

text:
The escotis/chotis/schottische is a Filipino term for “Scottish,” a dance whose running steps and hops suggest that it may truly have been Scottish in origin. In the Philippines, the dance and step combination come in varying step patterns. The escotis is a step, close, step, hop; the working foot is placed at the rear with a bent knee (Reyes-Aquino 1966). Another version is a step, close, step, close (Fajardo 1964). The chotis step can be a brush, place, brush, place, and four-step turn (Reyes-Aquino 1966). The schottische step can be a run, run, run, hop (Sison-Friese 1980).

The schottische found easy acceptance as it developed from the eccossaise, a lively dance of the early 1700s. The origin of the eccossaise is likewise controversial, with some authorities pointing to France and others to Scotland. Other scholars insist that it came from the German-Austrian area, and that as early as 1844 in Bavaria, the schottische was performed as the rheinlander and was known as the Bavarian polka. In any case, the schottische was a popular ballroom dance from 1800 to 1850. It may have been taught to Filipinos by Spaniards, visiting Europeans, or returning Filipinos.

The European schottische step is done to 4/4 time with a number of possibilities: a step, close, step, hop; or run, run, run, hop. In the hop, the working foot may be placed by the ankle of the supporting foot, swung diagonally or in front of the supporting foot, to finish by pointing on the floor.

 

 

The most noted escotis in the Philippines is done at all social gatherings in the barrios of Tinpas, Pasitan in Panay, and the mountainous areas of Capiz. During house warmings, the hopping, jumping, and stamping movements of the dance test the structure’s strength and durability. Toward the end, the music is played much faster, eliminating those who are out of breath. At the end, the remaining dancers are asked to whistle as a further test of their endurance and fitness.

The escotis has many variants in the Visayas. One version from Kalibo, Aklan, is a three-figure dance. Another is a six-figure dance, but without any escotis step in its figures. Yet another from Roxas City is a five-figure dance, performed by four couples in various floor patterns.

The chotis of Camarines Sur was as popular as the waltz, polka, and mazurka, and danced in scattered, long, set, or quadrille formation. In Lal-lo, Cagayan, it was a favorite among the elderly Ibanag. In Ilocos Norte, the chotis dingreña has been claimed by the elite. Chotis ilocano and chotis vintarina were performed at many Ilocano gatherings. Today, it is a popular intermission number at social dances. The chotis de negros is performed to complete a social gathering. Written by Corazon Generoso-Iñigo

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Folk dance refers to the dances created and performed collectively by the ordinary people. The term usually includes: so-called “ethnic dances” such as those of the cultural community in the Cordillera, in Mindoro, Palawan, Sulu, and Mindanao; and the rural or lowland Christian dances, among the groups, like the Ilocano, Pangasinan, Tagalog, Kapampangan, Bikol, Cebuano, Ilonggo, and Waray. Folk dances may also be divided into the “regional,” which refers to dances particular to one locale or area; and the “national,” which refers to those performed all over the country. Some regional dances, such as the tinikling of the Waray have become national dances because they are now performed by groups for all regions. A related term is “creative folk dance” which refers to character dances whose choreography uses folk steps and music.

Philippine folk dances are diverse, and include religious, ceremonial, courtship, funeral, combative, exorcism, torture, comic, and game dances. They have been named after saints, heroes, teachers, foreign steps or dances, their countries or places of origin, events, tribes, Philippine steps, a combination of steps, or of steps and places, and a combination of words.

Philippine folk dances—other than religious, ceremonial, and a few social—are performed with attention to detail and after meticulous rehearsals. Social dances, particularly ballroom dances, may be done on special request or at the spur of the moment. Sometimes folk dances serve as a welcome intermission between ballroom dances and are called pasakalye (intermission dances) or amenudo, and are performed by a couple or group.

Filipino ethnic groups still believe in the efficacy of dance as a means of communicating with deity. Christianized Filipinos too dance to plead with, or to thank the Virgin Mary or a patron saint, as in the turumba of Pakil, the subli of Batangas, and the sayaw sa apoy of Cavite. As in Filipino religiosity, the influence of indigenous culture persists, despite colonization.

 

 

Insects, reptiles, fowls, birds, simians, medicinal and fragrant plants, edible shoots, the national flower, bamboo nodes, and the sound of wind as it passes through the leaves have all been accorded recognition in Philippine dance. Activities such as rice production, broom making, gold panning, fishing, tuba (coconut wine) making, gathering of sweet potatoes, clams or honey, fetching of water, pot making, corn planting, and communal work have been reflected in Philippine folk dances.

The dances use movements of the head, waist, arms, feet throwing, circling, swooping, offering, and crowning. Some dances feature flags, beating with sticks, and swaying motions such as those of drunkards. Hand or stage properties are used: fans, earrings, bench, brass trays, chinaware, plates, oil lamps, drinking glasses, food covers, hats, fish containers, pots, leaves, floral arches, coconut shells, wooden implements, chopsticks, and maypoles.

Folk dances are integral to school, community, provincial, regional, and national celebrations. Children in ethnic groups learn their community’s dances informally. Christian Filipinos have been learning their dances in school since 1915, when folk dancing was required as part of physical education at all levels. Teacher and professional training courses prescribe advanced folk dances. The Philippine High School for the Arts, established for the gifted, offers a major in folk dancing.

Research in folk dance was pioneered by Francisca Reyes-Aquino with the support of then University of the Philippines (UP) president Jorge C. Bocobo. This pivotal work was continued by Far Eastern University (FEU), Philippine Normal College (PNC), Philippine Women’s University (PWU) and its regional colleges, Mindanao State University (MSU), University of the East (UE), and the Philippine Folk Dance Society. Libertad V. Fajardo, Lucrecia Reyes-Urtula, Jovita Sison-Friese, Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa, Juan Miel, Teresita Ines-Pascua, Ramon Obusan, Corazon Generoso-Iñigo, Paz Cielo Angeles-Belmonte, Henrietta Hofer-Ele, Jose Balcena, Petronila Suarez, Marcelino Garcia, Dolores Suzara, Cesar Nimor, Wilhelmina Torralba, Mary Jane Cacacho, Elena Rivera Mirano, Abelardo Villavert, and many other regional researchers and teachers have broadened our understanding of the folk dance. Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz started recording dances in the Benesh movement notation, and Larry Gabao in Labanotation.

Masteral degree programs in physical education encourage research on Philippine folk dances. Research materials are available at Centro Escolar University, Divine World University, PNC, PWU, UP, University of San Carlos, and University of Santo Tomas (UST).

Seminars and workshops are conducted yearly by the Philippine Folk Dance Society and the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). To commemorate the Decade of the Child, the Folk Arts Theater and the Bayanihan Alumni separately programmed Indak Pambata, a summer workshop for children. From 1988 to 1991, the UP College of Human Kinetics trained public and private physical education teachers in folk dancing. The National Association of Physical Education and Sports and the Dance Education Association of the Philippines also conduct national summer congresses and workshops. Since 1990, the CCP has held a regional workshop on the production and staging of folk dances. Performers and tours of folk dance companies and consultancies complement the CCP outreach program.

Folk dance contests are conducted in schools, communities, provinces, regions, and nationwide. Field day demonstrations saw mass participation of students from the 1940s to the 1970s. From 1976 to 1986, street performances by dance groups welcomed visiting dignitaries. More recently, they have been greeted by school children performing dance movements rather than full dances.

Five-star hotels feature folk dance evenings. Multinational companies request dance companies to entertain and enlighten their guests. Folk dances have been presented on board tourist ocean liners at sea, or while docked in Manila Bay.
