text:
A game dance is dance performed for play, with rules, and a prescribed style and structure. Game dances are done in informal social gatherings both for fun as well as to test the dancers’ skills.

One popular game dance is the musical icebreaker. In large social gatherings where not all the guests know each other, these dances function as an introduction. In the Tagalog huricuti, a dancer performs with a hat. He goes around the room until he spots a likely partner to whom he offers the hat as an invitation to dance. Girl and boy dance together until they tire, and the process is continued by the second dancer who looks for his new partner. Another Tagalog game dance, pabo (turkey), is similar in theme, but different in formation. A dancer chooses a partner from a circle of dancers surrounding him and simulates the mating ritual of the turkey. In the culebra, the dancers perform informal and unstructured figures, but on a certain musical cue they may change partners and dance with whomever they choose. This goes on indefinitely or until the host decides that the guests are already well acquainted. In the Bicol group dance, lubi-lubi, the dancers may also change partners on musical cue.

 

 

Some game dances, on the other hand, are contests of skill. In the Pangasinan sayaw ed tapew na bangko (dance on top of a bench), the objective is not to fall off the long wooden bench while performing the dance. The pandanggo sa patalong from Laguna tests a dancer’s balance and coordination. The dancer performs on ceramic plates, which must not break, while balancing a glass of wine on the head, clicking castanets in both hands, and singing. The Visayan dagit-dagit (to pluck) starts as a group dance. Dancers deemed mediocre by onlookers are unceremoniously plucked out of the formation until only the best are left.

The igal ha panyuh from Sulu is a chasing game dance where an “it” weaves in and out of a circle formed by seated players carrying a small hand prop, such as a stick or kerchief. At a certain point, the “it” drops his prop next to a seated player who must then chase the “it” to the player’s own position in the circle. If the “it” gets there first, the displaced player becomes the next “it.” The game dance continues in this manner until all the seated players have had the chance to be “it.” Written by David Bercades

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
The habanera is a dance in 2/4 time named after Havana, Cuba. It is believed that the habanera was brought to or invented in Havana by African slaves. It has since become a formal social dance fit for the ballroom or stage.

The Philippine version consists of a languid count “one” where the breath, body, and footwork suspend the initial step, a quickening of the pulse to catch up with the closing step on count “two,” and an assertive step in place for completion on count “and,” a sub-beat after count of “two.”

The habanera found its way to Spain and France in the late 19th century. Immensely popular in Spain, the dance was also immortalized by the French composers George Bizet, Alexis Emmanuel Chabrier, and Maurice Ravel. Some dance historians, however, claim that the origin of the habanera was the Spanish contradanza (square dance) of the 18th century, transformed in Havana and subsequently brought back to Spain.

The habanera has been compared to and is thought by some dance authorities to be the prototype of the tango. The slow, stately dance is accompanied by coplas (verses). Partners face each other and execute expressive gestures with langurous movements of the arms, hip, head, and eyes, which probably hint at the dance’s Moorish and Asian beginnings (Koegler 1977).

 

 

The habanera is found among the dances of the Ilocos, Cagayan, Pangasinan and, occasionally, other regional dances. The kilingkingan from Cagayan is named after a bird whose swift flight produces a sound similar to the clicking of castanets. It is danced to the cinco-cinco, the five-string guitar of Cagayan. The mascota, also from Cagayan, is an impromptu all-occasion dance, and is named after the design and style of a traditional skirt. Pabo (turkey) is a Tagalog game dance where a lone male struts around like an old turkey looking for a partner. Putong (to crown) is a beautiful dance from Marinduque that honors guests during an asalto (surprise party). The guests are serenaded, crowned, and given flowers as they sit between two children who are dressed as angels. Sainita from Nueva Vizcaya underlines the tasks of a good wife. There are also the surtido banna and surtido norte which incorporate the habanera.

A few documented dances are identified as habanera. The habanera of Magsingal, Ilocos Sur highlights the Ilocos kumintang gesture and delineates the modest character of the Ilocana. The lovely and complex habanera Botoleña from Botolan, Zambales was originally performed for a departing parish priest. Today, it is a famous theater piece. The habanera Capizeña is a popular courtship dance requiring graceful arm movements. It is the only habanera that uses a cross-habanera step. The habanera jovencita originates from Pampanga, its title derived from an endearing word for a young girl. The habanera de soltera celebrates the last dance of an engaged couple on the eve of their wedding day. Habasinan combines “haba” from habanera and “sinan” from Pangasinan. Romantically expressive, it is danced during weddings and important social occasions. Written by Corazon Generoso-Iñigo

text:
Hip-hop is a form of artistic and cultural expression, which uses four basic elements: namely, MC-ing or rap, DJ-ing or turntablism, graffiti writing or graf, and b-boying or breaking. Hip-hop started in the United States in the late 1960s as a way of expressing dissatisfaction, protest, and rage against extreme conditions of poverty, racism, street violence, gang wars, and state neglect. The youth in the inner cities or ghettoes of the United States’ East Coast, particularly in the South Bronx, were among its first performers. Battling or competition in the streets—which serve as locations for production, exhibition/performance of hip-hop—uses hip-hop’s four basic elements.

B-boying or breaking is the dance element of hip-hop. DJ Kool Herc is known to have coined the terms “breaking” to refer to the hip-hop dance and “breaker” to refer to practitioners of this type of dance. Contrary to the misconception that breaking derived its name from the bone-breaking acrobatic techniques and power moves that combine the fluidity of jazz and funk, the agility of martial arts, and the athleticism of gymnastics, hip-hop dance is called breaking because the breaker or the B(reak)-boy/B(reak)-girl used to dance the “breaks” or the temporary suspension of all instrumentations except for the last beat in a song. Later, when these breaks were looped and played over and over again by the DJ or spinner, extended beat breaks came to be known as breakbeats.

 

 

Generally, breakers used the dance to prevent street violence, which was rampant in the inner cities. Gang wars were translated into dance or break battles. Thus, winning in dance battles meant gaining respect in the streets and transforming the streets into dance spaces. This also meant claiming the city and the right to a space which the State had taken away from the poor African-American communities, as well as Latino and Asian migrants who were relegated to the inner cities. Breaking also served as an expression of resistance against studio-produced dances like jazz and ballet that were not accessible to the members of poor communities, because classes were too expensive and the techniques too stiff, confined, and commercial. Some of the pioneer breakers include the Crazy Commandos, Rock Steady Crew, and the Dynamic Rockers which dominated the streets of New York in the early 1980s.

As with other elements of hip-hop, breaking/b-boying is a combination, reinvention, reworking, and a sampling of numerous styles and vocabularies from jazz, salsa, boogie woogie, martial arts, gymnastics, acrobatics, and indigenous dances from all over the world. The different “schools” of hip-hop dances—from the rocking style rampant in the East Coast, to the LA style characterized by popping and locking which was supposedly developed in the West Coast, to the new jack swing of New York, and finally to the power moves of Asians predominantly executed by Korean and Chinese b-boys/b-girls—prove that the DNA of hip-hop dance is hybrid in nature.

Breaking/b-boying’s history in the United States is clearly rooted in the underground and cultural resistance movement of hip-hop, and it was only later on that the tension between manufactured hip-hop music/rap and underground hip-hop culture created rifts amongst its practitioners. In the Philippines, however, these two almost conflicting cultures of hip-hop dance, namely, the street/underground and commercial/manufactured, were almost simultaneously introduced through two streams of information dissemination.

The first was through the influx of American forms of music, including hip-hop in the late 1970s and 1980s, which came with the wave of the American balikbayan (Filipinos visiting from abroad) or Fil-Ams (Filipino Americans) who learned and participated in hip-hop culture as migrants in the United States. Upon returning or visiting the Philippines, they brought with them the underground hip-hop culture and some of its corresponding music and movies like Wild Style in 1982, Beat Street, Body Rock, and Breakin’ in 1984, and Krush Groove in 1985. The second way by which hip-hop became popular in the country was through the numerous dance shows that were patterned after the famous American music and dance television show called Soul Train. Two dance and music programs that dominated Philippine television in the 1980s, Penthouse 7 and Disco Rama, featured popping and locking techniques closely identified with the famous West Coast hip-hop pioneer breakers Sugar Pop and Poppin’ Feet.

 

The need to notate some of the basic vocabulary of breaking/b-boying became apparent with the establishment of numerous dance studios and companies offering hip-hop classes and embedding hip-hop genre in their repertoire, the proliferation of Internet tutorials on breaking, and the influence of hip-hop dance competitions all over the world. The dance form has acquired more or less a set of terms adapted from underground practices of breaking. Rocking or grooving, usually done at the start of a breakdance session, allows the dancer to get a feel of the beat patterns of the music. The dance move employs either a side-to-side swagger or an up-and-down bobbin’ of the upper torso and the head. Top rock is a breakdance movement that serves as preparation for more intense and acrobatic movements. Down rock or floor rock is another breakdance movement done with the hand/arm/head or body on the floor to demonstrate the breaker’s skill in weight shifts, control, and agility. Up rock is a competitive breakdance move that consists of shuffling, turns, and spins. Freeze / Stall / Air Move is a pose or stationary power move that focuses on body control and strength as the most skillful freezes, usually suspending off the floor, using a specific body part such as the arm, hand, or head.

 

At the core of a b-boy routine are power moves similar to gymnastic movements characterized by speed, momentum, and athleticism. There are several types of power moves. Spin could refer to a back spin, shoulder spin, hand spin, head spin, or air chair spin. Handstands demonstrate the breakers’ sense of balance and body control as they stand on their hands for extended periods of time while shifting from one body or leg pose to another. Floats could include crickets, hydro, jackhammer, lotus jackhammer, super jackhammer, darkhammer, hopping turtles, UFO, boomerangs, gorillas, gremlins spins, while Buddha spins are usually done with the body fixed while the hands move. Swipe, such as one-handed swipe, air swipe, or headslide swipe, is an upside-down power move wherein the breakers make a 360-degree turn using the momentum of their suspended legs while they land on their hands. Windmill, which could be a mummy, nutcracker, handcuff, or bellymill, is spinning on the floor without using the arms and almost purely dependent on the momentum created by the turning legs and bouncing mid- or upper torso. Flare—chair flare, one-handed flare, sandwich flare, lotus flare, or thread flare—is a gymnastic move that uses the arms to balance the suspended body while the body and the legs move side-to-side without touching the floor. Other basic movements that constitute the vocabulary of hip-hop are krumping, a move that is free, expressive, and often angry; locking, a sharp transition movement between multiple freezes; and popping or movements similar to mime, creating a stop-and-go motion effect.

The form may have originated in the cities of America but its presence has been strongly felt in the parks of Metro Manila and other provinces in the northern and southern parts of the Philippines. Interesting innovations of breakers include combining hip-hop styles with local dance moves. Pinoy b-boys/b-girls have likewise gained popularity abroad by competing and winning in world hip-hop dance competitions. Written by Roselle V. Pineda

article.value: Written by Roselle V. Pineda

B-boying or breaking is the dance element of hip-hop. DJ Kool Herc is known to have coined the terms “breaking” to refer to the hip-hop dance and “breaker” to refer to practitioners of this type of dance. Contrary to the misconception that breaking derived its name from the bone-breaking acrobatic techniques and power moves that combine the fluidity of jazz and funk, the agility of martial arts, and the athleticism of gymnastics, hip-hop dance is called breaking because the breaker or the B(reak)-boy/B(reak)-girl used to dance the “breaks” or the temporary suspension of all instrumentations except for the last beat in a song. Later, when these breaks were looped and played over and over again by the DJ or spinner, extended beat breaks came to be known as breakbeats.

article.value: Generally, breakers used the dance to prevent street violence, which was rampant in the inner cities. Gang wars were translated into dance or break battles. Thus, winning in dance battles meant gaining respect in the streets and transforming the streets into dance spaces. This also meant claiming the city and the right to a space which the State had taken away from the poor African-American communities, as well as Latino and Asian migrants who were relegated to the inner cities. Breaking also served as an expression of resistance against studio-produced dances like jazz and ballet that were not accessible to the members of poor communities, because classes were too expensive and the techniques too stiff, confined, and commercial. Some of the pioneer breakers include the Crazy Commandos, Rock Steady Crew, and the Dynamic Rockers which dominated the streets of New York in the early 1980s.

As with other elements of hip-hop, breaking/b-boying is a combination, reinvention, reworking, and a sampling of numerous styles and vocabularies from jazz, salsa, boogie woogie, martial arts, gymnastics, acrobatics, and indigenous dances from all over the world. The different “schools” of hip-hop dances—from the rocking style rampant in the East Coast, to the LA style characterized by popping and locking which was supposedly developed in the West Coast, to the new jack swing of New York, and finally to the power moves of Asians predominantly executed by Korean and Chinese b-boys/b-girls—prove that the DNA of hip-hop dance is hybrid in nature.

Breaking/b-boying’s history in the United States is clearly rooted in the underground and cultural resistance movement of hip-hop, and it was only later on that the tension between manufactured hip-hop music/rap and underground hip-hop culture created rifts amongst its practitioners. In the Philippines, however, these two almost conflicting cultures of hip-hop dance, namely, the street/underground and commercial/manufactured, were almost simultaneously introduced through two streams of information dissemination.

The first was through the influx of American forms of music, including hip-hop in the late 1970s and 1980s, which came with the wave of the American balikbayan (Filipinos visiting from abroad) or Fil-Ams (Filipino Americans) who learned and participated in hip-hop culture as migrants in the United States. Upon returning or visiting the Philippines, they brought with them the underground hip-hop culture and some of its corresponding music and movies like Wild Style in 1982, Beat Street, Body Rock, and Breakin’ in 1984, and Krush Groove in 1985. The second way by which hip-hop became popular in the country was through the numerous dance shows that were patterned after the famous American music and dance television show called Soul Train. Two dance and music programs that dominated Philippine television in the 1980s, Penthouse 7 and Disco Rama, featured popping and locking techniques closely identified with the famous West Coast hip-hop pioneer breakers Sugar Pop and Poppin’ Feet.

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Itik-Itik is a mimetic dance that is said to originate in Leyte, a province in the Visayas. The dancer’s arms, usually folded in, with his or her hands at chest level, mimic the flapping wings of a duck, itik in Filipino, and his or her feet glide or shuffle to copy the bird’s waddling.

According to Francisca Reyes-Aquino, itik-itik has its roots in sibay, a Visayan bird dance. The folk legend says that the term became popular in Surigao, a province at the southern part of the country, after “a young lady called Kanang (a nickname for Cayetana) who was considered the best dancer and singer of her time, was asked to dance the sibay. She became so enthusiastic and spirited during the performance that she began to improvise movements and steps similar to the movements of ducks as they walk with short, choppy steps and splash water over their backs while calling to the mates” (Reyes-Aquino 1996, 28). Those who saw her loved the way she danced and started to imitate her movements.

 

 

Itik-Itik is performed as a group dance during town festivities and other social gatherings. There is no limit to the number of couples who can participate. Partners do not touch at anytime; for demonstrations, partners usually stand about six feet apart. Female dancers wear either a camisa or kimona with a kerchief over one shoulder, paired with a patadyong (tubular skirt). Male dancers, on the other hand, don the barong tagalog or camisa de chino and trousers. Later, in the staging of folkloric performances, the girls were attired in a one-piece balintawak (butterfly-sleeved top) with a kerchief usually in black and yellow checkered pattern.

The most common footwork is done with one foot leading. The dancer steps forward with the heel of one foot (to imitate a duck’s foot), then slides the other foot behind it; he or she takes a small step with the ball of the first foot, and again slides the other foot close behind. The rondalla music that accompanies the dance is upbeat in 3/4 measure, and both the arm movements and the footwork are springy, giving the dance a lighthearted, playful feel.

Itik-Itik belongs to the nature/wildlife motif of local dances which “mimics the ways of birds, insects, fish, reptiles, and so forth” (Orosa-Goquingco 1980, 224). Other dances of this kind are the sinalampati (dove), balamban (sword-like fish), and the inalimango (crab). Written by Sarah Lumba

text:
Jazz dance is fundamentally a popular dance of African-American and Carribean origin utilizing African dance techniques such as polycentrism, rhythm, and isolation of individual parts of the human body. It also grew out of American vernacular or popular dance and incorporated the charleston, shim sham, lindy, and other similar social dances.

The term “jazz dance” was probably taken in 1917 from the “The Jazz Dance,” a song by W. Benton Overstreet. During the 1920s and 1930s, dancers performed with the big jazz bands of Count Basie, Duke Ellington, Benny Goodman, and Louis Armstong. The era was called the Jazz Age and the music was an international craze. In the 1940s, however, the original jazz dances lost their popularity. Modern jazz music replaced big-band jazz, and mass media introduced new varieties of popular music and dancing that eventually gave rise to present-day jazz dance.

Modern jazz dance is a highly stylized mix of original jazz dances with steps from dance crazes from the 1950s to the 1980s. It retains the syncopated rhythms, body isolations, and other original movements, but is done not only to jazz music, but also to pop, rhythm and blues, rock and disco.

 

 

Unlike the original jazz dance, which was performed by talented amateurs and self-styled entertainers, modern jazz is performed by professionals who may have a background in classical ballet, modern dance, ethnic and folk dance. It cannot be completely defined. Its essence is its ability to absorb the music and dances familiar to the general public, making it entertaining, accessible, and popular. Jazz used to be the most widely viewed dance form in the United States because it was available through many channels: TV, Broadway, nightclubs, and the concert stage.

Philippine jazz dance was first performed in bodabil shows at the Manila Grand Opera House and Clover Theater. Movies, both Filipino and foreign, also developed the public’s taste for the dance.

In 1959, Julie Borromeo arrived from the United States after training with Luigi and Matt Matox. She opened her own school and was the first to teach jazz dance formally. Shortly after, she formed the Julie Borromeo Dance Company, the first formal jazz company in the Philippines. Other troupes proliferated: The Allegro Dancers, The Aldeguer Sisters, Tony Fabella Dancers, and the Lito Calzado Dancers, among others. The Frontierettes of New Frontier Theatre were inspired by the Rockettes of Radio City Music Hall. It was headed by choreographer Corazon Generoso-Iñigo. She also worked with a group at the Araneta Coliseum, which performed with visiting artists. Other forerunners of jazz dance in the Philippines were Rose Borromeo, Alice Reyes, Teofilo Pila, Tina Santos, Jun Dalit, and Joji Felix-Velarde.

 

Jazz dance became extremely popular and was seen more and more often on TV, variety shows, musical theaters, pop concerts, local productions of American musical comedies such as West Side Story, Flower Drum Song, Sweet Charity, and local musicals like I’ll Take Manila by Morli Dharam, Nestor Robles, and Levi Celerio.

A number of third-generation jazz dance companies were also established. The Met Dance Company, started by Rene Hofileña and later headed by Veda Bañez, performed abroad and continues to perform locally. Whiplash, composed of former Met dancers, and the Adrenalin Dancers performed regularly in pop concerts and TV musical variety shows. One of the most popular groups was Powerdance, headed by choreographer Douglas Nierras, former head of Hotlegs and member of the CCP Dance Company. Many classical ballet dancers were lost to jazz dance as demand for it on TV, in concerts, shows, and TV advertisements made it commercially viable. Written by M. C. M. Garcia

text:
The jota is a dance in 3/4 tempo. Some varieties in the Philippines have 2/4 or 4/4 tempo sections. Its main triple tempo makes it similar to the waltz. The Philippine jotabal fuses the two.

The 16th-century courtship dance, canaries, is the “parent of jota” (Franks 1963, 63); the canaries, in turn, is the “slow form of the gigue” (Horst 1972, 109). The canaries used to be about death and only later about love and courtship (Buckman 1978, 87).

The jota itself is a couple dance performed to a song called cuartela, a four-line stanza of eight syllables to a line, and castanets. The Aragonese claim the dance; it is derived from the Andalusian fandango and was brought to Aragon by the exiled poet, Aben Jot. Its steps are “rapid hops, springs and athletic foot work” (Buckman 1978, 258), or more specifically, a jump into matalarana or a leap landing on one foot while pointing the other, followed by a pas de bourrie natural, a transitional travelling step (La Meri 1948, 163).

There are perhaps hundreds of jotas in the Philippines, not all documented and some newly concocted for special occasions. Some, such as the jota ilocana from Ilocos Norte and the jota echagueña from Isabela, require the bride and groom to dance. In the mascota and pantomina, the dancing bridal couple is showered with coins. In Zambales, the jota cabangan, also called the jota sinansinan, is done on the eve of a wedding.

The la jota San Joaquin from Iloilo and the famous la jota moncadeña from the town of Moncada in Tarlac are done to the rhythm of bamboo castanets. The moncadeña is unique for a passage called patay or desmayo, where the man and woman seem to commiserate with and console each other in a funereal tempo. The jota bicolana uses a decorative fan, while the Ilocano jota zapatilla is done to the clatter of women’s footwear. As in the la jota yogad, the men wear chinelas or closed slippers. The cabangan mimes courtship, lovers whispering by windows and secretly touching each other’s feet under the table. The jota ha kalipay (jota of happiness) from Samar is done by just one couple or amenudo.

Jotas are usually done by enough pairs to make up a quadrille, or even more. Regardless of the number of the couples, most of the figures involve meeting at the center, changing places, circling together as pairs, or a cadenza (small chain) as in the jota Rizal from Batangas. The Ibanag la jota filipina from Lal-lo, Cagayan, specifies its figures as pasakalye (meaning intermission), originally related to the chaconne (a preclassic dance in triple time), benya (bowing), poppo (clapping), and buelta (turning).

 

 

Clapping is done in the jotabal of Quezon, the la jota of Camarines Norte, the la jota concordiana of Iloilo, and the la jota filipina. Clapping is paralleled by panadyak (stamping) in the jota batangueña, the la jota and jota bicolana from Bicol, the a la jota and jota italiana from Laguna, the jota Pangasinan, the la jota samareña, the la jota from Negros Occidental, the jota Rizal, and the jotabal. In the jota gumaqueña, there is also clicking of heels.

Many of the jotas employ sway-balance, waltz, and waltz-turn steps. Korriti (mincing) is done in jota batangueña and jota paloana from Leyte. The characteristic Bicolano engaño step, which is similar to the sway-balance, is done in the jota rojana; the typically Visayan espunti step, or the shuffle on one foot while pointing the other, in the laota and the ese-ese step, also Visayan, and consisting of three steps and a stamp, in the la jota San Joaquin; the Ilocano mudansa or oblique steps with heel brushes in the la jota from Paoay, Ilocos Norte; and the piang-piang or sliding quarter turns in the jota ha kalipay. Some jotas employ the sarok or crossing feet and arms with body bent, cross-step, step-swing, step-brush (often with a hop), and a variety of turns. Some of these steps may lead to a do-si-do or changing places in a small square or back to back as in the jota Pangasinan, jota Rizal, and laota, or to a regular ballroom hold as in the jota cagayana and the jota Pangasinan. Some jotas employ other hand gestures besides clapping such as the kumintang or wrist circling and salok or scooping down with one hand.

Most jotas are named after their places of origin, such as the jota Navarra, originally from Spain and now called jota paloana in Leyte. Depending on the region, the women dancers are dressed in maria clara (native gown), the Ilocano costume mascota (tailless, floral-print skirt), or even patadyong (barrel skirt).

There are many other popular jota: the Tagalog manileña, caviteña and mindoreña; the jota de Olongapo from Zambales and the jota ecijana from Nueva Ecija; the Ilocos Norte vintarina, sarrateña, and laoagueña; and the sevillana from Iloilo.

The European triple tempo agreed so much with Filipinos that the jota spread throughout the country. The jota de Olongapo shows influences of the American square dance. The jota marks special occasions, such as fiestas, weddings, and baptisms. But they also have deeper implications when danced during the guling-guling, the mardi gras on the day before Ash Wednesday, or the tambora which is held on Christmas eve. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

article.value: Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

The 16th-century courtship dance, canaries, is the “parent of jota” (Franks 1963, 63); the canaries, in turn, is the “slow form of the gigue” (Horst 1972, 109). The canaries used to be about death and only later about love and courtship (Buckman 1978, 87).

The jota itself is a couple dance performed to a song called cuartela, a four-line stanza of eight syllables to a line, and castanets. The Aragonese claim the dance; it is derived from the Andalusian fandango and was brought to Aragon by the exiled poet, Aben Jot. Its steps are “rapid hops, springs and athletic foot work” (Buckman 1978, 258), or more specifically, a jump into matalarana or a leap landing on one foot while pointing the other, followed by a pas de bourrie natural, a transitional travelling step (La Meri 1948, 163).

There are perhaps hundreds of jotas in the Philippines, not all documented and some newly concocted for special occasions. Some, such as the jota ilocana from Ilocos Norte and the jota echagueña from Isabela, require the bride and groom to dance. In the mascota and pantomina, the dancing bridal couple is showered with coins. In Zambales, the jota cabangan, also called the jota sinansinan, is done on the eve of a wedding.

The la jota San Joaquin from Iloilo and the famous la jota moncadeña from the town of Moncada in Tarlac are done to the rhythm of bamboo castanets. The moncadeña is unique for a passage called patay or desmayo, where the man and woman seem to commiserate with and console each other in a funereal tempo. The jota bicolana uses a decorative fan, while the Ilocano jota zapatilla is done to the clatter of women’s footwear. As in the la jota yogad, the men wear chinelas or closed slippers. The cabangan mimes courtship, lovers whispering by windows and secretly touching each other’s feet under the table. The jota ha kalipay (jota of happiness) from Samar is done by just one couple or amenudo.

Jotas are usually done by enough pairs to make up a quadrille, or even more. Regardless of the number of the couples, most of the figures involve meeting at the center, changing places, circling together as pairs, or a cadenza (small chain) as in the jota Rizal from Batangas. The Ibanag la jota filipina from Lal-lo, Cagayan, specifies its figures as pasakalye (meaning intermission), originally related to the chaconne (a preclassic dance in triple time), benya (bowing), poppo (clapping), and buelta (turning).

article.value: Clapping is done in the jotabal of Quezon, the la jota of Camarines Norte, the la jota concordiana of Iloilo, and the la jota filipina. Clapping is paralleled by panadyak (stamping) in the jota batangueña, the la jota and jota bicolana from Bicol, the a la jota and jota italiana from Laguna, the jota Pangasinan, the la jota samareña, the la jota from Negros Occidental, the jota Rizal, and the jotabal. In the jota gumaqueña, there is also clicking of heels.

Many of the jotas employ sway-balance, waltz, and waltz-turn steps. Korriti (mincing) is done in jota batangueña and jota paloana from Leyte. The characteristic Bicolano engaño step, which is similar to the sway-balance, is done in the jota rojana; the typically Visayan espunti step, or the shuffle on one foot while pointing the other, in the laota and the ese-ese step, also Visayan, and consisting of three steps and a stamp, in the la jota San Joaquin; the Ilocano mudansa or oblique steps with heel brushes in the la jota from Paoay, Ilocos Norte; and the piang-piang or sliding quarter turns in the jota ha kalipay. Some jotas employ the sarok or crossing feet and arms with body bent, cross-step, step-swing, step-brush (often with a hop), and a variety of turns. Some of these steps may lead to a do-si-do or changing places in a small square or back to back as in the jota Pangasinan, jota Rizal, and laota, or to a regular ballroom hold as in the jota cagayana and the jota Pangasinan. Some jotas employ other hand gestures besides clapping such as the kumintang or wrist circling and salok or scooping down with one hand.

Most jotas are named after their places of origin, such as the jota Navarra, originally from Spain and now called jota paloana in Leyte. Depending on the region, the women dancers are dressed in maria clara (native gown), the Ilocano costume mascota (tailless, floral-print skirt), or even patadyong (barrel skirt).

There are many other popular jota: the Tagalog manileña, caviteña and mindoreña; the jota de Olongapo from Zambales and the jota ecijana from Nueva Ecija; the Ilocos Norte vintarina, sarrateña, and laoagueña; and the sevillana from Iloilo.

The European triple tempo agreed so much with Filipinos that the jota spread throughout the country. The jota de Olongapo shows influences of the American square dance. The jota marks special occasions, such as fiestas, weddings, and baptisms. But they also have deeper implications when danced during the guling-guling, the mardi gras on the day before Ash Wednesday, or the tambora which is held on Christmas eve.

text:
The Bontok from Central Mountain Province are known for their war dances, particularly the kayaw. Also known as mamakar or mangangayaw, the kayaw is a mock combat between two tribal warriors. Each warrior wields a pinnang or hand axe in one hand and a kalasag or shield in the other. A tufay or spear is sometimes used, instead of an axe.

The dance begins with the entrance of the male musicians doing the sikwat or hopping on the left then the right foot, with the heels alternately raised backward. They either strike their hand-held gongs in 2/4 measure or clap in the same measure if there are no gongs available. The female dancers, whose upper body is always erect, trail the musicians using the same footwork but with arms stretched sideways, hands in a fist and thumbs up. This arm movement is called the isagni.

 

 

The two warriors then enter, usually one after the other. Each wears a fallaka (also tinu-od) or cylindrical hat embellished with a rooster’s feather and a pig’s jaws; a tangka (also tanka) or arm bracelet adorned with bound hair; and a wanes or loin cloth about 2 1/2 to 3 m long. They move about the circle or semi-circle formed by the musicians and the dancers. Amidst the beating of the gongs, they do a lot of posturing, running around with the torso slightly bent forward, stamping, doing the sikwat and the salidsid, which is a simple jump followed by a slide sideways. One warrior pounds the ground with his axe; the other swings his spear around. Soon enough, their shields clash in mid-air. Both warriors step back for a moment to circle and dodge each other once again. They attack each other with their weapons more than once. In the end, one of them is killed. When this happens, the gongs’ beat changes from a 2/4 to a 3/4 beat. The musicians and the dancers begin to walk slowly on tiptoe, their knees bouncing almost imperceptibly, as they follow the successful warrior slowly exiting, carrying the slain one on his shoulder.

This ritual dance is performed to “thank the gods for success in headtaking expeditions” (Alejandro and Santos-Gana 2002, 77). Nowadays, it is performed before the planting season to call in the rains for a bountiful harvest. Written by Sarah Lumba

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Kumintang is the name given to several distinct styles, techniques, and forms of music and dance originating in the areas now known as Batangas, a province in the heartland of the Southern Tagalog region. Early 19th-century travelers’ accounts often mention the kumintang as a Tagalog chant national, describing them as dance-songs performed by pairs of men and women, with texts concerning love and courtship. All accounts mention a glass of native coconut wine passed from hand to hand by the dancers as they sing.

The earliest reference to the dance-song is found in Nicolas de la Cruz Bagay’s engraving for Fr Pedro Murillo Velarde’s Carta Hydrographica y Chorographica de las islas Filipinas (Hydrographic and Chorographic Documents of the Philippine Islands), 1734. A side bar to the map proper shows three small figures—a pair of male and female dancers and a male guitarist—in a scene labeled Indios bailando el comintang. Jean Baptiste Mallat, in his travelogue, Les Philippines, describes it as a pantomimic dance where the man runs around and gestures to a woman (not always decently), and finally pretends illness to get the woman’s full attention.

 

 

A piece of music found in the second volume of the Mallat work, identified as the “Comintang de la Conquista” by Henry Cohen is the earliest extant musical transcription of the form and is useful material for scholars, although Epifanio de los Santos comments that the piano line does not reflect the form of the kumintang and is an attempt to modernize the music for the European audience. Other early transcriptions are those found in Manuel Walls y Merino’s La Musica Popular de Filipinas (Popular Music of the Philippines), 1892, and Epifanio de los Santos’s Balagtas y su Florante (Balagtas and His Florante), 1914.

In the 20th century, Francisca Reyes-Aquino dubbed kumintang as the circular hand and wrist movement also known as the kunday. Among present-day aficionados of musical and dance events called awitan and pandangguhan in and around the city of Batangas, kumintang also refers to a guitar-plucking style, considered the most melodious and beautiful of all guitar styles accompanying the old kinanluran style of pandangguhan dance songs. Written by Elena Rivera Mirano

text:
The kuradang is a dance found mainly in the Visayas. It is also a step combination in time standardized in Philippine folk dance. The term is derived from kurandang, literally meaning showy or overdressed.

The movement is composed of a rhythmic change step—one foot steps diagonally forward, the other foot displaces it at the rear, and the first foot steps forward again all in two counts, and with a step across by the second foot to carry the weight on the third count. This combination is also done diagonally backwards, i.e., in reverse, but with pointing across the second foot, instead of a transfer of weight. A Visayan variety from Iloilo does the combination with hops, leg swings, and body twists, but set in duple time.

 

As a full dance with many variations, the kuradang is done during fiestas and occasions like weddings, mainly in the Visayas. A very simple kuradang recorded in Cebu and Bohol by Francisca Reyes-Aquino involves changing places and circling around. Another one, native to Loboc, Bohol, is similar but makes use of complex combinations of step-hops, two-foot jumps, parallel tortiller (a kind of sideway shuffling), and stamping embellishment. There are also contrasting steps for separate couples, simultaneously done in one figure.

In Samar, the kuradang is made up of waltz steps, done with or without the normal ballroom-dancing hold (face to face) and without specified formation. Another Samar kuradang was recorded in Villareal by Juan C. Miel: a “ballroom folk dance,” it is made up of waltz steps elaborated on with sway balances, hops, cross steps (a foot crossing over), and turns. It is accompanied by a song sung by onlookers and is about the solicitude of one “Inday” (a common Visayan name for girls and young women) who is compared to a shady tree or prized chick coveted by a hawk.

A kuradang in 2/4 time from Pototan, Iloilo, uses the Visayan step combination above, with much clapping from the dancers. Even if the dancers are barefoot (which they often are, unless shod in corcho or slippers, or shoes), there is much meeting and changing of places in the manner of the formal quadrille. It is quite sophisticated in choreography; the two couples are called mayor and menor, sometimes dancing different steps simultaneously in one figure.

Most female kuradang dancers wear patadyong (tubular skirt) with camisa or kimona (native blouse), or a saya (floor-length skirt) with a cola (train) tucked into the waist to show off the sapad or binabaye (embroidered chemise). The men usually wear a camisa de chino (closed collarless shirt) or barong tagalog. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Kuratsa, aka curacha, is an indigenized form of the la cucaracha (the cockroach), a Mexican courtship dance. It is believed to have been introduced by Mexican soldiers and traders when Mexico had administrative and trade relations with the Philippines. However, it is also very different from its Mexican counterpart in both music and movement. Based on the movement patterns of kuratsa, the dance form is believed to be a descendant of the kigal or quigal aka binanug described by Jesuit missionary Francisco Ignacio de Alzina in Historia de las Islas e Indios de Bisayas, 1668. Kigal is a courtship dance that mimics the mating of birds like the chicken and the hawk. Kuratsa’s movements suggest teasing and flirtation.

The music used in all Visayan versions is similar, in two parts and 3/4 time. Speed may vary, depending on the style and ability of the dancers. With agile dancers, the sway balance is performed with a brush or a hop. Cross and waltz turns are done briskly. Chasing steps accent the dance figures. The woman performs movements to attract her partner, while the man responds in kind. Depending on the artistry and skill of the dancing couple, the couple improvises combinations based on the basic movements of kuratsa. All versions contain the varied dance movements in accordance with the mood, inspiration, and cultural practices of the dancers. It is danced during weddings, baptismal celebrations, birthdays, and fiestas. There are as many versions of the kuratsa as there are localities that learned and adopted it as their own. The earliest of the kuratsa recorded by Francisca Reyes-Aquino was popular in Leyte and was called kuratsa visaya. Other kuratsa versions were later documented from other Visayan regions: kuratsa boholana from Bohol; kuratsa bago, kuratsa pulupandan, and kuratsa Bacolod from Negros Occidental; and kuratsa Iloilo from New Lucena, Iloilo. There are also kuratsa variants in Antique, namely kuratsa Culasi, kuratsa Hamtic, kuratsa San Jose, kuratsa Tibiao, and kuratsa antiqueña.

The version in Samar known as kuratsa samareña is similar to the antiqueña, where the bride and groom / performers are showered with coins or have gala or gifts of paper pinned on their holiday clothes. Kuratsa samareña is usually done amenudo (by a couple), with music that has five parts apart from an introduction and a finale. Both musicans and spectators sing during the fifth part of the accompaniment. A typical song performed in the kuratsa samareña is the “Abalulay.”

 

Abalulay, Abalulay

Linguid-linguid hinen baybay

Kon igkita ka hin away

Dalagan ayaw pa patay

Abalulay, Abalulay

 

(Abalulay, Abalulay

Sailing closely to the shore

If you encounter a quarrel

Run away, don’t get killed

Abalulay, Abalulay)

In Samar, the female dancer dons a patadyong (tubular skirt) and a camisa (a full skirt), a kimono (loose blouse with short or 3/4 sleeves), and alampay (scarf). The male dancer sports the barong tagalog with white pair of pants, or a camisa de chino matched with colored trousers. For formal occasions, the female garment is a mestiza dress and the male costume consists of barong tagalog and black trousers.

The kuratsa Iloilo specifies three figures in all six: haylo, estelo (where the man tries to block the woman’s way and gestures pleadingly), and padayao-dayao (literally, “to praise”). The hamtic specifies four figures in all seven: remate, pundo-pundo, ese-ese, and bayong-bayong.

There is only one type documented outside the Visayas: the kuratsa Paoay of Ilocos Norte. There, it is finished off with the characteristic ariquenquen dance, and its music shifts from triple to duple time. The Ilocano kuratsa starts very slowly in the execution of cross steps, moving forward and backward, with hands on waist and holding the skirt. As the dance progresses, the music goes faster, until the dance ends with coquettish gestures, such as an exaggerated hip movement or a slight raising of the skirt.

Kuratsa is more identified with the Waray, who consider it as the most popular dance among people from all classes. The dance is not formally taught to local children in the community but passed on naturally by social practice. In the Waray region, a fiesta is incomplete without the sarayaw or dance festival where kuratsa is the highlight. Kuratsa has also been used by politicians for their promotional campaigns. Although the dance is common to all social levels, the kuratsa performance, especially during grand public events, is the venue for the politicians and political aspirants to show off their dancing talent and their gala or the money thrown during performance. Since the dance, by nature, raises funds, the highlight of the sarayaw is the kuratsa performed by politicians.

In recent times, changes were introduced to the movement vocabulary of kuratsa with the incorporation of hip-hop and other invented movements derived from ballet and other genres. article.value: Written by Carmen T. Andin and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz, updated by Kinna G. Kwan and Rosalie S. Matilac

The music used in all Visayan versions is similar, in two parts and 3/4 time. Speed may vary, depending on the style and ability of the dancers. With agile dancers, the sway balance is performed with a brush or a hop. Cross and waltz turns are done briskly. Chasing steps accent the dance figures. The woman performs movements to attract her partner, while the man responds in kind. Depending on the artistry and skill of the dancing couple, the couple improvises combinations based on the basic movements of kuratsa. All versions contain the varied dance movements in accordance with the mood, inspiration, and cultural practices of the dancers. It is danced during weddings, baptismal celebrations, birthdays, and fiestas. There are as many versions of the kuratsa as there are localities that learned and adopted it as their own. The earliest of the kuratsa recorded by Francisca Reyes-Aquino was popular in Leyte and was called kuratsa visaya. Other kuratsa versions were later documented from other Visayan regions: kuratsa boholana from Bohol; kuratsa bago, kuratsa pulupandan, and kuratsa Bacolod from Negros Occidental; and kuratsa Iloilo from New Lucena, Iloilo. There are also kuratsa variants in Antique, namely kuratsa Culasi, kuratsa Hamtic, kuratsa San Jose, kuratsa Tibiao, and kuratsa antiqueña.

The version in Samar known as kuratsa samareña is similar to the antiqueña, where the bride and groom / performers are showered with coins or have gala or gifts of paper pinned on their holiday clothes. Kuratsa samareña is usually done amenudo (by a couple), with music that has five parts apart from an introduction and a finale. Both musicans and spectators sing during the fifth part of the accompaniment. A typical song performed in the kuratsa samareña is the “Abalulay.”

Abalulay, Abalulay

Linguid-linguid hinen baybay

Kon igkita ka hin away

Dalagan ayaw pa patay

Abalulay, Abalulay

 

(Abalulay, Abalulay

Sailing closely to the shore

If you encounter a quarrel

Run away, don’t get killed

Abalulay, Abalulay)

In Samar, the female dancer dons a patadyong (tubular skirt) and a camisa (a full skirt), a kimono (loose blouse with short or 3/4 sleeves), and alampay (scarf). The male dancer sports the barong tagalog with white pair of pants, or a camisa de chino matched with colored trousers. For formal occasions, the female garment is a mestiza dress and the male costume consists of barong tagalog and black trousers.

The kuratsa Iloilo specifies three figures in all six: haylo, estelo (where the man tries to block the woman’s way and gestures pleadingly), and padayao-dayao (literally, “to praise”). The hamtic specifies four figures in all seven: remate, pundo-pundo, ese-ese, and bayong-bayong.

There is only one type documented outside the Visayas: the kuratsa Paoay of Ilocos Norte. There, it is finished off with the characteristic ariquenquen dance, and its music shifts from triple to duple time. The Ilocano kuratsa starts very slowly in the execution of cross steps, moving forward and backward, with hands on waist and holding the skirt. As the dance progresses, the music goes faster, until the dance ends with coquettish gestures, such as an exaggerated hip movement or a slight raising of the skirt.

Kuratsa is more identified with the Waray, who consider it as the most popular dance among people from all classes. The dance is not formally taught to local children in the community but passed on naturally by social practice. In the Waray region, a fiesta is incomplete without the sarayaw or dance festival where kuratsa is the highlight. Kuratsa has also been used by politicians for their promotional campaigns. Although the dance is common to all social levels, the kuratsa performance, especially during grand public events, is the venue for the politicians and political aspirants to show off their dancing talent and their gala or the money thrown during performance. Since the dance, by nature, raises funds, the highlight of the sarayaw is the kuratsa performed by politicians.

In recent times, changes were introduced to the movement vocabulary of kuratsa with the incorporation of hip-hop and other invented movements derived from ballet and other genres. Moreover, the kuratsa today has become a musical form separate from the dance. Waray artists like Art Ramasasa have composed and experimented on the music that traditionally accompanied the dancing. The lyrics have also changed through time, incorporating current issues and sociocultural changes.

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
The lanceros, short for a ballroom dance called quadrille des landers, is a quadrille in 2/4 or 6/8 or in combination. It was created in 1817 by John Duval, a Dublin master, two years after the introduction of the quadrille to England from Paris by Lady Jersey. He published the descriptions of the figures la dorset, lodoiska, la native, les graces, and les landers in the Dublin Evening Post. It was first danced at the grand ball of the Countess of Farnham on 9 Apr 1817, to music by Spagnoletti and Yaniewicz.

Like the quadrille, the steps of the lanceros were originally complex and difficult. Eventually, these were simplified into walking steps. With the popularity of the waltz, the figures were waltzed to current music from musicals, operettas, and operas. This gave rise to the lively kitchen lancers, where the ladies were swung off their feet.

 

Joseph Hart published Les Lanciers, a Second Set of Lanciers in 1820, with similar figures and composers used by Duval. It was introduced in London by students of Sacre, a fashionable teaching mistress. In 1836, Laborde introduced the lanceros in Paris. In 1957, a Prussian court ballet performed the dance costumed in the uniform of cavalry lancers. By the 1850s, the dance had become prominent. The dance eventually found its way to the Philippines through Spain, or possibly later, during the American occupation. Its name was changed to lanceros. To date, there are three documented dances.

The lanceros de Pagsanjan in Laguna is performed as a quadrille and is popular in many regions. The figures simulate an American square dance called lancers, but it is less like an American square dance, and more like English lancers or the Philippine rigodon. The participants elegantly walk the saludo, chuchillada grande, chuchillada pequeña, desaire, visita, and cadena.

The lanceros de Tayabas was performed as a divertissement in the komedya of Tayabas, Quezon. Danced primarily in the quadrille formation, this lanceros uniquely integrates the use of fans for the ladies and panama hats for the gentlemen in the execution of the different figures in the dance.

The lanceros de Lingayen is also done in quadrille formation and incorporates Spanish and French influences, imitating the movements of the lancers. In Pangasinan, the hands are held in the kewet position. Four figures use walking steps. It incorporates typical Filipino dance patterns and steps, such as clapping while a partner walks and turns, kneeling and holding one hand while a partner walks around, turning under the arch of joined hands, jaleo (solo), change steps, gallops, heel places, do-si-do, foot stamping, and whirl-turns.

The lanceros de Negros of Silay was also popular in Luzon and other parts of the Visayas in the Spanish era and as prominent as the rigodon. It is danced in longways formation. The first figure has walking steps in various directions. It proceeds with changing steps, brincos con puntillas, brincos con vueltas, gallops, three-step turns, and whirl turns. It is uncertain whether the lanceros de Lingayen and the lanceros de Negros are examples of different stages in the development of the lanceros, or whether they are adaptations, or a combination of both. Written by Corazon Generoso-Iñigo

 

Sources

Alejandro, Reynaldo Gamboa, and Amanda Abad Santos-Gana. 2002. Sayaw: Philippine Dances. Pasig City: Anvil Publishing, Inc.

Obusan, Ramon A. 1989.RITWAL: Rare and Unpublished by Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group. Video documentary. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines.

text:
The langka, or fighting dance, is a kind of training or rehearsal for actual combat. It is a martial dance still popular among community celebrations in the Sulu archipelago. It is practiced by men and women—alone, in pairs, or in groups. The term “langka,” when affixed to the name of a traditional martial art form in Sulu and Tawi-Tawi, suggests a playful and frolicsome imitation or interpretation of such martial form.

The usually empty-handed performer normally begins with a greeting or obeisance. The square-line direction of movement, postures, and gestures closely resemble those of the martial art forms of Malaysia and Indonesia. It is infused with dance-like qualities, with movements that vary from slow and flowing, to graceful and angular.

 

There are many variants of the langka. Langka kuntaw is the Tausug-Sama (aka Samal) art of self-defense. The kuntaw or kuntao martial art form originates from Fukien, China and found its way into the Sama and Tausug martial art tradition characterized by nimble footwork and low stances for quick maneouvers. Jumps, kicks, and deep knee bends are combined with precise, forceful arm movements similar to the movements in Japanese karate, Chinese kung-fu, and the lai-ka of the Shan States of Burma.

Langka lima is a Sama-Tausug martial dance variation of five slow-paced movements or stances punctuated by the artful use of a bladed weapon, like a barung or a kris, before a momentary pose at the end of each defense stance. A kerchief, sometimes wielded by the performer, further accentuates the gestures.

Langka silat, performed throughout the Sulu archipelago, is characterized by a fast-paced but more relaxed and flowing movement compared to the langka kuntaw. It may be done as a solo performance with a sequence of movements, or with many opponents but with a set of stances and postures. The langka silat has a close affinity with the bersilat, an ancient art of self-defense, probably of Sumatran origin, and taught and practiced throughout Indonesia and Malaysia for over 400 years. Langka pansak is another variant that focuses on achieving perfection in the postures and stances. Execution of each sequence of movements is deliberately slow and ends with a short pause to transition into the next sequence.

 

The magsangkil is a Sama Dilaut fight dance. The dancers carry spears and fish-shaped shields made of tightly woven rattan. Meanwhile, langka sayaw is an exciting Sama dance from Sibutu, Tawi-Tawi. The two opponents dance carrying a budjak or lance, and a taming or a round shield. Fighters first appraise each other from a distance, then approach each other to execute both attack and defense techniques in a continuous manner until their weapons and shields are laid on the ground. To outsmart each other, the dancers may try kicking sand on each other’s face in order to get their weapons back.

As a dance form, the langka may be integrated into the pangalay or igal with spectacular results, as in the langka baluang or martial dance characterized by the movements of an angry monkey. Langka budjang is the only martial dance version for women with complete sequences from obeisance to the square line direction of stances and ending bow. The sculptural postures and gestures belie the restrained force of the thrusts. Movements involve kicks, jumps, fluid arm movements punctuated with clapping and slapping motions and sounds.

A female dancer usually wears a sablay (loose blouse) paired with a sawwal kantiu (loose trousers) for ease of movement. For the same reason, a male performer wears a badju (loose shirt) usually of white cotton fabric and a sawwal kantiu of batik or printed cotton fabric. However, the tight-fitting sawwal kuput shows the dancer’s postures to the best advantage. The usual male accessory is a pis or scarf wrapped around the head or placed on the shoulder, or a kuppiya (headpiece) which may be embroidered, or made of some rich fabric, like velvet.

The langka or martial dance is performed to the fast rhythm of a single percussive instrument like the agung, tambol, gandang, and tuntung. The agung is a deep brass gong played with a beater covered with rubber to protect the instrument and to produce a pleasing sound. The tambol is a metal drum with animal skin played with a stick. The gandang is a wooden drum played with bare hands on both ends, fastened on the neck with a piece of cloth, or tucked under one leg. The tuntung is the smallest gong in the kulintangan. For more formal occasions when a kulintangan ensemble is available, kulintangan music is used for accompaniment. Written by Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa, with notes from Rosalie S. Matilac

text:
The lunsay is the song dance of the Jama Mapun, one of the indigenous groups that populate Tawi-Tawi province in the Sulu Archipelago. An intricate dance, it is the only one in the Philippines accompanied by communal singing, the usual theme of which is love. Lunsay reflects the natural environment of the Jama Mapun: the movement of sea waves, the waxing and waning of the moon.

All the villagers, young and old, married and single men and women, participate in this night-long dance. The singing and dancing may take place inside a house or in any open space. Performers are free to fall in or out of the dance circle or spiral to eat, rest, or greet newcomers. The people’s voluntary participation as spectator and/or performer sustains the lunsay session all through the night.

 

The dance is performed on the lakapan lapis or floor matting made of wide bamboo slats. The bamboo matting, when placed on the ground or floor, produces clapping sounds under the impact of dancing feet, a special effect essential to the dance, which is alternately fast and slow. But even without the lakapan lapis, the feet stomping on bare surface also produce the engaging percussion that harmonizes with the singing.

The lunsay formation is either a circle or a spiral of handholding dancers; the inner coil is always occupied by the women. The male and female ends of the line do not hold hands directly but use a yellow kerchief, a stick, or a piece of string to link hands. The dance invariably starts with the slow movement (clockwise or step-left), matched by plaintive singing. When the singing is accelerated, the steps become vigorous and the movement direction changes to counterclockwise or step-right.

The intricacy of lunsay lies in the fact that lunsay singing is done simultaneously with the dancing, and has different melodic patterns that pertain to specific movements dominated by footwork. A tune from any of the six types of songs intoned by the men is always repeated and echoed by the women, but with appropriate changes in the words so as not to reveal unacceptable thoughts.

The singing begins with the slow tugilah or back and forth step, composed of eight phrases. The dancers move in a clockwise direction through footwork: step left foot sideward or forward and right foot stomps twice as it closes to left foot; then left foot steps forward followed by one right stomp behind left foot. Dancers sing while executing the movements:

Nilabuan tugilah lunsay na ba dumagsah

(Let us do the back and forth step, and start the lunsay)

 

Nilabuan na kakasi lunsay maglamilami

(Let us love one another and have fun with the lunsay)

 

Tagnaan ta na ba lunsay kaam siga ba malumbay

(Let’s start the lunsay, you who are kind and considerate)

 

Lamilami na ba nagnah kaam jama dambilah.

(Let’s start the fun, you people from the other side of the community.)

Through a transition movement, the leader of a lunsay session may initiate the end of tugilah after an indefinite time of enjoyable group dancing. The first pattern of transition footwork consists of right foot stepping forward followed by a left foot swing, then left foot is placed backward and right foot closes to left foot.

Once the transition movement is established after several repetitions, the dancers sing the tinggayon 1 or slow step 1, composed of four phrases. The dancers move in a counterclockwise direction through footwork that rises to a frenetic pace: stomp right foot sideward and close left foot to right foot. Then left foot stomps backward behind right foot and right foot steps close to left foot. The song that accompanies the dancing starts with a slow rhythm:

Tinggayon tinggayon doh battis pinaguyon doh

(Let’s do the slow step and let’s synchronize our steps)

 

Kaam takka bahau paantan nakam pitu.

(Those who just arrived, come hold our hands …)

The steps lead to a rising momentum until the leader ends the tinggayon with the second pattern of transition dance steps: left foot step forward with right foot swing; then right foot is placed behind and left foot closes to right foot.

The third part of lunsay is nilabos, meaning “to heighten performance,” and composed of four phrases starting in slow rhythm. Footwork is in clockwise direction, accelerating from a slow pace: left foot sideward step, right foot crosses over left, and left foot closes to right foot. Again, the leader ends nilabos by initiating a transitional movement.

The fourth melodic pattern is halin taroh, which means “change the tune.” This part has 12 phrases sung in fast tempo as dancers move counterclockwise stomping right foot sideward, followed by left foot closing to right foot. The simple but vigorous footwork builds up to a climax that leads to the second transition movement.

Halin taroh ba tunis na kaam siga gambina

(Let us change the tune, you beautiful ladies)

 

Tattoh pakiyukiyum na

(Let us laugh and smile)

 

Mangkin ba sinaglitan na.

(Especially when you are praised)

The fifth part is palabu-labu, meaning “swaying back and forth.” This is also in a fast beat and in counterclockwise direction. The footwork creates the percussion with a pattern of step right foot sideward, stomp left foot close to right foot with bent knees. Then step left foot sideward and stomp the right foot twice close to the left foot with flexed knees. The singing and fast beat steps are repeated as many times as the performers please, until the leader does the second transition movement to lead to the next song.

The sixth part of lunsay is tinggayon 2 or slow step 2 with 10 phrases in slow beat in clockwise motion starting with left foot sideward followed by a right foot swing forward. Then the right foot steps backward ending with a close-point of left foot to right foot. The footwork is repeated over and over until the leader ends it by doing the first transition dance steps. The whole group follows. The seventh part, moleh, meaning “let’s go home,” is for the closing. The song has eight phrases in slow tempo. Dancers move clockwise by stepping left foot forward and right foot stomps close to left foot. Then right foot steps backward and left foot stomps close to right foot. The dance steps are repeated as many times until the community dancing succumbs to the slow down of energy leading to rest.

As a spontaneous communal song dance, performers wear everyday garments when they dance the lunsay. But during celebratory gatherings, performers wear traditional costumes. Girls and women may wear sablay or loose blouse with sawwal kantiu (loose pants) or patadjung (tubular skirt). When worn with a sawwal, the sablay may go with a siyag or sash. Boys and men may wear the badjuh-lapi or the collarless tailored jacket with the sawwal kantiu.

In the 21st century, obvious changes in the lunsay are demonstrated by the different melodies, and the mixing of male and female in the circular and spiral formations. Such changes are brought about by modernization, lack of proper transmission from the elders who still know the song dance, and the incursion of Malaysian culture. Cultural workers of Tawi-Tawi are aware of the need to preserve traditional art forms like the lunsay because of Mapun’s propensity—due to its proximity to Sabah—to be taken over by Malaysian culture. Sabah is greatly acculturated by contemporary Malaysian culture, though the contested oil-rich territory is still considered to be under Philippine sovereignty. Written by Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa, updated by Rosalie S. Matilac, with notes from Filemon G. Romero

article.value: Written by Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa, updated by Rosalie S. Matilac, with notes from Filemon G. Romero

All the villagers, young and old, married and single men and women, participate in this night-long dance. The singing and dancing may take place inside a house or in any open space. Performers are free to fall in or out of the dance circle or spiral to eat, rest, or greet newcomers. The people’s voluntary participation as spectator and/or performer sustains the lunsay session all through the night.

value.desc: Lunsay, Jama Mapun song dance, 1998 (Felicidad A. Prudente Photo Collection)

article.value: The dance is performed on the lakapan lapis or floor matting made of wide bamboo slats. The bamboo matting, when placed on the ground or floor, produces clapping sounds under the impact of dancing feet, a special effect essential to the dance, which is alternately fast and slow. But even without the lakapan lapis, the feet stomping on bare surface also produce the engaging percussion that harmonizes with the singing.

The lunsay formation is either a circle or a spiral of handholding dancers; the inner coil is always occupied by the women. The male and female ends of the line do not hold hands directly but use a yellow kerchief, a stick, or a piece of string to link hands. The dance invariably starts with the slow movement (clockwise or step-left), matched by plaintive singing. When the singing is accelerated, the steps become vigorous and the movement direction changes to counterclockwise or step-right.

The intricacy of lunsay lies in the fact that lunsay singing is done simultaneously with the dancing, and has different melodic patterns that pertain to specific movements dominated by footwork. A tune from any of the six types of songs intoned by the men is always repeated and echoed by the women, but with appropriate changes in the words so as not to reveal unacceptable thoughts.

The singing begins with the slow tugilah or back and forth step, composed of eight phrases. The dancers move in a clockwise direction through footwork: step left foot sideward or forward and right foot stomps twice as it closes to left foot; then left foot steps forward followed by one right stomp behind left foot. Dancers sing while executing the movements:

Nilabuan tugilah lunsay na ba dumagsah

(Let us do the back and forth step, and start the lunsay)

 

Nilabuan na kakasi lunsay maglamilami

(Let us love one another and have fun with the lunsay)

 

Tagnaan ta na ba lunsay kaam siga ba malumbay

(Let’s start the lunsay, you who are kind and considerate)

 

Lamilami na ba nagnah kaam jama dambilah.

(Let’s start the fun, you people from the other side of the community.)

Through a transition movement, the leader of a lunsay session may initiate the end of tugilah after an indefinite time of enjoyable group dancing. The first pattern of transition footwork consists of right foot stepping forward followed by a left foot swing, then left foot is placed backward and right foot closes to left foot.

Once the transition movement is established after several repetitions, the dancers sing the tinggayon 1 or slow step 1, composed of four phrases. The dancers move in a counterclockwise direction through footwork that rises to a frenetic pace: stomp right foot sideward and close left foot to right foot. Then left foot stomps backward behind right foot and right foot steps close to left foot. The song that accompanies the dancing starts with a slow rhythm:

Tinggayon tinggayon doh battis pinaguyon doh

(Let’s do the slow step and let’s synchronize our steps)

 

Kaam takka bahau paantan nakam pitu.

(Those who just arrived, come hold our hands …)

The steps lead to a rising momentum until the leader ends the tinggayon with the second pattern of transition dance steps: left foot step forward with right foot swing; then right foot is placed behind and left foot closes to right foot.

The third part of lunsay is nilabos, meaning “to heighten performance,” and composed of four phrases starting in slow rhythm. Footwork is in clockwise direction, accelerating from a slow pace: left foot sideward step, right foot crosses over left, and left foot closes to right foot. Again, the leader ends nilabos by initiating a transitional movement.

The fourth melodic pattern is halin taroh, which means “change the tune.” This part has 12 phrases sung in fast tempo as dancers move counterclockwise stomping right foot sideward, followed by left foot closing to right foot. The simple but vigorous footwork builds up to a climax that leads to the second transition movement.

Halin taroh ba tunis na kaam siga gambina

(Let us change the tune, you beautiful ladies)

 

Tattoh pakiyukiyum na

(Let us laugh and smile)

 

Mangkin ba sinaglitan na.

(Especially when you are praised)

The fifth part is palabu-labu, meaning “swaying back and forth.” This is also in a fast beat and in counterclockwise direction. The footwork creates the percussion with a pattern of step right foot sideward, stomp left foot close to right foot with bent knees. Then step left foot sideward and stomp the right foot twice close to the left foot with flexed knees. The singing and fast beat steps are repeated as many times as the performers please, until the leader does the second transition movement to lead to the next song.

The sixth part of lunsay is tinggayon 2 or slow step 2 with 10 phrases in slow beat in clockwise motion starting with left foot sideward followed by a right foot swing forward. Then the right foot steps backward ending with a close-point of left foot to right foot. The footwork is repeated over and over until the leader ends it by doing the first transition dance steps. The whole group follows. The seventh part, moleh, meaning “let’s go home,” is for the closing. The song has eight phrases in slow tempo. Dancers move clockwise by stepping left foot forward and right foot stomps close to left foot. Then right foot steps backward and left foot stomps close to right foot. The dance steps are repeated as many times until the community dancing succumbs to the slow down of energy leading to rest.

As a spontaneous communal song dance, performers wear everyday garments when they dance the lunsay. But during celebratory gatherings, performers wear traditional costumes. Girls and women may wear sablay or loose blouse with sawwal kantiu (loose pants) or patadjung (tubular skirt). When worn with a sawwal, the sablay may go with a siyag or sash. Boys and men may wear the badjuh-lapi or the collarless tailored jacket with the sawwal kantiu.

In the 21st century, obvious changes in the lunsay are demonstrated by the different melodies, and the mixing of male and female in the circular and spiral formations. Such changes are brought about by modernization, lack of proper transmission from the elders who still know the song dance, and the incursion of Malaysian culture. Cultural workers of Tawi-Tawi are aware of the need to preserve traditional art forms like the lunsay because of Mapun’s propensity—due to its proximity to Sabah—to be taken over by Malaysian culture. Sabah is greatly acculturated by contemporary Malaysian culture, though the contested oil-rich territory is still considered to be under Philippine sovereignty.

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
A martial dance is a sporting dance of combative nature, ranging from unarmed execution to armed stylized confrontation. It is a mimetic dance when enacting a battle to assure an actual victory. Warriors may enter a trance or hypnotic state to give themselves courage and determination.

Sometimes, a dancer may be armed with shields, bows and arrows, swords, or sticks that ward off evil spirits and assist in ritual dances. Sword dances are related to fertility dances.

 

Philippine martial dances—war, combat, or mock-duel dancing—exhibit mainly a Malay influence and use skillful hand movements to exhibit strength and flexibility. The tradition of martial dances continued during the Spanish colonial period but took on a religious nature.

Ayu-ayu is an Aeta duel dance from Zambales. The dancers use bolos or bows and arrows in imitative combat. They tie an imaginary captive to a tree and attack him with their weapons while shouting and cheering. Similarly, in the sumbali, the Aeta chant and sing while brandishing their arms.

From the mountain region of Cordillera Central, there are the Bontoc war dances. The pattong or Bontoc war dance is a mock-combat dance characterized by the brandishing of head axes and spears and the clashing of shields. After an advance and retreat, chase and hiding, the dance may end with a dramatized killing. The takiling is a victory dance of the headhunting Kalinga. The minger (the head-chopping warriors) are crowned with lawi (feathered headdresses) to the beating of the gangsa (gongs) played by the bodan (nonhead choppers). The kayaw is a headhunting expedition of the Kalinga, before which they perform a ritual called mangayan to consult the idaw, a bird of omens. They also consult the mandadawak or shaman who performs a ritual over a plate; insects on the plate indicate the number of heads that may be taken.

 

In the south, the binanog is a mock-war dance of the Agusanon Manobo. The warriors mimic combat with an imaginary foe, or play the hero by killing a big banog (hawk) to protect a troubled mother hen and her chicks. In the saot (dance) of the Mandaya, the warrior displays his kasan (spear) or kampilan (scimitar) to the beating of the gimbal (drum) and agong. In sayaw kailawan, the Tiruray of Cotabato strike their swords and shields, and at the end one of them pretends to die. In sayaw sa bulawi (dance of rivalry), two men armed with swords and shields dance around a coveted lady. She evades their encounters until she is taken by one of the men.

Martial dancing among the Muslims of Mindanao reflects the influence of the neighboring Southeast Asian nations. Kuntaw, from Malay “kuntau” or fist, and berkuntau, meaning to box, uses bare hands. Its name also connotes the Chinese koon tao. Langka kuntaw among the Tausug and Sama combines precise and forceful arm gestures with jumps, kicks, and deep knee bends. Martial dancing is one of the artistic styles of the Martial Arts and Self-Defense Organization in Southeast Asia known as Pensak Silat. Langka pensak and langka budjang share the slow, sustained, and graceful arm movements that stimulate and stylize a fight. The langka silat, in particular, is similar to an ancient martial art called bersilat in Sumatra during the Melaka Sultanate. The Sama Dilaut magsangkil uses a sangkil or spear and a fist-shaped taming or shield.

The sagayan is a well-known war dance among the Maranao and Maguindanao. It depicts the warrior hero Prince Bantugan in the epic Darangen preparing for combat to defend his sweetheart, Princess Gandingan. The dancer fights an imaginary opponent forcefully and gracefully showing his skill in handling the kampilan or kris and a shield.

The baile de cristianos y moros is performed by two groups of masalayao or male dancers, one dressed as Christians and the other as Moors, and is characterized by excessive shouting, jumping, leaping, and other disorderly gestures and movements. The kinampilan (armed with bladed weapon) is a basic step of the sinug of Cebu, a precolonial war dance which is the precursor of the sinulog. Akin to the kinampilan is the patadpatad performed by armed men who make harmonious sounds by stamping their feet, and are accompanied by either a bell struck with little sticks called hotatac or tatak, or the drum called karatong.

The maglalatik from Zapote and Loma of Biñan, Laguna, is a Christian mock-war dance depicting the fight between Moors and Christians over the latik (condensed coconut milk). It is also known as magbabao because shallow halved coconut shells are tied to the various parts of the body of male dancers and struck with handheld shells to produce sharp rhythmic sounds. The first half of the four-part dance shows a heated encounter between the protagonists; the last shows their reconciliation. The dance is performed during the feast of San Isidro Labrador, during an evening procession, or in front of houses during the day in exchange for gifts, including money.

Palo-palo is another mock-duel dance and is related to the choreographed fighting between Moors and Christians, using sticks as arms. The binabayani from Masinloc, Zambales (not to be mistaken with the Aeta binabayani), enacts the fight between natives and Malay immigrants. Today, it is performed to celebrate a fiesta or to ensure a good harvest. Written by Larry A. Gabao and Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz
