text:
Ritual dancing is dancing directed by a shaman and the supplicants to spiritual beings and gods: to ask for blessings for the newly born, the newly baptized, the newlywed, and the dead; to pray for good health, a bountiful harvest, and victory in war; to thank the gods for blessings received or favors granted.

The gods and divinities are as varied as the rituals. An other-worldly being called anito is honored by certain animist groups with drinking, dancing, and singing. The term diwata (guardian spirit/goddess), may have come from the Hindi-Sanskrit word devata, referring to a goddess or good spirit. The polytheist Ifugao have countless bagales or deities, some of whom are Kabunyan, the Supreme Being, and Manilonda, their ancestors. Other groups have their own set of numerous divinities, for each of whom they perform different rites.

 

Leading the ritual activities is the shaman, who is known by various names, depending on the indigenous group: babaylan or baylan, balyan, catalonan, katalman, walian, marayawan, manibunong, mambunong, mumbuni, mumbaki, mandadawak, manalisig, pari, albularyo, erbularyo, maningbulong, manugtambal, manggagamot, or imam. Male or female, the shaman acts as medium between the people and the spirits, going into a trance as the spirits being supplicated take possession of them in order to partake of the ritual offerings. The ritual itself is known by various names: pag-ampo (Visayan); anituan (Aeta); anito baylan (Mandaya); diwata, pagdiwata, inim, karatong (Tagbanwa); mag-anito (Tagalog); marayaw (Mangyan); and palinawa or dawak (Kalinga). The dances in the rituals are usually performed principally by the shaman who goes into a trance. Sometimes the people themselves dance as part of the ritual.

The Ifugao have the following rituals with dances: the dinuy-a, a festival to thank the gods for a good harvest; the bumajah, a medium-sized ritual of thanksgiving with much dancing; and the uyaoy/uyaoya, which is a dance to ask the gods for good fortune, a bountiful harvest, and to bless a wedding. There is also much food, dancing, music, and singing of the Hudhud at night. The uyaoy for wealthy people may use gongs. Bunilbaki is a rice festival, with prayer, animal sacrifice, and vigorous dancing. It is for illness, thanksgiving, and well-being, and is led by mumbaki priests. The Kalinga palinawa is a dance of the mandadawak or priestess who uses a china bowl to catch floating hair in the air, after someone has died tragically, whose strands she then puts on the heads of the bereaved. Another death ritual practiced by the Kalinga is the bikbik-sagsag, a ritual performed only by women and the mandadawak with burning branches to drive the spirit of the dead into the world beyond. Other Kalinga dance rituals are the dawak, sis-siwa, and sapoy. The dalidog bids farewell to dead warriors. The Kalinga gabook is a ritual dance performed to welcome a newborn baby, especially a boy.

 

Among the Itneg, the ritual of supplication is the daing. One of several Tinguian daing rites performed by several men and led by a mandadawak asks for rain. A pig is carried around a dry field, its ears occasionally touched with burning straws; its cry is believed to reach the gods. The pig is later sacrificed. Prayers supplicated are celebrated in the palook, a thanksgiving dance for a good harvest. The Benguet tayaw is a sacrificial rite where a mambunong or priestess of Kabunyan leads people in offering pigs to the gods.

In the Aeta amba, men circle the sick, shout, run, walk, and threaten malevolent spirits so they will leave. In the anituan, another Aeta healing ritual, several shamans encourage and later threaten the spirits so they will leave the patient, who is covered with a red cloth.

Practiced among the southern communities are several rituals with dance component. The Bukidnon dugso is a dance performed at harvest time, upon the birth of a male heir, or in supplication. The inahaw is a dance offering by the Bukidnon where females move around a sacred fire. An example of a work-a-day ritual is the Bukidnon tadag where a babaylan requests permission from nature spirits to clear the woods.

The Bagobo gin-um requires human sacrifice to satisfy the god of life and death and other deities. But it is also performed for thanksgiving when the rice granaries are full, after victory in battle, as well as for driving away evil spirits, and asking for wealth. The Bagobo pamalugu is a ritual bath in the river where dancers are sprinkled with water by a priestess. The Mansaka munsayaw is a ceremony presided over by a man disguised as a female shaman to attract the diwata. The Talaingod baboy is a dance performed by a village shaman using a sacrificial pig.

Among the Manobo are the sinuyad, a ritual where the diwata heals the sick through a dancing priestess, and the sinundo/sinungga, a dance exorcism of a disease-bearing evil spirit. The sinaliling is a ritual where a baylan requests a spirit to transfer the disease of a person to the sacrificial chicken and some eggs. The say-am is a major feast where a priestess communicates with the spirits. The manganito is a ceremonial element of this ritual. The dalidog is for warriors who feel protected by the bloodthirsty war god Tagbusaw. Captured enemies are sacrificed. Today, the dance is a sublimation of the bloody rite.

The Tagbanwa runsay, where offerings are placed on a raft and sent on the ocean to the deities of the sea, is done every third night after the last full moon of the year, by a medium and other participants. The tarek is like the tugatak, karatong, and tegupat, and is a dance of the babaylan or priestess. The diwata/pagdiwata is an important ritual, led by a priestess who calls on the great spirit, Magindusa. It involves dances, chants, music, and healing sequences. Another Tagbanwa ritual is the inim, a sequence in the pagdiwata wherein the priestess drinks tabad (rice wine) after the spirits have “drunk.” Public dancing follows.

The Subanon practice the bolang-bolang, a sacrificial rite where participants move around a pole in supplication; the lapal, a ritual where a medium asks for permission to make a forest clearing; the binua-bua, a shaman dance and rite performed for barren women; and the buklog, the most important ritual of the Subanon, which is celebrated to give thanks for a good harvest, to celebrate shared prosperity, or to deflect illness or misfortune. In this elaborate ritual, a whole community dances in a circle around a pole that is pounded against a mortar below a high suspended floor on which everyone congregates and dances. Food and wine are offered to and shared with, the spirits, accompanied by incantations from the shaman. The communal dance progresses counterclockwise, the dancers stepping sideways, and over and under the right foot, assuming a very celebratory mood which contrasts with the serious mien of the babaylan. In the Mandaya tradition, the anito baylan has a female shaman in a trance chanting and shuffling around the sick, trying to contact the Mandaya environmental gods, whose presence is induced by the dancing, gong and drum playing, and chanting. The same ritual is practiced among the Mansaka where a male shaman leads the sacrifice of a chicken and uses a human skull. Later, young female onlookers dance.

Intriguing ritual dances are performed with piety and earnestness in the Sulu Archipelago. Magjuwata from South Ubian, Tawi-Tawi drives away spirits that cause illness; likewise the Sama Dilaut pagjinn held during the full moon, magpugot from Musu, and magsalba from Bulikulul, both in Siasi. Female participants wear the traditional garments consisting of the sablay (loose blouse with long sleeves) and patadjung (wrap-around skirt) or a sawwal kantiu (loose trousers). The latter is for men and women. Male performers may wear a badju (loose skirt) and a pis (headkerchief) as desired. The ritual dance is believed to appease the spirits called apo-jin. It also prays for a good catch, easy childbirth, long life, peaceful death, or a happy trip to heaven.

There are also ritual dances of Hispanic influence. The sayaw sa obando of Bulacan features men and women dancing on the streets during the procession of the images of Santa Clara, San Pascual Baylon, and the Nuestra Señora de Salambao either to ask for children, husbands, or wives. The turumba sa Birhen of Laguna is a procession by devotees dancing to petition or thank the Virgin for diverse reasons, among them relief for the sick. In the sanghiyang of Cavite, performers walk over live coals after a series of prayers. The sinulog, also referred to as sinug or sinurog, is regarded as the premier folk religious dance in the Visayas. The Cebuano ohong-ohong is a festival dance performed in long formation, and accompanied by a song which may be sung by the audience. The gapnod is a worship dance of Sibulan, Negros Oriental which begins with a reenactment and celebration of the discovery of the image of San Antonio de Padua, patron saint of Sibulan, by a fisherman, and ends with a fluvial procession along the coast. Written by Ramon A. Obusan, with notes from Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa

text:
Sagayan is a war dance of the Maguindanao and the Maranao danced predominantly by male performers. The dance traces its origins to the Darangen epic as a ritual in preparation for battle performed by the epic hero Bantugan. It portrays the ways in which Bantugan wears his battle gears and weapons. The Maranao consider it a royal dance because it dramatizes Bantugan’s preparation to rescue his sister Lawanen in an episode in the epic called Kalid a Dempas. Bantugan puts on his headgear called kapasiti or kapasti which is decorated with mirrors. Then he slips into his rainbow-colored attire. He tries out his klung or klong, a shield carved from hardwood attached with bells. He holds his shining kampilan or double-edged sword and moves gracefully by turning and going from side to side. The epic hero recites prayers invoking the help of guardian spirits with each move. During the conduct of the war, Bantugan cannot see his enemies but is guided only by the rattling sound of their klung.

Emulating the heroism of Bantugan, the Maguindanao and the Maranao consider this dance a testament to their honor, nobility, and bravery. Performers of the dance are also called sagayan who represent fierce warriors sporting the kampilan and colorful klung festooned with shells. On top of ankle-fitting pants, sagayan dancers wear a three-layered skirt of red, yellow, and green. Their kapasiti have decorations like flowers, mirrors, reflectors, tassels, and feathers. But the elaborate costume is perhaps a recent evolution since photos of Maguindanao warriors and sagayan dancers in the Spanish and American colonial periods show them wearing metal vests with skirts and less elaborate headgears decorated with traditional designs.

There are several sagayan variants with different social meanings ranging from secular performances to spiritual dancing. In the Maguindanaon kuyog or royal parade, sagayan serves as the opening ritual to drive away malevolent spirits and negative energies through the sword movements and noises from the klung’s shells. One ritualistic variant is called sambuyog a malna, performed in the kapagipat healing ritual to appease the source of the disease—either saitan (malignant spirits) or the tunong (ancestral spirits). This sagayan version uses graceful and definitive movements with spiritual meanings. It is performed by male and/or female shamans who move as if they were in a duel. They are believed to be possessed by the tunong in the Darangen epic, such as the souls of the rival siblings Balatamay Lumena and Alongan Pidsayana. The ritual dancing, accompanied with percussion music of the kulintang, also symbolizes the defeat of evil and the cleansing of the self and the environment.

 

 

Meanwhile, the more common Maguindanao variant associated with war dance is sagayan dalkat. The sagayan dancer must possess strength and flexibility to execute the combinations of jumps, turns, leaps, and butterfly kicks according to the energetic rhythm of kulintang or drums. He combines quick and forceful movements of the head, accompanied with fast hip jiggles and the forceful handling of the klung and the kampilan.

Among the Maranao, sagayan is a sacred ritual in preparation for a battle. The warrior or sagayan invokes protection from Allah against all kinds of harm after which he proceeds to sharpen his weapons and wear his multi-colored top, trousers, and skirt. He puts on his elaborate headgear and sits to meditate, sometimes checking on the sharpness of his kampilan on his own body until he fastens the sword oriented to the west. Incense burns in front of the warrior to put him in a trance. Then he rises and chants out loud, asking for guidance in the battle and seeking total surrender to Allah’s grace. description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
The salidsid, a courtship or wedding dance, originated from Tanudan, Southern Kalinga. It is usually performed by the bride and the groom. It is also performed during bodong/pudon or peace pact by all the members of the contracting tribes.

To the syncopated beat of the gangsa or gongs, the male dancer or the groom enters with running steps, holding up with both hands an allap, a woven cloth or wrap-around skirt. He waves the allap, a symbol of his affection, toward the female dancer or the bride, and thus begins the salidsid. The male dancer, wearing a colorful baal or loincloth and a headdress decorated with feathers, runs around the stage, sometimes even stamping his feet, and aggressively brandishes the allap to attract the woman’s attention or block her way. His movements simulate that of a rooster trying to attract a young hen.

At first, the female dancer, in her tapis or woven wrap-around skirt, with her own allap draped on her shoulder, and her hands on her gently swaying hips, shows disinterest and even tries to evade him by running away using smaller steps or the salidsid. But the series of female dodging is interspersed with flirtatious movements such as the forward tilting of her torso and the mild shaking of her chest. Soon, the dance reveals the mutual affection the pair of dancers has for each other.

 

 

To prolong this fast-paced dance, the male dancer could, at one point, temporarily refuse the woman’s affection by also running away from her. The dance ends when the female dancer places her allap on top of the one already draped on the male’s shoulder. He then folds them together—an act that symbolizes their union and his ability to protect his bride—and seals their love with a handshake. Written by Sarah Lumba

 

See also

Courtship and Wedding Dances

 

Source

Taguba, Remedios, and Carmen T. Andin, eds. 1994.Cordillera Ethnic Dances: A Manual forTeachers. Manila: National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

article_title: Sayaw Ed Tapew na Bangko/Sayaw sa Bangko
description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Sayaw sa bangko or sayaw ed tapew na bangko is a dance originating in Pangasinan performed by a barefoot couple, usually male and female and is done, as the name suggests, on top of a bench. An early documentation of the dance was done by Francisca Reyes-Aquino, in the locality of Pangapisan, Lingayen. The only prop needed is a well-built bench that has no backrest, commonly called a carpenter’s bench. The simple bench should be able to carry the weight of two dancers. It is quite narrow, measuring six to seven inches, and has an average length of two to three yards. Its elevation is about two feet but may vary depending on the height of the dancers. Originally, the girl dons a camisa (loose blouse) over a skirt with an extended tail whose tip is tucked at the waist to allow easy movement. The boy sports a camisa de chino (loose collarless shirt) over a pair of colored pants. Music is in 2/4 and 3/4 time.

The dance requires strength, agility, coordination, and balance. It begins with the girl standing at the right of the boy in front of the bench. When music begins, the male dancer mounts the bench and assists the female dancer who may hop or step up the bench. Partners assume a ballroom dance position and bow to the audience with a three-step turn in place. The performance has four figures with increasing difficulty in movement. In all figures, the girl and boy hold hands in various ways which is necessary to maintain balance and coordination between the partners.

 

The first figure consists of change steps with partners in a ballroom dance position moving through the length of the bench and turning clockwise to exchange places on the narrow surface. The second figure combines the coordinated hops, kicks, and jumps of the partners, exchanging places while executing these. Then they join palms of hands and perform an outward three-step turn. The third figure shows the fine footwork of the dance. The couple performs small change steps toward the end of the bench where partners carefully exchange places through small steps on the balls of the feet, which is necessary lest they fall off the narrow dancing area. The couple repeats this combination as they move to the other end of the bench. The fourth figure begins with change steps in preparation for exchanging places through playful hops. The combination is repeated to return to proper places. Then partners hold hands to alternately skip with each foot, swinging the elevated leg sideways in a lighthearted manner. For the final bow, girl and boy hold each other with inside hands, then make a three-step turn inward.

Sayaw sa bangko is a fun-filled dance usually performed by only one couple on one bench. Folk dance groups led by the Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company revised the choreography by adding more couples who rearrange many benches through the dance. Partners jump up and down through increasing levels of benches mounted on top of one another, reaching the height of four elevations. This version is replete with stunts to create suspense. The tall pyramid of benches is a big departure from the single bench in the rustic sayaw ed tapew na bangko. In the 2000s, the acrobatic version has become very popular and widely imitated by folk dance groups in the country and abroad. Tricks have been added, like using blindfolds on the dancer who will execute the jumps at the highest elevation to make the performance a daring and dangerous feat calculated to thrill spectators. A number of performers and critics, however, think that the addition of sensational tricks has turned the dance into something like a circus act. Written by Rosalie S. Matilac

 

See also

Folk Dance

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Singkil is the most famous dance of the Maranao ethnic group in Lanao del Sur. The word “singkil,” which means “hurdling,” is also the name of the dancer’s brass anklets and bells that clink while the dancer steps over a series of twin bamboo poles on the ground. The poles are rhythmically clapped together to produce a musical beat. The sound of the brass accessories helps the dancer to keep pace with the rhythm.

Singkil is perhaps the best example of a dance that has undergone great theatrical modifications since 1958, when it became a sensation at the Brussels Universal Exposition. At the time, the Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company presented an all-female version that highlighted a princess with a female attendant stepping in between clapping bamboo poles. The all-female version was first researched by Henrietta Hofer together with Lucrecia Urtula who was Bayanihan’s dance director in the mid-1950s. Their main informant was Princess Tarhata Alonto of Lanao who used to dance singkil with three fans held by each hand.

 

The overwhelming response to the dance made singkil the Bayanihan’s signature choreography, earning for the group airtime on American television and three months on Broadway. The success of singkil encouraged Bayanihan to alter the original presentation. In the 1959 Broadway performances, Bayanihan added a male dancer representing Bantugan, the hero in the epic Darangen, along with a male entourage. The inclusion of male dancers drew criticism from among the Maranao because, traditionally, male and female dancers are forbidden to dance together. In fact, in the traditional singkil, the bamboo poles are held by women because of this taboo. Moreover, some Maguindanaon disapproved of Bayanihan’s changes that gave no credit to the Maguindanao who claim to have a singkil version with a prince trying to woo a princess.

The origin of singkil is unclear. Even the tale of Princess Gandingan, heroine of the Darangen epic who is said to be the lead female character in singkil, has several versions. One story tells of an incident when several diwata (guardian spirits) played a trick on her. While walking through a forest, the diwata caused earth tremors that knocked down trees and rocks which were strewn along her path. The calm Gandingan just nimbly hopped to safety. The rapping of bamboo poles in singkil represents the upheaval caused by the earthquake. In the Bayanihan version, the diwata wanted to protect Princess Gandingan from Bantugan who was pursuing the princess. The diwata triggered an earthquake to obstruct Bantugan’s path.

The original singkil, so to speak, was documented by the Darangan Cultural Dance Troupe in 1963 during field research at Rumayas Maguing and Taluan in the town of Lumba a Bayabao, Lanao del Sur. There are four basic elements in the dance. First is the ksadoratan footwork which is a regal walk in a gliding manner through a careful changing of weight from right foot to left, accompanied by the slow turning of the head from right to left with downcast eyes or oblique glances. Second is the singkil footwork which consists of the steps used in going in between and outside the bamboo poles. Third element is the pause, done with weight on the right foot while the left foot is positioned in front. The fourth element is made up of fan manipulations by both right and left hand which accompany the ksadoratan footwork, the singkil steps, and the pause. The measure of a good dancer is on how she can combine beautiful ways to move the fans during each pause and while executing singkil and ksadoratan steps.

The field research at Rumayas Maguing and Taluan was able to document what is perhaps the closest to singkil’s primordial version, performed solo by a woman, and rarely, by two women. It only uses two bamboo poles placed parallel each other on the floor. The performance starts with the dancer seated on a chair, singing the bayok or love song with two fans held by each hand. She places the left hand, holding the open fans, at the waist level while the right hand sways the fans forward and backward. Then she moves the fans alternately with a figure of eight circling from the wrist. Next, her arms move to shoulder level, with fans facing downward parallel to floor at face level, followed by the movement of the fans in figure of eight. At the end of the bayok, the performer stands with fans held sideward at shoulder level and dances toward the bamboo poles using ksadoratan steps. Upon reaching the poles, the dancer drops two fans, retaining one fan held by each hand. Then she performs the singkil footwork while waving the fans in figure of eight, which may be executed from waist to shoulder level in sideward and forward directions. Singkil steps may be spontaneously done in several directions—diagonal, vertical, or circular. The dancer decides when to end and exit.

The second version of singkil, as documented in the 1963 field research, involves only a female dancer dancing with two fans, held with the left and the right hand. Twin poles, eight in all, are arranged in a quadrangle. The dancer performs ksadoratan steps while outside the poles and shifts to singkil steps to go in and out of the clapping poles. The pause is important before changing direction. During each pause, the dancer can move the fans in many ways—forward and backward, figure of eight, or wave-like movements up and down. She may change how the fans are held to position them perpendicular to the body. She may also do other variations like flipping the fans alternately. The dance ends when the performer is done passing through all the sides of the quadrangle using singkil and ksadoratan steps.

The third version documented in Lumba a Bayabao utilizes two twin poles that intersect at the middle, producing a square at the center of the cross formation. Two dancers hold fans with each hand using the thumb and index fingers. The dancers take opposite positions of the square at the center of the cross. Performance commences when both dancers do three stomps and a pause, repeated thrice. This is followed by singkil and ksadoratan steps through the clapping poles. They simultaneously execute fan techniques while stepping in and out of the crisscrossed poles. It is important that the two dancers improvise combinations of steps and fan techniques that are different from each other.

Bamboo poles used in the dance should be about seven feet long and two inches in diameter. Singkil may have no musical accompaniment but the clapping sound of bamboo in 4/4 time, complemented by the sound of stomping feet and tinkling anklets. It may also be performed with musical instruments like a kotiyapi (bamboo guitar), insi (bamboo flute), kobing (mouth harp), or tintikan (two small metal sticks). Female dancers wear a tubular skirt called malong over a fitted or loose blouse with either long or 3/4 sleeves. Each dancer carries at least one pair of accordion hand fans.

Three National Artists for dance imparted their individual interpretations of singkil. Lucrecia Urtula’s creation is described in the aforementioned Bayanihan version. Ramon Obusan’s choreography opens with a ritual and interprets it as a wedding dance. Meanwhile, Francisca Reyes-Aquino wrote that the dance has two versions, one for royal women and one for common folks. The version for royalty is performed strictly by aristocratic ladies featuring a princess with an assistant holding an ornamental umbrella. The singkil version for common folks is performed by male and female natives who do not belong to the nobility.

From the 1950s to the 2000s, the stylized singkil remained as one of the most iconic dances of the Philippines. It is an indispensable part of the Muslim Mindanao Suite performed by folk dance groups in the Philippines and abroad. Its elaborate production design is a favorite choice to showcase Philippine culture, as exemplified by Miss World title holder Megan Young, who danced singkil in the 2013 Miss World beauty pageant. The innumerable reinventions of singkil staged worldwide are devoid of the dance’s original context and meaning in Maranao culture. Nevertheless, it has become a symbol of Filipino identity and has given Filipinos who know little about the Philippine archipelago’s pre-colonial culture and history a sense of pride in cultural heritage. Written by Rosalie S. Matilac

The measure of a good dancer is on how she can combine beautiful ways to move the fans during each pause and while executing singkil and ksadoratan steps.

The field research at Rumayas Maguing and Taluan was able to document what is perhaps the closest to singkil’s primordial version, performed solo by a woman, and rarely, by two women. It only uses two bamboo poles placed parallel each other on the floor. The performance starts with the dancer seated on a chair, singing the bayok or love song with two fans held by each hand. She places the left hand, holding the open fans, at the waist level while the right hand sways the fans forward and backward. Then she moves the fans alternately with a figure of eight circling from the wrist. Next, her arms move to shoulder level, with fans facing downward parallel to floor at face level, followed by the movement of the fans in figure of eight. At the end of the bayok, the performer stands with fans held sideward at shoulder level and dances toward the bamboo poles using ksadoratan steps. Upon reaching the poles, the dancer drops two fans, retaining one fan held by each hand. Then she performs the singkil footwork while waving the fans in figure of eight, which may be executed from waist to shoulder level in sideward and forward directions. Singkil steps may be spontaneously done in several directions—diagonal, vertical, or circular. The dancer decides when to end and exit.

The second version of singkil, as documented in the 1963 field research, involves only a female dancer dancing with two fans, held with the left and the right hand. Twin poles, eight in all, are arranged in a quadrangle. The dancer performs ksadoratan steps while outside the poles and shifts to singkil steps to go in and out of the clapping poles. The pause is important before changing direction. During each pause, the dancer can move the fans in many ways—forward and backward, figure of eight, or wave-like movements up and down. She may change how the fans are held to position them perpendicular to the body. She may also do other variations like flipping the fans alternately. The dance ends when the performer is done passing through all the sides of the quadrangle using singkil and ksadoratan steps.

The third version documented in Lumba a Bayabao utilizes two twin poles that intersect at the middle, producing a square at the center of the cross formation. Two dancers hold fans with each hand using the thumb and index fingers. The dancers take opposite positions of the square at the center of the cross. Performance commences when both dancers do three stomps and a pause, repeated thrice. This is followed by singkil and ksadoratan steps through the clapping poles. They simultaneously execute fan techniques while stepping in and out of the crisscrossed poles. It is important that the two dancers improvise combinations of steps and fan techniques that are different from each other.

Bamboo poles used in the dance should be about seven feet long and two inches in diameter. Singkil may have no musical accompaniment but the clapping sound of bamboo in 4/4 time, complemented by the sound of stomping feet and tinkling anklets. It may also be performed with musical instruments like a kotiyapi (bamboo guitar), insi (bamboo flute), kobing (mouth harp), or tintikan (two small metal sticks). Female dancers wear a tubular skirt called malong over a fitted or loose blouse with either long or 3/4 sleeves. Each dancer carries at least one pair of accordion hand fans.

Three National Artists for dance imparted their individual interpretations of singkil. Lucrecia Urtula’s creation is described in the aforementioned Bayanihan version. Ramon Obusan’s choreography opens with a ritual and interprets it as a wedding dance. Meanwhile, Francisca Reyes-Aquino wrote that the dance has two versions, one for royal women and one for common folks. The version for royalty is performed strictly by aristocratic ladies featuring a princess with an assistant holding an ornamental umbrella. The singkil version for common folks is performed by male and female natives who do not belong to the nobility.

From the 1950s to the 2000s, the stylized singkil remained as one of the most iconic dances of the Philippines. It is an indispensable part of the Muslim Mindanao Suite performed by folk dance groups in the Philippines and abroad. Its elaborate production design is a favorite choice to showcase Philippine culture, as exemplified by Miss World title holder Megan Young, who danced singkil in the 2013 Miss World beauty pageant. The innumerable reinventions of singkil staged worldwide are devoid of the dance’s original context and meaning in Maranao culture. Nevertheless, it has become a symbol of Filipino identity and has given Filipinos who know little about the Philippine archipelago’s pre-colonial culture and history a sense of pride in cultural heritage.

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Social dancing is principally performed among ethnic or hispanized groups to celebrate the landmarks in the cycle of life, such as births, baptisms, and weddings; to mark harvests of rice or fish, victory in war, and in the case of Christian areas, the feasts of patron saints or the visit of important personages. Some of the earliest examples of social dances among the indigenous groups are the dinuy-a of the Ifugao and the among and palok of the Kalinga. With a droning, steady tempo provided by percussion instruments and the simplest of steps, these dances invite participation from the crowd.

The Mandaya of Davao Oriental dance the gimbaw at informal gatherings to the beat of a drum of the same name. On the island of Cagayan de Sulu, the Jama Mapun dance the lunsay, a community dance of varying tempo, from dusk to dawn. The Tagbanwa of Palawan dance the andardi on special occasions, a moderately paced dance with simple steps and repeated figures.

The Spaniards brought not only Christianity, but also the ballroom dances of Europe in the 16th century. Dances like the fandango, jota, and habanera were introduced by the colonizers, and adapted to local taste and conditions, with almost every region or town evolving their own versions of these dances. There are versions of the fandango in Ilocos Norte, the Visayas, and the Tagalog region. The jota can be batangueña, bicolana, cagayana, ilocana, Pangasinan. The mazurka can be boholana, de Jaen, or mindoreña. All these are danced during town fiestas and religious holidays, as well as in purely social gatherings such as weddings, baptisms, and birthdays.

 

 

Eventually, other European dances were introduced to the Philippines. Important social events occasioned the performances of such imports like the rigodon (France), the redova (Czechoslovakia), the polka (Bohemia and Czechoslovakia), the schottische (Germany), the ba-Ingles (England), and the lanceros (French and English, by way of America). These dances were brought over by visiting foreigners and returning Filipino students.

Although the lower classes were barred from social interactions with the Spaniards and mestizos during the Spanish colonial period, they nevertheless copied what they saw of the new dances and improvised the rest. The schottische became the escotis and the chotis, the polka became polka sa nayon or polka sala, and the fandango became pandanggo sa ilaw and pandanggo sa sambalilo. The lower classes also produced dances in the Spanish style and manner, but purely Filipino in character such as the balitaw, sinisiki, magkasuyo, karakal, maramyon, kuradang, magtipan, and kuratsa.

The American occupation, with its sweeping institutional changes, brought with it a new concept in social dancing. Social dance became its own reason for being and Filipinos absorbed the new dance forms with the same ease that they absorbed other American influences. Social dance in the Philippines has since closely followed American trends.

In the 1920s, Filipinos danced the charleston; during the 1930s, they did the jitterbug and some South American styles; by the 1940s and 1950s they were adept at the mambo, samba, and cha-cha. The 1950s also brought the boogie-woogie and countless rock ‘n’ roll styles. The 1960s saw the twist, frug, camel walk, shy tuna, aqua velva, escalator, shimmy, and boogaloo.

Recently, nationalism has renewed interest in traditional dance forms. Many dancers and choreographers now incorporate movements and Filipino traditions of social dance in modern choreography. Thus, jota and pandanggo movements have been incorporated in performances such as Alice Reyes’s Amada and Julie Borromeo’s Zagalas de Manila (Young Maidens of Manila). Written by David Bercades

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
A song dance is a dance performed to the lyrics of a song whose meaning is often acted out in gestures and other movements. The songs may describe a community’s history, character, and traditions. The Tagbanwa of Palawan dance the andardi, whose performers sing and dance to the beat of drums and other percussion instruments. Although a festival dance, the andardi is also performed to while away the dancer’s time. The lunsay is a song and dance of the Jama Mapun of Cagayan de Sulu aka Mapun Municipality. Similarly, the suasua (literally, a small orange or pomelo plant) is performed with a song. The dalling-dalling is a comic song dance popular in Sulu and Tawi-Tawi: in the song, the boy may say that he has no peace of mind while away from his love, and the girl may respond that her love will never change though they are miles away from each other.

Among the dances of the Tagalog is the abaruray, in which a man and woman act out a courtship. The Tagalog of Tayabas, Quezon perform the abaruray, sometimes called tagayan, hapayan, and pandanggo sa baso. Abaruray is a contraction of the words “aba” and “ruray.” Aba is “hey” or “hail” while Ruray is a nickname for Aurora. In this dance, a woman offers a drink to visitors to signal the beginning of dancing and singing. “Kaninong Anak Ito?” (Whose Child Is This?) is a song that is popular among children. The children carry a “‘baby,” whom they pretend to find lying beside an owl on the grass, and whose mother they look for later. The Tagalog lerion is performed in barrio Parang, Marikina to the tune of “Leron-Leron Sinta” (Leron-Leron My Beloved), while bahay kubo (nipa hut) is arranged for children who sing about a nipa hut with a garden full of edible plants like eggplants, beans, gourds, and peanuts. Paruparong bukid imitates the movements of the butterfly to whom the lady of the song is compared.

In the balitaw, popular among the Tagalog and Cebuano, dancers sing and mime the lyrics to the accompaniment of a guitar, harp, or flute. In the lyrics, the male offers his love to the female who wards off the attention being lavished upon her. If the dancer-singers are good, the balitaw may last several hours. The dancers stop only when one has outsung all the others.

The palmerito (“small hands”) of Janiuay, Iloilo is about a crab. The inday na kunday of Leyte is a courtship dance performed during social gatherings with a song accompaniment. The gayong-gayong of Aklan and Capiz tells about a man choking on a piece of adobo and asking for help to dislodge it from his throat. The pinggan-pinggan pino of Bohol, sung alternately by a boy and a girl, is a courtship dance in which the boy keeps a small saucer in his pocket as a gift to his loved one. The lawiswis kawayan, which describes the sound of bamboo leaves swaying in the wind, was popularized by the people of Samar and Leyte but is also performed in Davao by Visayan settlers. In Marinduque, the putong (“to crown”) is performed in honor of a special guest or a birthday celebrant. The singers sing the first part but dance the crowning portion of the song.

The people of Cagayan sing and dance the pintalatoo cu ta futu cao (“pondering within my heart”) to tell about a girl who refuses to accept a returning suitor. The Ilocano like to name their song dances after their loved ones. Examples are manang biday, rogelia in Pangasinan, sainita in Nueva Viscaya, and pastora, where a boy pleads and kneels before Pastora. In the basulto of Pampanga, one verse is usually danced and the next sung. A town inspired the sa banwa sang Buenavista of Bohol and Iloilo. It tells of two unmarried sisters from the town of Buenavista. When the youngest gets married, the eldest cries; the younger sister consoles the other with assurances that she will someday find her own husband. Written by Larry A. Gabao, with notes from Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Many Filipino folk dances have their roots in the Spanish jota, paso doble, fandango, verdiale, chotis, and sevillana. Spanish influence is strongest in urban or Creole dances, also known as bailes criollos de Filipinas or bailes de cabecera (big-town dances), less in the bailes de sementera (rural folk dances), and least in the bailes de la montaña (mountain dances).

Introduced in the 16th century, Spanish dances became models of local choreographic inspiration among Filipinos. Cleric and lay missionaries, and families of bureaucrats, soldiers, and settler-traders introduced the basic steps, music, and forms of what later became Filipino folk dances. These choreographic concepts were assimilated by Filipinos and mixed with whatever dances they already had.

 

The pasakalye, an exhibition dance and song, was the first popular Spanish dance, and was integrated as the paso doble into the komedya’s dagger-and-sword fight sequences. Early dances were the sakuting, maglalatik, and calesa (later known as caleseras). Dances also depicted specific forms of the paseo, with the sombrillas (umbrellas), abanicos (fans), bastones (canes), mantillas (veils), mantones de Manila (shawls of Manila), and palillos (bamboo or stick castanets). These later flavored the scenes of love and courtship in the sarsuwela, the romantic comedy with songs and dances.

The most famous of the pasakalye (later paso doble) genre is the danza popular española, in the paso dobles toreros, such as españa cañi, currito de la cruz, alma andaluza, el relicario, and cielo andaluz. The españa cañi was and still is the representative Spanish dance. The chotis madrileño, complete with manton de Manila and paineta (comb) or pañoleta (shawl), and abanico (fan), became popular at the turn of the century in Manila, Iloilo, Vigan, and Zamboanga. The one-two-three step and beat of the chotis, and its grand-waltz steps gave way to the swagger of the colorful manton or the big abanico. Like the paso doble, the chotis madrileño that came with the traje de chula (which strongly influenced the ponyang traje de mestiza of the early 1900s) came to be loved by Filipinos, and eventually became bilingual, in Spanish and Tagalog/Visayan/Ilocano. Some examples are “El Paypay de Manila” and “Neneng” (a chotis balitaw). The most famous Spanish chotis are “El Pichi,” “La Mañuela,” “Manoletin,” “Monisima,” “Mantoncito de Manila,” “La Rosa de Madrid,” “Soy de Madrid,” and “Madrid, Madrid, Madrid” by Mexican composer Agustin Lara.

The Spanish waltz preceded the chotis and pasakalye (or paso doble). The waltz step is found in almost all Filipino folk dances, and in the common ballroom dances of Filipino fiestas, saraos, te danzantes, and tertulias literario-musicales held by the rich. At the turn of the century, the paso doble was replaced by the Argentine tango as the national Filipino ballroom dance. There were variations in Rudolf Valentino movies as well as the Manuel Quezon dance-step impositions. But the jota, sevillanas antiguas, navarras, and aragonesas persisted as danzas de exhibicion in fairs, verbenas (night festivals), and carnivals, and in grand mansions up to the early 1970s. The four-part sevillanas reached the Philippines in the 17th century. The sevillanas antiguas became a native Creole dance or danza criolla known as la jota sevillana de Panay.

 

 

Most of the danzas clasicas de España, danced to the compositions of Albeniz, De Falla, Granados, Ravel, Bizet, Tchaikovsky, and Mozart are based on the sevillanas. They have almost all the feet positions and figures of ballet, and may be group, solo, trio, or couple dances. They usually depict a particular era of Spanish art and dress, like that of the la epoca goyesca from the styles of Francisco Goya, or de la era isabelina from the times of Queen Isabella II de Bourbon and Kings Alfonso XII and XIII.

Antonia Merce (aka La Argentina) was a great Spanish dancer of the 1920s and 1930s. She came to Manila to perform at the Metropolitan Theater (then known as Teatro Cervantes) and introduced the danza clasica española. Her vast repertoire of Spanish folk, classic, and popular dances included Filipino dances such as the cariñosa, binasuan, and the local pandanggo. Merce was the first to introduce Filipino dance, then considered part of the Spanish and Latin American dance repertoire, to the outside world.

She met Rosa G. Jimenez Rivera of Iloilo, with whom she exchanged dances. Jimenez Rivera was born in the late 1880s in Iloilo, a child of Spanish parents from Seville, where she was known as “La Filipina.” As a child, she lived in Spain where she went on to become a professional Spanish dancer and teacher. Most information on Spanish dance in the Philippines at the turn of the century comes from her. Jimenez Rivera also danced native dances such as the singkil and other Muslim dances, passing them on to Merce. She also performed Ifugao and Tinguian dances, and used the Spanish zapateado to measure the primitive steps and movements.

After Merce’s visit, Spanish dance enjoyed a brilliant resurgence in Manolo Rosado, Manila’s great Spanish dancer, and several Filipinos who became local exponents of the dance, until the outbreak of World War II. Rosado danced from 1953 to 1955 with the Spanish Ballet of Marinela de Montijo in Europe, and in 1956 with the company of Magda Briones in Mexico. article.value: Many Filipino folk dances have their roots in the Spanish jota, paso doble, fandango, verdiale, chotis, and sevillana. Spanish influence is strongest in urban or Creole dances, also known as bailes criollos de Filipinas or bailes de cabecera (big-town dances), less in the bailes de sementera (rural folk dances), and least in the bailes de la montaña (mountain dances).

Introduced in the 16th century, Spanish dances became models of local choreographic inspiration among Filipinos. Cleric and lay missionaries, and families of bureaucrats, soldiers, and settler-traders introduced the basic steps, music, and forms of what later became Filipino folk dances. These choreographic concepts were assimilated by Filipinos and mixed with whatever dances they already had.

The pasakalye, an exhibition dance and song, was the first popular Spanish dance, and was integrated as the paso doble into the komedya’s dagger-and-sword fight sequences. Early dances were the sakuting, maglalatik, and calesa (later known as caleseras). Dances also depicted specific forms of the paseo, with the sombrillas (umbrellas), abanicos (fans), bastones (canes), mantillas (veils), mantones de Manila (shawls of Manila), and palillos (bamboo or stick castanets). These later flavored the scenes of love and courtship in the sarsuwela, the romantic comedy with songs and dances.

The most famous of the pasakalye (later paso doble) genre is the danza popular española, in the paso dobles toreros, such as españa cañi, currito de la cruz, alma andaluza, el relicario, and cielo andaluz. The españa cañi was and still is the representative Spanish dance. The chotis madrileño, complete with manton de Manila and paineta (comb) or pañoleta (shawl), and abanico (fan), became popular at the turn of the century in Manila, Iloilo, Vigan, and Zamboanga. The one-two-three step and beat of the chotis, and its grand-waltz steps gave way to the swagger of the colorful manton or the big abanico. Like the paso doble, the chotis madrileño that came with the traje de chula (which strongly influenced the ponyang traje de mestiza of the early 1900s) came to be loved by Filipinos, and eventually became bilingual, in Spanish and Tagalog/Visayan/Ilocano. Some examples are “El Paypay de Manila” and “Neneng” (a chotis balitaw). The most famous Spanish chotis are “El Pichi,” “La Mañuela,” “Manoletin,” “Monisima,” “Mantoncito de Manila,” “La Rosa de Madrid,” “Soy de Madrid,” and “Madrid, Madrid, Madrid” by Mexican composer Agustin Lara.

The Spanish waltz preceded the chotis and pasakalye (or paso doble). The waltz step is found in almost all Filipino folk dances, and in the common ballroom dances of Filipino fiestas, saraos, te danzantes, and tertulias literario-musicales held by the rich. At the turn of the century, the paso doble was replaced by the Argentine tango as the national Filipino ballroom dance. There were variations in Rudolf Valentino movies as well as the Manuel Quezon dance-step impositions. But the jota, sevillanas antiguas, navarras, and aragonesas persisted as danzas de exhibicion in fairs, verbenas (night festivals), and carnivals, and in grand mansions up to the early 1970s. The four-part sevillanas reached the Philippines in the 17th century. The sevillanas antiguas became a native Creole dance or danza criolla known as la jota sevillana de Panay.

Most of the danzas clasicas de España, danced to the compositions of Albeniz, De Falla, Granados, Ravel, Bizet, Tchaikovsky, and Mozart are based on the sevillanas. They have almost all the feet positions and figures of ballet, and may be group, solo, trio, or couple dances. They usually depict a particular era of Spanish art and dress, like that of the la epoca goyesca from the styles of Francisco Goya, or de la era isabelina from the times of Queen Isabella II de Bourbon and Kings Alfonso XII and XIII.

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Street dance is dancing executed by groups of performers as part of a religious procession or a secular parade, which courses through the streets of a town or city. Using the thoroughfare as a social spatial stream, participants of communal celebrations create group movements usually in unison and to the music of a brass band or other groups, while onlookers watch on both sides of the road.

In Philippine history, street dancing was a form of prayer, often in fulfilment of personal vows, performed as part of the daytime procession held on the feast of the town’s patron saint. The latter’s image was carried on andas or rode on an elaborately decorated float, followed by a brass band playing pandanggo or balitaw music. To this lively beat, devotees, usually women, danced together, forming two parallel lines in front of the patron’s karo. In Pakil, Laguna, the andas of the Birhen ng Turumba literally sways as the men carrying it dance to the refrain “Maria, Maria, Mariangga / Magsayaw tayo at magsaya / Sumayaw ng tuturumba / para sa Birheng Maria” (“Mary, Mary, sweet Mary / Let us dance and celebrate / And dance the turumba / For the Virgin Mary”). The procession begins from the church, winds through the principal streets of the town which are decorated with buntings and arches, and ends up in the church after several hours. Devotees from Laguna and nearby provinces join the procession, asking the Virgin for personal favors or thanking her for favors granted.

 

Far more elaborate is the street dancing in Angono, Rizal, specially prepared for the feast of the town’s patron saint, San Clemente. On Nov 23, the townspeople mount a procession that winds through Angono’s streets. Various contingents—students from local schools in balintawak costumes, organizations of fishermen, farmers, vendors in their trade attires, civic, religious, and government groups in their gala uniforms, among others—dance or play to the same beat, creating an overwhelming sound with their bakya (wooden clogs) and instruments. The procession also highlights families of dancing higantes (giants): huge figures of bamboo with heads which are dressed in male and female native attire. One person carries and manipulates the figure from the inside, so that it can sway, bow, jump, jog, and dance to any tune.

In Obando, Bulacan, devotees flock to join the procession in honor of the three patron saints—the Virgin of Salambao, Santa Clara, and San Pascual Bailon. In an orderly sequence, groups of women, sporting different colors of baro’t saya or terno, dance to the pandanggo melodies played by the brass band, brandishing anahaw fans or handkerchiefs. Joining them are devotees in civilian clothes who converge in Obando to dance and pray for a husband, a wife, or a child. After several hours, the procession returns to the church or the church patio, where devotees as one engage in almost an hour of frenetic dancing before the altar and the images of the three saints, reminiscent of the fevered dancing of babaylanes (native shamans) in a trance.

 

In many towns whose patron saint is Santiago Matamoros, a special street dance is performed to honor the saint. Sometimes called moros y cristianos, this dance dramatizes the conflict between the Christians and the Moors, with the Christians winning in the end, usually with the help of the patron saint. A version called kinabayo may be found in Dapitan, Zamboanga del Sur, which is also held in honor of Santiago Matamoros. A modest version called sayaw is performed on the streets of Ibajay, Aklan, but in honor of the Santo Niño.

The Ati-Atihan in Kalibo, Aklan, which is held in honor of the Santo Niño or Holy Child Jesus, is one of the oldest fiestas where street dancing is the main event, with participants stepping sad-sad style, a style attributed to the ancestral ati (aeta) of the Visayas, after whom the festival is named. To emulate the Ati and as part of a sacrifice, participants in the Ati-Atihan are required to rub soot on their faces, hands, torsos, and legs. Today, groups join the parade in groups, sporting fantastic costumes and performing their own choreographies to a beat that has become popular all over the country. Prizes are given out to the outstanding performers and costumes. At the same time the portrayal is allied to the supposed migration of the ten Bornean datus to the island of Panay and their acquisition of lands through barter with the aboriginal ati, after whom the feast is named.

 

In Cebu, the sinulog also venerates the Santo Niño and the conversion to Christianity in its street dancing. The image of the Holy Child in the basilica is supposed to have been the one brought by the Spanish fleet of Ferdinand Magellan in 1521. Not too long ago, this street dance imitated the indigenous Aeta, so that participants even painted themselves black. At present, this is no longer allowed by the organizers so that the dramatization of the Aeta and their shaman has now become subsidiary or been dispensed with. Now the official competitive dancing in the streets culminates in a contest among contingents in Cebu’s Sports Complex. Due to the national prominence of the sinulog, this kind of ending (and judging) has been observed by other places in Cebu Province in their versions of street dancing. Today many cities and provinces, including those in the Visayas and Mindanao, also compete in Cebu.

Dinagyang in Iloilo is influenced by both Cebu and Aklan. It began when Cebu gave an image of the Santo Niño to Iloilo City, thus also honoring the saint. Like in Aklan, the Dinagyang festival integrates the story of the barter in Panay between the native ati and the Bornean datu. But unlike in Cebu, the cast of Ati dominates in elaborate costuming and choreography but there is no culminative showdown on one stage, inasmuch as viewing and judging happen in various streets of the city.

The same prominence of indigenous people prevail in the Pintados, now renamed Kasadyaan, in Tacloban, Leyte. Also centering around the worship of the Santo Niño, this fairly new street dance celebration derives its main identity from the historical practice of tattooing among the Visayans, a process mistaken as body-painting by the Spaniards. It has also spawned various modes of representing Leyte. Versions of the pintados have also won prizes in the sinulog competition in Cebu.

In recent decades, street dancing has also been featured in festivals which are secular in nature, organized for one or more of the following reasons: to promote the main economic product of a place, to instill pride of place and regional identity, to underscore tribal unity and identity, and even to promote corporate interests. These festivals are usually characterized by elaborate costumes, movements that may use or reinterpret the traditional dances, and fierce competition among participants. Many have become the focus of local and even national tourism.

Since 1996, the Baguio Flower Festival, also known as the Panagbenga (a Kankanaey term meaning “season of blossoming”) has been attracting tourists to its February events, which does not only highlight Baguio’s flower industry and Cordillera culture but also advocates respect for and protection of the environment. The festival includes a street display of artworks inspired by flowers, local and national landscaping competitions, open-air markets selling Baguio’s flowers, boating competitions, horse-riding activities, flea markets, and flower-related school activities. But the climax of the festival is the parade, in which local dance groups wear fantastic outfits depicting flowers, bees, and birds, as well as traditional Ibaloy costumes or modern interpretations thereof. Invariably, Ibaloy-themed groups showcase dances that feature gangsa music among the boys and the banga or pot dance among the girls. Big floats, funded by civic and business groups, schools, and government agencies, depict lush gardens or native houses or topiaries representing huge swans or bees, all covered in fresh Baguio flowers.

Another new and invented street dance is the Masskara in Bacolod. The festival was supposed to have been created to comfort the people of Negros Occidental after the fall of their sugar industry. This has grown to be an elaborate and colorful street dancing event, characterized by the donning of various styles of masks. Unlike the masks or make-up in ati-atihan and dinagyang, these are not always meant to represent the aeta. There is a lot of inventiveness in designing these masks, including those sold to the bystanders as souvenirs. Participants move to the rhythm of Latin beats. The basic theme is merry-making of the people.

An interesting adaptation and transformation of the sinulog style is found in Camiguin Island. To highlight its agricultural produce, Camiguin stages a Lanzones Festival. It parallels Cebu’s dual formats, namely, the street dancing, and later, the showdown which also adopts Cebu’s triptych staging style: a central group is framed by two at the sides that all converge at the end. But where the Santo Niño is central in Cebu, in Camiguin it is the branch of the lanzones that is waved by dancers during the parade. The lanzones are threatened by people in bat costumes, which are equivalent to the unconverted masses in the Cebu sinulog.

In the south, Tawi-Tawi Island stages the Agal-Agal Festival every year to commemorate its founding as a province separate from Sulu. The main event of the festival is the street dancing which aims to conserve and promote the cultural heritage of the peoples of Tawi-Tawi, especially through its dance and music. The special focus of these efforts are the dances unique to the Sama Badjao, the Jama Mapun, and the Tausug, namely, the pangalay/igal, the kuntaw, and the linggisan. Floats, which are assembled on motor vehicles, represent the lepa and other types of boats in the Tawi-Tawi area. While the aims of the festival are commendable and participation in the festival among the youth has been enthusiastic, the dancing has tended to mimic the ati-atihan in terms of musical rhythm and movements, even as the costumes tend to adopt cuts and colors that are not representative of the groups of Tawi-Tawi. Upon the advice of pangalay/igal scholar and performer Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa, festival organizers are seeking to counter this tendency, in order to project what is truly unique to Tawi-Tawi in terms of dance, music, and costumes.

Proceeding from Manila’s Luneta Park to Pasay City, the Aliwan street dancing competition sponsored by a broadcasting company has aspired to be national. It draws noted winners in sinulog, dinagyang, and many other festivals from the north and south of the country, from provinces with Christian, Muslim, and lumad (indigenous folk) population. It has added categories for floats and beauty contests, which are given the biggest prizes. Whereas entertainment personalities and national politicians’ presence are highlighted in Cebu, in Pasay the proceedings during Aliwan are further sustained by interspersed live and broadcasted segments during entrances of contingents. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz and Nicanor G. Tiongson

But unlike in Cebu, the cast of Ati dominates in elaborate costuming and choreography but there is no culminative showdown on one stage, inasmuch as viewing and judging happen in various streets of the city.

The same prominence of indigenous people prevail in the Pintados, now renamed Kasadyaan, in Tacloban, Leyte. Also centering around the worship of the Santo Niño, this fairly new street dance celebration derives its main identity from the historical practice of tattooing among the Visayans, a process mistaken as body-painting by the Spaniards. It has also spawned various modes of representing Leyte. Versions of the pintados have also won prizes in the sinulog competition in Cebu.

In recent decades, street dancing has also been featured in festivals which are secular in nature, organized for one or more of the following reasons: to promote the main economic product of a place, to instill pride of place and regional identity, to underscore tribal unity and identity, and even to promote corporate interests. These festivals are usually characterized by elaborate costumes, movements that may use or reinterpret the traditional dances, and fierce competition among participants. Many have become the focus of local and even national tourism.

Since 1996, the Baguio Flower Festival, also known as the Panagbenga (a Kankanaey term meaning “season of blossoming”) has been attracting tourists to its February events, which does not only highlight Baguio’s flower industry and Cordillera culture but also advocates respect for and protection of the environment. The festival includes a street display of artworks inspired by flowers, local and national landscaping competitions, open-air markets selling Baguio’s flowers, boating competitions, horse-riding activities, flea markets, and flower-related school activities. But the climax of the festival is the parade, in which local dance groups wear fantastic outfits depicting flowers, bees, and birds, as well as traditional Ibaloy costumes or modern interpretations thereof. Invariably, Ibaloy-themed groups showcase dances that feature gangsa music among the boys and the banga or pot dance among the girls. Big floats, funded by civic and business groups, schools, and government agencies, depict lush gardens or native houses or topiaries representing huge swans or bees, all covered in fresh Baguio flowers.

Another new and invented street dance is the Masskara in Bacolod. The festival was supposed to have been created to comfort the people of Negros Occidental after the fall of their sugar industry. This has grown to be an elaborate and colorful street dancing event, characterized by the donning of various styles of masks. Unlike the masks or make-up in ati-atihan and dinagyang, these are not always meant to represent the aeta. There is a lot of inventiveness in designing these masks, including those sold to the bystanders as souvenirs. Participants move to the rhythm of Latin beats. The basic theme is merry-making of the people.

An interesting adaptation and transformation of the sinulog style is found in Camiguin Island. To highlight its agricultural produce, Camiguin stages a Lanzones Festival. It parallels Cebu’s dual formats, namely, the street dancing, and later, the showdown which also adopts Cebu’s triptych staging style: a central group is framed by two at the sides that all converge at the end. But where the Santo Niño is central in Cebu, in Camiguin it is the branch of the lanzones that is waved by dancers during the parade. The lanzones are threatened by people in bat costumes, which are equivalent to the unconverted masses in the Cebu sinulog.

In the south, Tawi-Tawi Island stages the Agal-Agal Festival every year to commemorate its founding as a province separate from Sulu. The main event of the festival is the street dancing which aims to conserve and promote the cultural heritage of the peoples of Tawi-Tawi, especially through its dance and music. The special focus of these efforts are the dances unique to the Sama Badjao, the Jama Mapun, and the Tausug, namely, the pangalay/igal, the kuntaw, and the linggisan. Floats, which are assembled on motor vehicles, represent the lepa and other types of boats in the Tawi-Tawi area. While the aims of the festival are commendable and participation in the festival among the youth has been enthusiastic, the dancing has tended to mimic the ati-atihan in terms of musical rhythm and movements, even as the costumes tend to adopt cuts and colors that are not representative of the groups of Tawi-Tawi. Upon the advice of pangalay/igal scholar and performer Ligaya Fernando Amilbangsa, festival organizers are seeking to counter this tendency, in order to project what is truly unique to Tawi-Tawi in terms of dance, music, and costumes.

Proceeding from Manila’s Luneta Park to Pasay City, the Aliwan street dancing competition sponsored by a broadcasting company has aspired to be national. It draws noted winners in sinulog, dinagyang, and many other festivals from the north and south of the country, from provinces with Christian, Muslim, and lumad (indigenous folk) population. It has added categories for floats and beauty contests, which are given the biggest prizes. Whereas entertainment personalities and national politicians’ presence are highlighted in Cebu, in Pasay the proceedings during Aliwan are further sustained by interspersed live and broadcasted segments during entrances of contingents.

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Subli is a religious devotional practice which involves dance, song, prayer, instrumental music, and feasting. It is performed in honor of the Mahal na Poong Santa Cruz, a large cross of anubing wood with the face of the silver sun at its center. The icon was allegedly discovered in the early decades of Spanish rule in what is now the town of Alitagtag, Batangas. It has since been honored as the patron of many towns in the area, notably the ancient town of Bauan, Batangas. The performance of this devotion usually happens around the first week of May, in celebration of the feast day of the Exaltation of the Holy Cross, whose feast day falls on May 3. In towns tracing their origins to Bauan, such as Alitagtag, Santa Teresita, San Pascual, and Agoncillo, the subli consists of a long sequence of performances and entertainment in varied forms and styles called laro by its practitioners. The practice fulfills the function of the panata which, in many Philippine communities, is a ritual transaction between individuals or groups in a community seeking favor from a deity in exchange for lifelong devotion.

The subli verses recount the first journey of the early manunubli (subli performers) through the fields, hills, and rivers of Batangas in search of the miraculous cross and their forging of a panata with the icon. Sections of verse are sung to a fixed punto or skeletal melody, which may be elaborated on in different ways by different subli troupes. About five of these punto are used in a complete subli performance. These sections may be divided further into various fixed dance patterns involving one, two or eight pairs of men and women. These numbers seem to be the norm in Bauan, although other towns like Agoncillo may have formations involving three pairs at a time.

 

The stances, gestures, and movements of the male dancers are freewheeling and dramatic, consisting of leaping, striking the ground with kalaste (wooden bamboo clappers held in both hands), and other movements suggesting the martial arts. The women circle on half-toe, performing the talik (small refined gestures with wrists and fingers), their fingers superficially touching or appearing to touch their small-brimmed hats and alampay (triangular scarf worn loosely over the shoulder) which are the essential parts of their costume. They dance and sing to the rhythm beaten out by a stick on the tugtugan, a goblet-shaped and footed drum of langka wood with mouth covered with iguana skin. In the different barangay associated with Batangas City, the subli dance is also performed but it is a less elaborate affair, without the intricacies of the practice of Bauan. It is usually appended to the Maytime Alay or Santacruzan celebrations and is not associated with the panata. As a result, the songs and prayers are not found in Batangas City practice and the performances are more playful and associated with courtship and other more secular and even erotic concerns.

In 1988, in celebration of Batangas City Foundation Day, the Cultural Affairs Board of Batangas City launched an annual Sublian Festival that has survived until today. School and community groups from the city and its surrounding towns were encouraged to learn the dances, songs, and prayers from the traditional manunubli and perform 10-minute excerpts in competition. This has led to a revival of interest in the devotion and the training of another generation of subli practitioners. Written by Elena Rivera Mirano

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Surtido means “assortment” and refers to dances which are an assembly of steps generic to a region or from the different regions of the Philippines. The surtido becomes interesting because of the unpredictable shift of steps and rhythms. One of these steps is the haplik, a lively 16-measure combination of hops and three-step turns. The combination of typical melodic airs also heightens the attraction of the dance.

The documented surtido dances are from the Ilocos, Bicol, and the Visayas, and combines steps from these and the Tagalog regions. The 10-figure surtido from Bicol has a corresponding 10-part musical accompaniment, and features a unique kiss-throwing sequence. The surtido banna is a festival dance from Espiritu, Ilocos Norte; Banna was Espiritu’s old name. The surtido cebuano from Bantayan, Cebu was originally danced in quadrille formation by a number of pairs referred to as cabeceras (head pairs) and costados (side pairs or “flanks”), and uses a fan as a hand prop. The surtido norte combines the distinct steps and music of the Ilocos region and emphasizes the Ilocano kumintang gesture. The surtido samareño combines eight figures from the well-loved pandanguido, kuratsa, lubi-lubi, lawiswis kawayan, an marol, tinikling, inkoy-inkoy, and dos amigos.

The other documented surtido dances are performed in quadrille formation and are danced in the manner of rigodon de honor. Written by Corazon Generoso-Iñigo

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Tadek inlaud is the courtship dance of the lowland Tinguian, the indigenous group of Abra, which is one of the provinces that comprise the Cordillera region. This dance is also known as salukisik as the main musical instrument used for it is the salukisit, a hand-held bronze gong that is upturned then hit with a stick. It is played together with the drum to produce a fast, syncopated beat in 2/4 measure.

Traditionally, the male dancer wears only a headgear and a baal or loincloth for this dance. The female dancer, on the other hand, pairs a kimona or upper garment with a kain, a wrap-around skirt, usually cream-colored and accentuated with violet and maroon prints. Both dancers accessorize with batek or bracelets all made of beads of varying hues.

 

Each dancer holds an allap, a piece of cloth the size of a kain. A kain could also be used as an allap. The “wooing” commences when the male dancer waves his allap at waist level, an arm’s length in front of him, similar to the way a matador would brandish his cape in a bullfight. Then using small quick steps and with knees bent, both dancers approach but pass each other a few times. Occasionally, the male dancer moves toward his partner with elaborate foot stamping and high knees.

When dancing in place, they merely take mincing steps, but the footwork changes into a ball-heel action when they move about the stage, which is usually any flat, open space enclosed by the musicians and the audience. The male dancer’s occasional hopping and foot stamping symbolize a suitor’s courage, strength, and power. Unlike the male dancer who bends slightly forward every time he runs after his partner, the female dancer keeps her torso erect the whole time to signify a woman’s quiet dignity and grace. This dance ends when male and female finally meet face-to-face, and together, they sing the oggayam or Tinguian song whose lyrics change depending on the occasion. The singing signals the end of a successful courtship. Written by Sarah Lumba

Courtship and Wedding Dances

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
The takik of Western Mountain Province is a flirtation, love, or wedding dance. It is usually performed during the begnas, a ritual held during the planting and harvesting season.

One male dancer and at least three female dancers perform the takik. The man simulates the movements of a rooster, putting one foot forward, bending his torso toward the front, and flapping his arms like the bird’s wings. The women mimic a hen’s movements, trying to evade the persistent rooster in the beginning.

 

The male dancer, in his wanes or loin cloth and with a bedbed or headdress made of woven cloth, proudly enters with fast walking steps, then hops around on alternating feet as he keeps his arms stretched sideways, palms facing the ground, while he does hand flaps for every count. The female dancers enter one at a time. In her bedbed or three-piece cloth and beads, she faces him but still keeps her distance. Her arms are in a reverse T, overhead with elbows bent almost at a 45-degree angle and palms facing the heavens. This is combined with a step-close step. Her upper body is slightly bent forward. The male dancer runs toward her and begins a series of flirtatious moves and male posturing to exhibit his power, virility, and confidence: a lot of swinging of feet, hopping, gliding, and running around each female dancer. He repeats these steps for every female participant as the gangsa or gongs play, together with the solibao, a drum made from a hollow log five to six feet long and covered with a cowhide on one end, to produce the syncopated rhythm which is the trademark of Cordillera music. Written by Sarah Lumba

Courtship and Wedding Dances

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Tap dance is an entertainment dance where the dancers tap with their toes and heels. When done with metal cleats, it plays up the tapping sound; when danced without, it shuffles with the soft-shoe. In Germany, it is called the steptanz, the name by which it was known in the United States in the early days, until it became popular as the tap dance in the 1930s. Tap dancing is most often associated with African-Americans. It is said that the “parent of tap dancing,” Thomas Darmouth Rice, imitated an African-American man who improvised a song and antic, which Rice incorporated into his vaudeville act. Zip Coon (said to be Bob Farrel originally), a contemporary of Rice, danced the leeve, as the style was also called. George Washington Dixon wrote “Old Zip Coon” which became “Turkey in the Straw.” As a clog, the tap dance was done to 6/8 rhythm like a “quick waltz in half time;” as a leeve, it was done to 2/4 or 4/4, a march time that later became the fox-trot tempo. Many minstrel troupes and individuals popularized the style invented by the Blackfaces, the greatest of whom was the legendary Bill Robinson or Bojangles. His movies with Shirley Temple made him world famous. Paul Draper is a recent classicist who danced to Bach or Couperin, and composed a choreographed sonata all to his own tapping.

Although tap dance in the Philippines became popular mainly through the movies of Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers, it was performed much earlier by minstrel troupes around the turn of the century. In the 1930s, the brothers Richard and Raymond Reynolds made a team and also taught their fellow Filipino vaudeville entertainers. Buster and the Garcia sisters, Flor and Modesta, formed a trio of tap and jazz dancers. Charito “Chuchi” Hernandez had a Spanish-American tap and ballet teacher named Carmen Macleod.

 

Vaudeville and stage shows grew with the movies and movie musicals showed fine examples of tap dancing by Eleanor Powell who was billed as “the world’s greatest tap dancer,” Joan Crawford, Rita Hayworth, Anne Miller, Ray Bolger, Sammy Davis Jr, and the occasional or long-time teams: Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers, Judy Garland and Mickey Rooney, Vera Ellen and Gene Kelly, Debbie Reynolds and Donald O’Connor.

Locally, Nieves Manuel and Bayani Casimiro, known as the “Ginger Rogers and Fred Astaire of the Philippines,” teamed up. Comedian Casmot, later called Dandy, was a “tap dancing expert,” while many other stage show dancers like Dolphy and Nikki Ross tapped at one time or another. Tap dance was formally taught by Roberta Cassell in the late 1940s. Among her students were Carlyn Manning and Rose Borromeo, who became serious teachers of the popular art. Julie Borromeo learned it mainly from her sister Rose Borromeo who also taught Bing Locsin, whose sister, Agnes, also became a noted tap dance teacher and modern dance choreographer. Agnes Locsin has used Filipino ethnic music and themes to interpret the tap technique. As tap dance was a folk expression, it has affinities with some ethnic dancing. Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz
