article.value: Written by Basilio Esteban S. Villaruz

Although tap dance in the Philippines became popular mainly through the movies of Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers, it was performed much earlier by minstrel troupes around the turn of the century. In the 1930s, the brothers Richard and Raymond Reynolds made a team and also taught their fellow Filipino vaudeville entertainers. Buster and the Garcia sisters, Flor and Modesta, formed a trio of tap and jazz dancers. Charito “Chuchi” Hernandez had a Spanish-American tap and ballet teacher named Carmen Macleod.

Vaudeville and stage shows grew with the movies and movie musicals showed fine examples of tap dancing by Eleanor Powell who was billed as “the world’s greatest tap dancer,” Joan Crawford, Rita Hayworth, Anne Miller, Ray Bolger, Sammy Davis Jr, and the occasional or long-time teams: Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers, Judy Garland and Mickey Rooney, Vera Ellen and Gene Kelly, Debbie Reynolds and Donald O’Connor.

Locally, Nieves Manuel and Bayani Casimiro, known as the “Ginger Rogers and Fred Astaire of the Philippines,” teamed up. Comedian Casmot, later called Dandy, was a “tap dancing expert,” while many other stage show dancers like Dolphy and Nikki Ross tapped at one time or another. Tap dance was formally taught by Roberta Cassell in the late 1940s. Among her students were Carlyn Manning and Rose Borromeo, who became serious teachers of the popular art. Julie Borromeo learned it mainly from her sister Rose Borromeo who also taught Bing Locsin, whose sister, Agnes, also became a noted tap dance teacher and modern dance choreographer. Agnes Locsin has used Filipino ethnic music and themes to interpret the tap technique. As tap dance was a folk expression, it has affinities with some ethnic dancing.

text:
The tayao or tayaw is the common dance of the Ibaloy, Kankanaey, and Kalahan. It begins with the mambunong or shaman offering the sacrificial pigs to the Benguet god and ends with the dancers partaking of the tapae or rice wine offered them.

Dancers usually perform in a big circle to the syncopated beat typical of the Cordillera dances. Tayao music is produced by an ensemble of percussive instruments: the pallas or iron clappers; a solibao, a wooden drum measures five or six feet long with a “wide opening on one side covered with a cowhide … slapped with the fingers of the palm” (Taguba and Andin 1994, xi); a kalsa or gong made from brass or iron; a pinsak or small gong; and a kimbal or lower pitched drum.

 

A menedpao or male dancer has a pangjet (also shinget and binatjek) or cloth wrapped around his head. A kulibao (also kulebaw) or white blanket hangs from each of his shoulders and is spread up to his wrist to mimic the wings of a hawk in flight. Covering his loins is a kuval or a cloth measuring two and a half to three meters long wrapped around the waist. The meneshang or female dancer is wrapped in a sapey or safey, too—a sacred blanket. Under the sapey, she wears a kambal or blouse and an aten (also debit, divet, divit, and tapis) or wrap-around woven skirt. Both male and female dancers wear accessories such as the batding or leglets and the karing or bracelet.

The menedpao mainly has his “arms stretched sideward, palms facing upward, [as] fingers flip from wrist in every count” (Taguba and Andin 1994, 37) while the meneshang does the sadong or reverse-T position where her arms are raised overhead, with elbows bent and palms facing upward. In this dance, arms that are stretched out signify independence and freedom. The reverse-T position signifies worship, and for the indigenous people of Benguet, this stance is meant to honor their supreme god, Kabunian. These arm movements are accompanied by a lot of heavy running steps and hopping by the male and an easy step-close footwork with slight bouncing on the knees by the female. Female dancers more often dance in place and have smaller, subtler footwork.

The tayao is usually performed during big feasts called peshits or kanyaos. These big feasts—either weddings, death anniversaries, healing rituals, rice planting or harvesting season, and budong or peace pacts—could last for a month. Written by Sarah Lumba

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Tinikling is a mimetic dance that originated in the province of Leyte but is also common to other Visayan provinces. The name itself comes from the word “tikling,” which is a local name for the barred rail (Gallirallus torquatus), a long-legged bird with extended neck. The dance mimics the playful movements of the tikling as they forage in rice fields, where they avoid bamboo traps placed by farmers to protect the crops. To simulate the tikling’s plight, the barefoot tinikling dancers hop in and out of bamboo poles that clap together to a rhythm. The tinikling requires stamina, agility, and musicality to be able to keep up with the beat of the dance.

Tinikling is the most famous folk dance of the Philippines. It is actually considered by many the national dance of the Philippines. Because the tinikling is a great crowd pleaser, it has been made the mandatory finalé of most dance groups over the decades: the Bayanihan, the Far Eastern University Folk Dance Troupe, and the Baranggay Folk Dance Troupe in the 1950s and 1960s; the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group in the 1970s; and the Kaloob Philippine Music and Dance Ministry in the 2000s. From the basic number of four performers, folk dance groups have expanded the number of dancers to 20, or more. But the transformation of tinikling must be attributed to Leonor Orosa-Goquingco, later proclaimed National Artist for dance, who turned tinikling into a dazzling show stopper by speeding up the pace of the dancing to suit the taste of a Western audience.

 
 

The dance has two versions. The more famous one utilizes twin bamboo poles about nine feet long which are clapped apart in two counts and slid close together on the third count. The less popular and older version, called tinikling ha bayo, is more difficult because it uses two rice pestles about six feet long. Tinikling ha bayo is a recreational dance performed during the harvesting of rice. While resting after a rigorous session of pounding rice, harvesters take time to play the guitar, sing, and dance. Music is in 3/4 time.

Costumes consist of the patadyong (skirt), kimona (blouse), and panyo (scarf draped on a shoulder) for the women; and barong tagalog and a pair of red pants with one leg rolled below the knee for the men. Two persons position themselves opposite each other to hold the tips of the twin pestles. They strike the pestles over a wooden board to produce two major rhythms. A male and a female waltz their way to positions opposite the pestles and they tap their right foot in between the pestles on designated beats of each measure with three counts. This introduction is followed by seven figures with varying degrees of difficulty using leap and step, heel and toe, knee dip, kuradang (an interim syncopated waltz step with arms in fourth position done outside the poles), and tinikling step.

The basic tinikling step is executed with a leap on left foot outside pestles, followed by a leap on right foot between pestles, then a leap on left foot in between. Then the dancer leaps on right foot outside clapping pestles, succeeded by left skip in between, and jump on same foot to turn about. The female dancer holds the patadyong with her left hand and raises the right arm in reverse-T position with a kumintang (circular or wavelike hand movements from the wrist). The male dancer puts his hands on his waist. Meanwhile, the knee dip is a challenging movement that consists of standing outside the pestles, then bending the supporting leg as the other leg dips the knee to touch the floor in between pestles. The kuradang portion of tinikling ha bayo is executed outside the pestles, which consists of footwork and arm movements with kumintang flourish.

The popular version of tinikling that uses bamboo poles has eight figures consisting of 16 measures each. Dancers are positioned at the left side of the bamboo, with the dancer’s right shoulder near the poles. The tinikling’s basic step starts with a hop right inside the poles, followed by a hop left inside, then a hop right outside the poles. The repetition is reversed and the sequence is enhanced with arm movements with kumintang hand gestures. Half-turns are also executed while in between the poles. Then there is the whole figure with heel and toe combinations in between clapping bamboo poles. To animate the dancing, there is a crossover sequence done by hopping with the right foot in between the poles and then crossing the left foot over right ending with a hop outside the poles. This is followed by a kuradang portion wherein the couple dances outside bamboo poles. Then, the pair resumes dancing through the poles with the hopscotch figure, which consists of jumping inside the poles twice on both feet and hopping out each foot on both sides of the poles. Partners may hold hands as they dance the hopscotch figure. The next figure consists of variations on the crossover figure by changing the partners’ orientations and directions, and by adding half-turns. The dance ends with the basic steps, and then a bow with a pose. Written by Rosalie S. Matilac

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
The tongatong, sometimes called chonggachong, is a ritual dance of the Baliwon tribe of Paracelis, Mountain Province. It is usually performed at the beginning of a wedding feast, with the bride and the groom beginning the dance, later on followed by their guests. It could also be danced during other important occasions, with at least six male and two female dancers involved.

Unlike most Cordillera dances that rely on bronze gangsa or gongs for music, this dance makes use of the tongatong, which are bamboo tubes of varying lengths and pitches. The longer the bamboo, the lower the pitch it makes when one of its ends is pounded on the ground. The rhythm produced by the combination of bamboo tubes is still syncopated, which is characteristic of all Cordillera dances.

The movements of the tongatong are reminiscent of the courtship dances of Abra and Kalinga. The groom or male dancer zigzags towards his bride or female partner, using a step-hop move, and with his torso bent, he waves the allap, a piece of unsewn cloth, in front of him to attract his partner’s attention. The bride feigns indifference at his romantic attempts. Dressed in a lumfon (also lomfon), which is a blouse, and a tapis (also kain) or colored woven wrap-around skirt, she keeps her hands on her hips, and proudly goes the opposite direction using a step-hop step. Undaunted, the groom, dressed only in be-er (also ba-ar) or loincloth and a gongon or beaded necklace, runs after her. He dances around her, hopping or springing about following the fast tempo of the tongatong and offers his allap every chance he gets. She continues to dance, too, either with her hands on her hips or with arms stretched sideways, fingers pointing upward. At one point, she deliberately moves towards him, only to have him chase after her the next. This happens a few times—a series of flirtatious moves on her part. Eventually she relents and accepts the allap, the symbol of his affection and his ability to protect her. She places the cloth over both their shoulders, and then they exit together. Written by Sarah Lumba

description: Indigenous, folk, Hispanic, and Western dance forms in the Philippines
text:
Tumahik, which literally translates to “war dance” in Yakan bahasa, is a male martial dance of the Yakan ethnic group originating from Basilan province. The province of Basilan, founded in 1974, is the largest and northernmost island of the Sulu Archipelago located just across the southern shoreline of Zamboanga Peninsula. One of the municipalities of Basilan Province is Lamitan, the original home of the Yakan.

Tumahik dance steps and movement patterns are reflective of the Yakans’ love for horses. Traditionally, owning a number of horses was a sign of wealth and status. Each Yakan family owned a horse as animal of labor and means of transportation. In a tumahik performance, as the legs of a dancer move, the jambu (tassels) of the leggings swing to and fro like the horse’s tail. The men display intricate footwork likened to the frenetic movements of enraged horses: trotting, galloping, kicking, jumping, skipping, or limping when hurt.

 

Traditionally, tumahik was performed during combat to settle disputes or to defend themselves from invading groups. While going through the motions of the dance, the warriors would stick out their tongue and spit. They made grotesque facial expressions: gritting their teeth and sneering, sending dagger looks, and making their cheeks quiver to infuriate opponents. The more aggressive performance won over the more subdued one.

In the past, the Yakan considered the tumahik as the only acceptable dance form in the community, as the women, especially those coming from very conservative families, were not allowed to be seen in public, or to be in the presence of men. The dance also became an important training and rite of passage for Yakan boys five years old and above. The father, as the principal trainer, guides his son/s by familiarizing them with the most important items, like the budjak (spear) and the taming (shield). He teaches the boys how to use the spear with the correct stance, footwork, and facial expressions. He also demonstrates how to wear the traditional attire and accessories that go with the war dance. As the trainees mature, the martial training becomes more rigid with the objective of transforming them into fearless warriors. The young men acquire precise and strong techniques in the movement of the hands, wrists, arms, body, legs, and feet. These are essential to enable the young fighters to deftly wield the spear and the shield in assault and defense.

 

Tumahik is revered by the elders of the community. The dance plays a significant role during a wedding ceremony or pegkawin. The tumahik performance during a wedding ceremony has a three-fold purpose: first, to ward off evil spirits that might disturb the three-day ceremony; second, to serve as a rite of passage for the young man to enter adulthood; and third, to prepare the groom for greater responsibilities like earning a living for his family and protecting his wife and children from harm and danger.

During the pegkawin or wedding ceremony, the groom’s relatives, who are also tumahik dancers, accompany him to the bride’s house. The pangantin lella (groom) performs the tumahik while his relatives and the imam approach the bride’s house where the wedding ceremony is set. Holding the spear with his right hand and shield with his left, the groom thrusts the spear in the ground in front of the house while the parents and relatives of the pangantin dende (bride) wait at the pantan (porch). The ceremony cannot proceed unless the groom dances the tumahik. As soon as the groom finishes the dance, tagungguh (gong ensemble) musicians play the megtambul (tumahik beat) and expert tumahik dancers take turns to show-off their abilities. A pamansak or pangalay dancer accompanies the performance. The groom and his entourage are allowed to approach the stairs of the house after the dance performances. A relative sings the sa-il, a Yakan song, and the group enters the house with a warm reception from the bride’s family.

The fundamental dance steps of the tumahik are grounded on the basic dance position or stance called ningkas. The dancer stands with his left foot in front, toe touching the ground, knees turned-in, and the right foot bearing weight of the body. He holds the spear with his right above the head and the left hand clutches the shield covering his body.

There are six basic foot movements: magkahig is the motion of scratching the floor by touching the floor with the left or right toe, then brushing the toe backwards. Magpasu simulates the trotting of horses, with turned-out feet that are apart with bent knees, then heels are raised and move to any direction. When they hit the ground, the balls of the feet produce a stamping sound like the hoofs of horses. Netek is a movement that kicks backwards from the magkahig, in which the dancer brushes his right or left toe backwards, hitting his ankle against his thigh or butt, with the heel of the left or right foot raised. Patugpah or skipping movement is done with the dancer hopping continuously forward or to any direction alternately with right and left foot. Patindak is a movement characterized by forward kicks. The dancer kicks the opponent’s knee with his left or right foot. He pushes the leg of the opponent down with the arch of his foot. Palaksu or jumping is done with the dancer standing in fourth position, either left or right foot in front. He springs forward with one or both feet, either with both knees bent on air or with one leg kicking forward or from the side. He then lands in the same or different position with another stance.

Tumahik arm movements are less elaborate. The right hand holding the spear may do the movement called kinaagen (shaking the spear) or mag-bono’ kuntara (striking the spear). The left hand clutching the shield must maintain the postures of maglekkeb baranin (covering the body) or migpid tammingin (shaking of the shield).

The three basic head movements are magkeleng-keleng or shaking the head from side to side; the maglengek-lengek or dangling the head from side to side; and the magpapatey-patey or kuweh matey described as hanging the head at one side, the eyes devoid of expression. The facial expressions throughout the dance are calculated to provoke or to antagonize the opponent. Magkuti-kuti means to tease or invite the enemy to attack, moving the head downwards and eyes looking fierce. Magtige-et is to grit the teeth. Magkisi means to grin. Magbingis mata is to look fierce. Ngusah means to move the cheeks. Maglurah is to spit.

Tumahik dancers wear the badju (top) and sawwal (trousers) which are entirely made of hand woven sinelu’an or of purchased material. The Yakan of Lamitan town proper used to wear garments made from a black cloth called naynay. Traditionally, these shirts and trousers are tight at the sleeves and leggings. Traditional Yakan trousers or sawwal are tight-fitting from the knee down while the section from the thigh going up hangs loose, sewn at the waist with a band of cloth that firmly holds the pants in place when folded. It has a knee-joinery line called bakiyaq, an embroidery of tiny chain stitches of four to six color bands. A sapid or braid, made of intertwined threads, is stitched at the section where the woven cloth is sewn together and around the part of the leggings that reaches the ankle. A sawwal will not be complete without leg tassels made of silk threads called jambu to symbolize their favorite animal, the horse.

The badju is a tight-fitting top with tight-fitting sleeves and decorated with gold buttons called batawi. The size and the number of batawi on a shirt determine the prominence of the wearer. The badju also serves as an overcoat or jacket and is elaborately decorated on weddings, graduations, or the grand feast of Lami-lamihan. The men don the pis or head cloth, with a red background symbolizing bravery and strength, coupled with green, yellow, and black patterns. Aside from serving as head protection from heat and during combat, the pis serves as blanket or mat at night or in transit. When used as head cloth, it is folded into a triangle, with the apex on the forehead and the two ends knotted at the nape.

Men also wear the kandit or traditional belt which measures up to 15 m or more made of red cotton cloth called gilim. This is tediously coiled around the waist with tassels of unwoven sine’luan cloth sewn at one end to cover the genital area. The belt is worn for protection during combat. Sometimes the kandit may be used as a hammock or as a pillow. The Yakan accessorize their costume with sappa or lutuan which is a betel nut container tied around the waist; the barung lella or male bolo; and the saruk or nito hat.

Megtambul music is the accompaniment for any tumahik performance. The music is produced by the tagungguh composed of three gongs of different sizes, the set of kwintangan tumbaga (graduated bronze gongs), and the gandang (split bamboo tube).

The tumahik is an important tradition reflective of the ancient culture of the Yakan. In 2013, the Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao and Basilan Province launched the first Tumahik Festival. Though the dance is synonymous with war and fighting, the tumahik is also a symbol of the husband’s responsibility to protect his wife and family. The latter is the relevant cultural value being propagated by the Tumahik Festival. In the light of the continuing strife in Basilan Province, the Tumahik Festival, erstwhile a symbol of war, is now used as a symbol of protection. Each participating group wears their typical Yakan attire, especially the men, who bring with them their weapons, shields, betel chewing containers, and other properties. The festival provides an important venue for the Yakan to hone and exhibit their dancing prowess accompanied by the skillful playing of the traditional tagungguh. The Tumahik Festival promises to uphold Yakan cultural identity. Written by Earl Francis C. Pasilan and Rosalie S. Matilac

article.value: Written by Earl Francis C. Pasilan and Rosalie S. Matilac

Tumahik dance steps and movement patterns are reflective of the Yakans’ love for horses. Traditionally, owning a number of horses was a sign of wealth and status. Each Yakan family owned a horse as animal of labor and means of transportation. In a tumahik performance, as the legs of a dancer move, the jambu (tassels) of the leggings swing to and fro like the horse’s tail. The men display intricate footwork likened to the frenetic movements of enraged horses: trotting, galloping, kicking, jumping, skipping, or limping when hurt.

Traditionally, tumahik was performed during combat to settle disputes or to defend themselves from invading groups. While going through the motions of the dance, the warriors would stick out their tongue and spit. They made grotesque facial expressions: gritting their teeth and sneering, sending dagger looks, and making their cheeks quiver to infuriate opponents. The more aggressive performance won over the more subdued one.

In the past, the Yakan considered the tumahik as the only acceptable dance form in the community, as the women, especially those coming from very conservative families, were not allowed to be seen in public, or to be in the presence of men. The dance also became an important training and rite of passage for Yakan boys five years old and above. The father, as the principal trainer, guides his son/s by familiarizing them with the most important items, like the budjak (spear) and the taming (shield). He teaches the boys how to use the spear with the correct stance, footwork, and facial expressions. He also demonstrates how to wear the traditional attire and accessories that go with the war dance. As the trainees mature, the martial training becomes more rigid with the objective of transforming them into fearless warriors. The young men acquire precise and strong techniques in the movement of the hands, wrists, arms, body, legs, and feet. These are essential to enable the young fighters to deftly wield the spear and the shield in assault and defense.

Tumahik is revered by the elders of the community. The dance plays a significant role during a wedding ceremony or pegkawin. The tumahik performance during a wedding ceremony has a three-fold purpose: first, to ward off evil spirits that might disturb the three-day ceremony; second, to serve as a rite of passage for the young man to enter adulthood; and third, to prepare the groom for greater responsibilities like earning a living for his family and protecting his wife and children from harm and danger.

During the pegkawin or wedding ceremony, the groom’s relatives, who are also tumahik dancers, accompany him to the bride’s house. The pangantin lella (groom) performs the tumahik while his relatives and the imam approach the bride’s house where the wedding ceremony is set. Holding the spear with his right hand and shield with his left, the groom thrusts the spear in the ground in front of the house while the parents and relatives of the pangantin dende (bride) wait at the pantan (porch). The ceremony cannot proceed unless the groom dances the tumahik. As soon as the groom finishes the dance, tagungguh (gong ensemble) musicians play the megtambul (tumahik beat) and expert tumahik dancers take turns to show-off their abilities. A pamansak or pangalay dancer accompanies the performance. The groom and his entourage are allowed to approach the stairs of the house after the dance performances. A relative sings the sa-il, a Yakan song, and the group enters the house with a warm reception from the bride’s family.

The fundamental dance steps of the tumahik are grounded on the basic dance position or stance called ningkas. The dancer stands with his left foot in front, toe touching the ground, knees turned-in, and the right foot bearing weight of the body. He holds the spear with his right above the head and the left hand clutches the shield covering his body.

There are six basic foot movements: magkahig is the motion of scratching the floor by touching the floor with the left or right toe, then brushing the toe backwards. Magpasu simulates the trotting of horses, with turned-out feet that are apart with bent knees, then heels are raised and move to any direction. When they hit the ground, the balls of the feet produce a stamping sound like the hoofs of horses. Netek is a movement that kicks backwards from the magkahig, in which the dancer brushes his right or left toe backwards, hitting his ankle against his thigh or butt, with the heel of the left or right foot raised. Patugpah or skipping movement is done with the dancer hopping continuously forward or to any direction alternately with right and left foot. Patindak is a movement characterized by forward kicks. The dancer kicks the opponent’s knee with his left or right foot. He pushes the leg of the opponent down with the arch of his foot. Palaksu or jumping is done with the dancer standing in fourth position, either left or right foot in front. He springs forward with one or both feet, either with both knees bent on air or with one leg kicking forward or from the side. He then lands in the same or different position with another stance.

Tumahik arm movements are less elaborate. The right hand holding the spear may do the movement called kinaagen (shaking the spear) or mag-bono’ kuntara (striking the spear). The left hand clutching the shield must maintain the postures of maglekkeb baranin (covering the body) or migpid tammingin (shaking of the shield).

The three basic head movements are magkeleng-keleng or shaking the head from side to side; the maglengek-lengek or dangling the head from side to side; and the magpapatey-patey or kuweh matey described as hanging the head at one side, the eyes devoid of expression. The facial expressions throughout the dance are calculated to provoke or to antagonize the opponent. Magkuti-kuti means to tease or invite the enemy to attack, moving the head downwards and eyes looking fierce. Magtige-et is to grit the teeth. Magkisi means to grin. Magbingis mata is to look fierce. Ngusah means to move the cheeks. Maglurah is to spit.

Tumahik dancers wear the badju (top) and sawwal (trousers) which are entirely made of hand woven sinelu’an or of purchased material. The Yakan of Lamitan town proper used to wear garments made from a black cloth called naynay. Traditionally, these shirts and trousers are tight at the sleeves and leggings. Traditional Yakan trousers or sawwal are tight-fitting from the knee down while the section from the thigh going up hangs loose, sewn at the waist with a band of cloth that firmly holds the pants in place when folded. It has a knee-joinery line called bakiyaq, an embroidery of tiny chain stitches of four to six color bands. A sapid or braid, made of intertwined threads, is stitched at the section where the woven cloth is sewn together and around the part of the leggings that reaches the ankle. A sawwal will not be complete without leg tassels made of silk threads called jambu to symbolize their favorite animal, the horse.

The badju is a tight-fitting top with tight-fitting sleeves and decorated with gold buttons called batawi. The size and the number of batawi on a shirt determine the prominence of the wearer. The badju also serves as an overcoat or jacket and is elaborately decorated on weddings, graduations, or the grand feast of Lami-lamihan. text:
TV dance or television dancing refers to dancing adapted to or expressly created for a television show, whether the dance is part of a variety show with many numbers or is the main activity and attraction of the show. In looking at the growth of Philippine TV dancing and how it has become a cultural phenomenon, the role of camera manipulation and image-capturing techniques cannot be ignored. Behind each dance performance’s appearance on the monitor is the director’s command of the specific perspective of the camera; each angle or shot results in a particular rendering of the dance.

American dances continued to be influential in the Philippines after World War II. The decade of ballroom dancing in the 1940s gave way to the rock and roll era of the 1950s which also ushered in the beginning of dancing in TV variety shows. The Nida-Nestor Show, 1964-72, popularized the cha-cha and the boogie choreographed by Julie Borromeo. Borromeo went on to choreograph the weekly show of Pilita Corrales, mostly with dancers of Dance Theater Philippines. Helen Gamboa, the original “Dancing Queen” became popular in both films and TV with her signature song and dance Bang-Shang-A-Lang. She starred in her own show Helen, 1966-70, and was later dubbed as the diva of the 1960s. In the late 1960s and early 1970s, the trend among dancers and TV and movie stars in shows such as Dance-O-Rama, 1967-72, was dancing “ad lib” or “maskipaps” (a shortened version of the Filipino phrase “Maski papaano,” which translates to “anything goes”), picking up steps from signature dances such as the chicken, mashed potatoes, the shovel, and watusi.

 

In the 1970s, dances like the hustle, the bus stop, the bump, the L.A. walk, the grind, funk, pop from the record label Motown and their accompanying flashing disco lights bedazzled TV viewers with several dancers and choreographers leaving their mark on local television. Early in the scene were Al Quinn, Lito Calzado, and Chito Feliciano who started the dance craze even before the dance instructors in Dance Time with Chito (1962-72) caught the public’s interest in dance.

Successful TV dancers all had signature steps that were appealing to televiewers: Mike Monserat and Poncy Quirino of the Funky and Latin group of Penthouse 7, 1975-82, the Aldeguer sisters Lally and Terry, Chato Sugay, Pia Moran, Vivian Velez, Bella Dimayuga, pop legend Geleen Eugenio, “Ms. Body Language of T.O.D.A.S.” Frieda Fonda, and the “Choreographer to the Stars” Maribeth Bichara. Television reworked the vocabulary of ballet. For instance, the Aldeguer sisters reinvented the ballet genre and came up with their signature “toss head back, pas de bourreé, cartwheel and split” combination. This was later used by a new breed of dancers and choreographers like Eugenio, who worked with a group of sister recording companies: Electro Sound Center, Dyna Music, WEA Records, and other top record labels under one umbrella. The dance duo Geleen and John (Eugenio and Gaddi) which first danced on Penthouse 7 later merged with The 8th of Sep, a group of modern dancers headed by choreographer Raffy Chan. Performing cultural, pop, and contemporary dances, they formed the WEA Dancers. The group got bigger with the addition of the WEA twins Joy and Gay Pobre and was eventually known as the WEA Family, appearing weekly in several TV variety programs, such as in one of the longest running TV variety shows, Superstar, 1972-89; Superstar sa 13 on IBC 13; and Superstar: Beyond Time, on RPN 9, both in the 1990s. As the WEA dancers dominated Philippine TV, Eugenio introduced signature steps such as new wave, the rock, punk rock, metallic gigolo, the wanderer, modern romance, curly shuffle, freaky and a variety of signature pop dances.

 

In the 1980s, the disco with its iconic mirror ball and psychedelic graffiti was still popular, while the street dance style of hip-hop and locking and popping of breakdancing followed suit. The widespread new dance style of soul, funk, jazz, rap, and r&b eventually gave way to jazz funk which became the new dance vogue in both TV and films. The advent of retro-pop culture also saw the increase in number of international music labels and more commercial signature steps. Recording companies had in-house dancers for their labels: the WEA Dancers for Warner Elektra Atlantic labels; Vicor Dancers & Vicor Crowd for the Vicor Music Corporation; the DYNA Dancers for DYNA Music; the Blackgold Dancers for Blackgold Records; the ALPHA Dancers for ALPHA Music; the PolyCosmic Dancers, Polycosmic Kukuz, and Polygram Dancers for PolyEast Records; and the OctoArts Dancers and Octo Mechanics, for Octo Arts/EMI Records. There were also ghost dancers or dancers who did not belong to the main recording label dancers but nonetheless promoted the same music as a follow-up promotion for the record company: WEA Pop Girls, Ral’s Dancers, Disco Fantasy, Discorporation Dancers, Katz, Maneuvers, Knapsax, X People, Body Heat, Danz Promo, Kids at Work, Beat Culture, Abstract Dancers, Streetboys, and the Universal Motion Dancers. Members of these groups were regular dancers for top variety TV shows and also appeared in movies.

Dance innovations or fusions, which were common in clubs, fitness centers, and parties, began to be featured in Philippine TV shows in the 1980s and continued to do so till the 1990s as local celebrities proved to be versatile performers who could dance with athletic grace and form. The popularity of these TV/movie idols saw the rise in the number of TV variety shows, which in turn increased the demand for dance groups for TV shows like Vilma!, later retitled Vilma In Person, 1986-95; Superstar, 1972-89; Maria! Maria!, later retitled Maricel Live!, 1986-89; The Other Side of Alma, 1981-83, and Loveliness, 1987-88; Manilyn Live!, 1986-88; Lotlot and Friends, 1985-88; Tonight with Dick and Carmi, 1988-91; Pops!, 1992-96; Vina, 1993-94; and The Sharon Cuneta Show, 1986-88, 1988-97, on IBC 13 and subsequently on ABS-CBN 2. With many stars having variety shows, the battle of opening production numbers began in the late 1980s and lasted until the 1990s.

Simultaneous with the expansion of local recording companies was the birth of independent dance groups like the VIP Dancers, Powerdance, Hotlegs, Adrenaline, Whiplash, Solid Gold, Discorama Dancers, Julie Borromeo’s Dance Arts, and Veda Bañez’s Metropolitan Dancers which also shifted to commercial TV. The VIP Dancers danced for Vilma! on BBC 2 and later for Vilma In Person. Vilma Santos was known for her death-defying dance routines in the show Vilma! With its in-house choreographer, Maribeth Bichara, it became the most awarded musical variety show in local TV history. The VIP Dancers’ style of dancing was diverse: commercial pop, street dance, ballet, jazz, gymnastics, hip-hop, ballroom, folk, funk, broadway, theatrics or theatrical, and athletic dance steps were complemented by the use of props. The movement combinations by the VIP Dancers paved the way for more dance fusions on Philippine TV which is seen until today.

The 1990s witnessed crossovers from the 1980s. The developments in technology linked us to new video games, DJ scratching, line dancing, and other new dance styles like the tootsie roll, the jiggy, da dip, macarena, electric slide, and the running man. Associated with these dances was a range of looks and fashion styles such as the grunge look and hair spray, cargo pants and MC Hammer pants, Nike ball caps with tags, and chain necklaces with charms which were worn by many dancers on TV shows. Hip-hop, a major dance genre of the decade, was usually accompanied by a DJ’s record scratching. Stunts such as leaps, somersaults, flips, rolls, hand stand, head stand, tumbling, and a combination of movements from gymnastics, ballet, ballroom, cheerdance, and other athletic moves were basic to this dance.

Worldwide, the most popular dance was the macarena, with its signature arm movement combination and an eight-step line dancing. Locally, it was promoted by the Maneuvers. A number of pop-locking groups like Kidz at Work, Danz Promo, Octo Full Force, X-10, Universal Motion Dancers, Streetboys, Dyna Dance Squad, Teensquad, Abstract Dancers, and Sexbomb Dancers emerged at the time. The decade likewise saw the birth of a new genre, ballroom fusion, introduced by the VIP Dancers.

The VIP Dancers also had their own show entitled Eezy Dancing on TV5, 1995-98, which was later re-titled Keep On Dancing on ABS-CBN 2, 1998-2001, with the addition of Australian Marc Nelson. As ballroom dancing became popular on Philippine TV, it also became a sensation in clubs, afternoon discos, and bars. It also gave birth to a social but competitive dance, popularly known as dancesport. Later, this was showcased on Philippine TV by a reality dance competition program hosted by Lucy Torres-Gomez in her show Shall We Dance, 2005-10, which eventually became Celebrity Dance Battle.

In 2001, the ubiquitous street dance and modern dance had movements borrowed from ballet or based on the lyrics of songs. Lyrical dance, or the new interpretative dance, falls under the category of hip-hop. The latter, which remains popular, borrows moves from different cultures and has changed the landscape of TV dancing. Meanwhile, a new generation of dance groups began appearing on local TV: the Dance Crews; the Philippine All Stars; the Intensity Breakers; the Team Imusenio; the Ad Lib; the Philippines Hip Dance Crew; the Philippines Underground Crew; the Extreme Boyz Gen San; and Jabbawockees. The latter is also known as the Fil-Am International Dancers. As a group, they won the 2006 and 2008 World Hip Hop Dance Championship. They specialize in a spin-off genre of hip-hop popularly known as urban dance. As b-boy dancers, many groups have also brought pride to the country by winning in international competitions.

Common among Philippine TV shows of the new millennium are permanent performers like the Sexbomb Dancers and EB Babes of Eat Bulaga!, the Go Girls of Magandang Tanghali Bayan, and the Showtime Dancers of It's Showtime. In the absence of “company” dancers dominating Philippine TV, there is now the G-Force which reinvented the urban style of the 20th century by pushing the limits of dance fusion. Collegiate pep squads have also become stronger and more competitive in both local and international cheerdance competitions. College pep squads have been invited to perform on local TV shows, and the UAAP Cheerdance Competition and the NCCA Cheerleading Competition are both regularly televised during the college athletic season.

In the 2000s, TV dancing saw dances that shared the vocabulary of earlier dances. Krumping with its vocabulary of battle, biter, session, buck, call out, labbing kill-off, and jabs shares moves with hip-hop. Also incorporated in krumping’s dance moves are different dance styles—pop and lock, chest pop, arm wave, and crisscross—seen on TV as dance groups “battle” with each other. But there are also viewers who feel that there are dances like twerking and pumping that have lost the “story” of dance by becoming too centered on the dancer and by displaying moves that are very sexually suggestive. Some groups associated with these are the V-Boyz and Men In Heels Dancing. These all-male groups usually perform very feminine routines, which have become popular on local television variety shows as well as online platforms like YouTube.

Looking back at the development of TV dancing in the Philippines, it can be said that reinvention or innovation of dance genres is one of the reasons why dance on TV remains strong. Moreover, it has demonstrated that global influences have informed the evolution of various dance genres and forms. Written by Alberto L. Dimarucut and J. Santos

With many stars having variety shows, the battle of opening production numbers began in the late 1980s and lasted until the 1990s.

Simultaneous with the expansion of local recording companies was the birth of independent dance groups like the VIP Dancers, Powerdance, Hotlegs, Adrenaline, Whiplash, Solid Gold, Discorama Dancers, Julie Borromeo’s Dance Arts, and Veda Bañez’s Metropolitan Dancers which also shifted to commercial TV. The VIP Dancers danced for Vilma! on BBC 2 and later for Vilma In Person. Vilma Santos was known for her death-defying dance routines in the show Vilma! With its in-house choreographer, Maribeth Bichara, it became the most awarded musical variety show in local TV history. The VIP Dancers’ style of dancing was diverse: commercial pop, street dance, ballet, jazz, gymnastics, hip-hop, ballroom, folk, funk, broadway, theatrics or theatrical, and athletic dance steps were complemented by the use of props. The movement combinations by the VIP Dancers paved the way for more dance fusions on Philippine TV which is seen until today.

The 1990s witnessed crossovers from the 1980s. The developments in technology linked us to new video games, DJ scratching, line dancing, and other new dance styles like the tootsie roll, the jiggy, da dip, macarena, electric slide, and the running man. Associated with these dances was a range of looks and fashion styles such as the grunge look and hair spray, cargo pants and MC Hammer pants, Nike ball caps with tags, and chain necklaces with charms which were worn by many dancers on TV shows. Hip-hop, a major dance genre of the decade, was usually accompanied by a DJ’s record scratching. Stunts such as leaps, somersaults, flips, rolls, hand stand, head stand, tumbling, and a combination of movements from gymnastics, ballet, ballroom, cheerdance, and other athletic moves were basic to this dance.

Worldwide, the most popular dance was the macarena, with its signature arm movement combination and an eight-step line dancing. Locally, it was promoted by the Maneuvers. A number of pop-locking groups like Kidz at Work, Danz Promo, Octo Full Force, X-10, Universal Motion Dancers, Streetboys, Dyna Dance Squad, Teensquad, Abstract Dancers, and Sexbomb Dancers emerged at the time. The decade likewise saw the birth of a new genre, ballroom fusion, introduced by the VIP Dancers.

The VIP Dancers also had their own show entitled Eezy Dancing on TV5, 1995-98, which was later re-titled Keep On Dancing on ABS-CBN 2, 1998-2001, with the addition of Australian Marc Nelson. As ballroom dancing became popular on Philippine TV, it also became a sensation in clubs, afternoon discos, and bars. It also gave birth to a social but competitive dance, popularly known as dancesport. Later, this was showcased on Philippine TV by a reality dance competition program hosted by Lucy Torres-Gomez in her show Shall We Dance, 2005-10, which eventually became Celebrity Dance Battle.

In 2001, the ubiquitous street dance and modern dance had movements borrowed from ballet or based on the lyrics of songs. Lyrical dance, or the new interpretative dance, falls under the category of hip-hop. The latter, which remains popular, borrows moves from different cultures and has changed the landscape of TV dancing. Meanwhile, a new generation of dance groups began appearing on local TV: the Dance Crews; the Philippine All Stars; the Intensity Breakers; the Team Imusenio; the Ad Lib; the Philippines Hip Dance Crew; the Philippines Underground Crew; the Extreme Boyz Gen San; and Jabbawockees. The latter is also known as the Fil-Am International Dancers. As a group, they won the 2006 and 2008 World Hip Hop Dance Championship. They specialize in a spin-off genre of hip-hop popularly known as urban dance. As b-boy dancers, many groups have also brought pride to the country by winning in international competitions.

Common among Philippine TV shows of the new millennium are permanent performers like the Sexbomb Dancers and EB Babes of Eat Bulaga!, the Go Girls of Magandang Tanghali Bayan, and the Showtime Dancers of It's Showtime. In the absence of “company” dancers dominating Philippine TV, there is now the G-Force which reinvented the urban style of the 20th century by pushing the limits of dance fusion. Collegiate pep squads have also become stronger and more competitive in both local and international cheerdance competitions. College pep squads have been invited to perform on local TV shows, and the UAAP Cheerdance Competition and the NCCA Cheerleading Competition are both regularly televised during the college athletic season.

In the 2000s, TV dancing saw dances that shared the vocabulary of earlier dances. Krumping with its vocabulary of battle, biter, session, buck, call out, labbing kill-off, and jabs shares moves with hip-hop. Also incorporated in krumping’s dance moves are different dance styles—pop and lock, chest pop, arm wave, and crisscross—seen on TV as dance groups “battle” with each other. But there are also viewers who feel that there are dances like twerking and pumping that have lost the “story” of dance by becoming too centered on the dancer and by displaying moves that are very sexually suggestive. Some groups associated with these are the V-Boyz and Men In Heels Dancing. These all-male groups usually perform very feminine routines, which have become popular on local television variety shows as well as online platforms like YouTube.

Looking back at the development of TV dancing in the Philippines, it can be said that reinvention or innovation of dance genres is one of the reasons why dance on TV remains strong. Moreover, it has demonstrated that global influences have informed the evolution of various dance genres and forms.
